IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease remains the leading cause of mortality in the U.S., but its multi-factorial mechanisms and early detection are not well established. Applying new analyses of cardiovascular magnetic resonance images and integrating these measures with broad existing data including risk factors, genetics, and blood biomarkers, we will obtain deeper understanding of structure and function of the heart in older aged white and African American adults. Ultimately, accomplishment of this project will facilitate new strategies towards cardiovascular disease prevention and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It is now clear from large-scale sequencing of cancer genomes that mutational co-occurrence and the relative timing of mutational acquisition follow non-random patterns, but limited studies have addressed the impact of mutational order and cooperation in oncogenesis. The proposed project harnesses a unique iPSC-based model of de novo oncogenesis developed in my laboratory to address fundamental principles underlying the effects of mutational order on leukemogenesis and oncogenesis in general.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The incidence of premature birth (delivery more than three weeks early) is increasing worldwide and many infants born extremely preterm (less than 28 weeks' gestation) suffer long-term lung disease resulting from injury due to oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation. These former preterm infants experience lifelong breathing problems, including wheezing and increased respiratory infection severity which puts a high burden on the health care system because of the need for continued care and rehospitalization. This project will contribute to our understanding of reasons why preterm infants and their oxygen exposures at birth leave them vulnerable to worse respiratory infections and wheezing later in life, in attempts to alleviate this burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The vision of the Health Systems Node of the National Institute on Drug Abuse’s Clinical Trials Network is to transform treatment for substance use disorder through integration of care into real-word medical settings. Through its network of 16 learning health systems from across the United States, the Health Systems Node will conduct research that increases identification of patients who need care and identifies multiple effective treatment options. As part of the Clinical Trials Network, the Health Systems Node will continue to build the infrastructure required for high impact research to address the nation’s urgent need to address substance use disorder along the spectrum of care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement: Glioblastoma (GBM) is the most prevalent and malignant primary brain tumor in adults, with a median patient survival of about 15 months after standard treatment. The proposed research will define the role of a novel long non-coding RNA (lncRNA) and a lncRNA/RNA-binding protein complex in promoting the cell-cycle progression and in regulating radiosensitivity of GBM cells/glioma stem cells (GSCs), and will reveal a new mechanism of its function. The proposed studies will provide new insight into how lncRNAs contribute to the molecular pathogenesis of GBM and may help develop effective therapeutic strategies to treat this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on developing state-of-the-art single-cell genomic approaches that enable a comprehensive view of cellular temporal-spatial dynamics in neurogenesis and apply them to investigate the molecular mechanism underlying neurogenesis dysregulation in aging and Alzheimer’s disease. Once such strategies have been developed, there is a potential for a significant advance in designing therapeutic targets to trigger neurogenesis and restore cell population homeostasis in aging and neurodegenerative diseases. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epithelial cells line the airways and are important for maintaining lung health. Airway epithelial cell dysfunction is a key feature of asthma and other common airway diseases. This project will study how genes are regulated in airway epithelial cells and is designed to provide a scientific basis for designing new approaches to prevent, cure, or treat airway diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immunotherapy has revolutionized the way we treat a number of malignancies, but to date its impact in pancreatic cancer has been marginal. We know, for example, that conventional immune checkpoint inhibitors approved for use in melanoma, lung cancer, and other solid tumors show little or no benefit for the vast majority of pancreatic cancer patients, and that additional “priming” of the immune system will be absolutely necessary to overcome the intrinsic resistance of pancreatic tumors to immunotherapy. To achieve this goal, we will study in preclinical models of pancreatic cancer and in a clinical trial a new immunotherapeutic strategy that combines drugs across several therapeutic classes shown by our data to be highly interdependent.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Obesity related to overnutrition has become a global epidemic that increasingly strains our health care system and has few effective non-surgical therapies. Here, we seek to better understand how high fat diet causes hypothalamic inflammation, one of the earliest pathological responses to overnutrition observed. We focus on the critical role tanycytes, a unique cell type that faces the blood stream on one side and the brain on the other, play in initiating the pathologic response to overnutrition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: The proposed project will address an urgent public health need to optimize the accuracy and validity in measuring cognitive decline due to AD/ADRD in the rapidly growing and aging Latino/a/x older adult population. The proposal will investigate whether available tools for the assessment of cognitive impairment due to AD/ADRD measure cognitive and functional decline equivalently in Latino/a/x compared to non-Latinx white older adults. This research will lead to more accurate estimates of the prevalence, determinants, and impact of AD/ADRD in Latino/a/x older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This research seeks to improve long-term survival for individuals diagnosed with pancreas cancer by (1) evaluating the safety and efficacy of a potentially curative surgical resection for patients with initially unresectable disease, (2) validating a novel culture technique as a tool to deepen our fundamental knowledge of the disease and (3) demonstrate the promise of applying a novel culture technique to provide personalized therapeutic recommendations, lengthen life, and increase rates of cure. This research will also serve as a foundation for career development with a goal of providing leadership in future team science initiatives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Vision impairment affects over 4 million Americans over the age of 40, at a direct cost of over $140 billion dollars per year, producing a critical need to train the next generation of vision scientists to work in areas of translational vision science. Our goal is to train vision scientists who understand the need for translation of their discoveries in the laboratory to clinical treatment and rehabilitation strategies, armed with an understanding of the biology and pathophysiology of vision disorders that will facilitate development of therapies and potential cures to blinding and vision impairing diseases. As faculty with significant translational components to our work and with processes in place to aid in this training, we are well positioned to train these future translational vision scientists.
PROJECT_TERMS: Training Programs;vision science
PROJECT_TITLE: Training Program in Translational Vision Sciences

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Interactions between mesolimbic dopamine systems and hippocampus are tailored to support the active acquisition of salient information into long-term memory, a process that supports a variety of adaptive behaviors such as memory selectivity, generalization, and decision-making. Similarly, this circuit contributes to motivated behaviors that occur in the absence of explicit rewards which are relevant to substance abuse — such as craving and relapse. This proposal examines how mesolimbic-hippocampal interactions contribute to episodic memory in the context of active information seeking to build a framework to understand how mesolimbic signaling at multiple timescales interact to shape memory encoding and consolidation in the absence of explicit reward feedback

PROJECT_TITLE: The influence of mesolimbic-hippocampal interactions on episodic memory during active information seeking

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Symptomatic knee osteoarthritis is a prevalent and disabling condition that has few effective treatments that alter the natural history of the disease. Intra-articular inflammation manifesting as synovitis is an important phenotype and potential treatment target. This proposal seeks to better understand the role of synovitis in osteoarthritis pain, progression and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project 1 Narrative The Tabas R35 program will explore new, highly interrelated concepts related to four key areas in which critical gaps in atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease exist: inflammation resolution & efferocytosis (safe clearance of dead cells); pathophysiology of the minority of atherosclerotic lesions that are most clinically important; immunometabolism in macrophages (how macrophages process molecules to alter function); and aging- related clonal hematopoiesis (expansion of blood cells that is common in aging). The flexibility and forward- looking nature of this R35 program will allow expansion of these areas into human atheroma tissue studies, human genetics, and studies with genetically engineered human macrophages to complement the human genetic studies. Successful completion of this R35 program will address key gaps in our knowledge of how the most clinically dangerous atherosclerotic plaques develop; lead to the design of novel therapeutic strategies; and promote the training and mentoring of young scientists in this critical area of research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project is relevant to public health as it will elucidate key genetic mechanisms that contribute to the development of age-related macular degeneration (AMD), the most common cause of vision loss in the United States among people over the age of 55 years. The research will achieve this objective by optimizing and validating experimental systems for studying genetic risk factors of AMD that are currently poorly understood. The novel insights gained by completion of this study will immediately facilitate the discovery and interpretation of new disease-contributing mutations and enable the development of therapies to treat visual disorders that affect people of all ages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research project is relevant to public health as acquiring knowledge regarding genome editing of cardiac Ryanodine Receptor Type-2 is expected to lead to a better understanding of how cardiac gene therapy can treat ventricular arrhythmias and other cardiovascular conditions related to dysregulation of this critical calcium channel. Such knowledge may ultimately lead to new therapeutic approaches that focus on correcting the underlying causes of genetic cardiac disorders. Thus, this research is relevant to the NIH’s mission as it seeks to acquire knowledge that will aid in the treatment of human disease and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anxiety and related disorders remain prevalent and costly, and although effective treatments exist, many who suffer with these disorders cannot complete or do not benefit from treatment. Research initiated here seeks to more effectively target, with non-invasive brain stimulation, pervasive avoidance of day-to-day activities, a key disorder feature that keeps many from fully engaging in treatment or attaining symptom remission. Since major depression, substance misuse, and various other mental health disorders also involve pervasive avoidance as a key feature, proposed research could have implications far beyond the anxiety spectrum of disorders.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Sensory processing disorder (SPD) is a debilitating neurodevelopmental disorder that affects a majority of children with autism spectrum disorder and manifests as over responsivity or under responsivity to stimuli that can affect social and cognitive behaviors. SPD has genetic and environmental risk factors, and biological pathways including altered white matter integrity and reduced connectivity between thalamus and sensory cortices. The goal of this study is to examine how the maternal gut microbiota affects development of microglia and neural circuits implicated in somatosensory behaviors, and identify mechanisms and novel therapeutic targets to better treat SPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Melanoma:Metabolic Biomarkers of Response to Targeted Therapy Project Narrative Melanoma is currently treated with an inhibitor of a signaling protein that sends signals for the tumor cells to proliferate. While this method is initially effective in most patients, all patients eventually become resistant to this drug and have to be treated with other agents. The goal of this project is to develop an imaging method that detects the onset of resistance to this drug and indicates when treatment should be switched to an alternate drug. The study will also investigate if including a glutaminase inhibitor in the initial treatment regimen can increase or prolong effective therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Public health relevance Previous research finds state-level policies targeting alcohol use during pregnancy at best have had no impact on drinking during pregnancy or related outcomes and, at worst, contribute to public health harms. Research has not explored the more severe outcomes related to these policies nor has it comprehensively examined which general population alcohol policies might reduce harms from drinking during pregnancy. Understanding effects of these policies is crucial to our ability to adopt and implement policies that will lead to reductions in harm from alcohol use during pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Of the millions of American schoolchildren who suffer concussions each year, approximately one quarter experience persistent physical, emotional, and/or cognitive symptoms, which can affect their quality of life, academic performance, social behavior, and psychological well-being. This project will measure concussion symptoms, biological markers, and academic and social factors across the first year postconcussion to develop a model that enables early identification of and symptom management for children at higher risk for persistent postconcussive symptoms. Findings will provide novel insights into the longer-term effects of concussion on children's physical, psychological, and social well-being and support the development of personalized healthcare and school-based plans to reduce disparities in children's ability to return-to-learn and -play and improve postconcussion quality of life.

ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Electronic nicotine delivery systems (ENDS), including electronic-cigarettes and JUUL devices, have become increasingly popular among smoking and non-smoking pre-teens, teenagers and adults. Little, however, is known about the long-term cardiopulmonary effects of ENDS aerosols. We will use ENDS exposure systems we have developed, combined with biomarkers of toxicity and physiological changes found in dual-users (cigarette plus ENDS), to predict early signs of cardiopulmonary toxicity induced by sole exposures to ENDS aerosols.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kaposi’s sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) is a major cause of AIDS-associated malignancies and thus represents a significant public health burden. The proposed work will identify specific genes and DNA elements that mediate the cancerous reprogramming that occurs in KSHV-associated B cell lymphomas. Results will be impactful, because they will be used to develop therapeutic strategies for this presently incurable cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Macromolecules play key roles in nearly all biological processes, and thus understanding their structure and function is critical to human health. Determining structures of macromolecules would be highly beneficial for elucidating mechanisms of human disease and designing countermeasures. Despite recent advances, many health-relevant macromolecules remain difficult to study. We propose to use DNA nanotechnology to gain programmable spatial control over these targets to their enable structure determination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Pulmonary macrophages and fibroblasts are critically involved in lung homeostasis as well as inflammatory and fibrotic diseases. In this proposal, the principal investigator seeks to continue a highly productive and innovative investigative program designed to provide new insights into the molecular regulation of these two cell types in health and disease. These insights will provide a foundation for new therapeutic strategies widely applicable to a variety of lung diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Friedreich's ataxia (FRDA) is a progressive neurodegenerative disease caused by reduced expression of the mitochondrial protein Frataxin (FXN). The G130V pathogenic point mutation inhibits production of mature FXN and gives rise to an atypical FRDA phenotype in patients. Realization of this project will define molecular mechanisms linking frataxin processing with clinical presentation of the disease and will be important for FRDA patients with point mutations as well as GAA expansions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: This project seeks to uncover the molecular mechanisms that control functional plasticity of gap junctions that form electrical synapses in neurons. Electrical synapses play important roles in development, sensory adaptation, learning and memory, and motor control, and in pathological states can contribute to neurological disorders and ischemic injuries. Identification of mechanisms that control their plasticity will allow the development of targeted therapies for problematic neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE UT Southwestern proposes to maintain a Network Lead Academic Participating Site (LAPS) for the NCI National Clinical Trials Network (NCTN). As an NCTN Network LAPS, UT Southwestern will provide scientific leadership by helping to develop and conduct clinical trials in association with adult Network Groups and will contribute substantial accrual to clinical trials conducted across the entire NCTN. Key strengths of our site relevant to this effort include a history of leadership in multiple cooperative groups and excellent accrual to cooperative group trials (including ethnic and racial minorities), innovative basic research and drug discovery (which can be translated to clinic trials), an Advanced Imaging Research Center, and our unique position as the only NCI designated Comprehensive Cancer Center and academic medical center in the fourth largest metropolitan area in the country.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Rates of Alzheimer’s Disease and its Related Dementias (ADRD) are approximately 3 times higher in Indigenous populations who already shoulder a range of health inequities including a disproportionate share of age-related diseases. Our research uses community-based, qualitative research to understand how culture and community context influence the impacts of ADRD in diverse American Indian and First Nations communities. By documenting the lived experience of ADRD in Indigenous populations this research will contribute to the knowledge base necessary to create culturally appropriate ADRD health diagnostics, caregiving practices, health promotion and education tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is a leading cause of blindness worldwide; however, there is a lack of treatment for dry AMD and to halt its progression to the late, blinding forms because the underlying causes of AMD development and progression are unclear. This study utilizes a novel, comprehensive methodology called “metabolomics” (i.e. the study of small molecules) to investigate the mechanisms of AMD and to serve as the basis for future biomarkers of this condition and its progression in easily accessible biofluids (blood and urine). Our work has the potential to: (i) give unique insights into the causes of AMD; (ii) significantly impact AMD diagnosis and risk assessment; and (iii) accelerate the development of novel strategies for earlier treatment and prevention of this blinding condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance / Narrative: Glaucoma is leading cause of irreversible vision loss, affecting an estimated 76 million people worldwide. This project aims to fill knowledge gaps concerning the role of an emerging but still poorly understood protein, LTBP2, in eye structure and pressure regulation in glaucoma. Results of these studies will serve as a foundation for the development of innovative new glaucoma treatment strategies, to help preserve vision in glaucoma patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This training program will enhance the research career trajectories of a community of postdoctoral and junior faculty including women and those from groups historically underrepresented in the biomedical and behavioral sciences through a coordinated set of programs focused on mentorship, skills development, and research experiences. The underrepresentation of women and persons excluded due to ethnicity and race (PEERs) has many causes; this program addresses the attrition of these groups from neuroscience research at senior postdoctoral and junior faculty levels. Critical aspects of the program include building a community of lifelong mentors and peers; practical skills including incorporating cutting edge methods, effective communication, networking, and management; and individualized support to retain outstanding scientists in neuroscience and to accelerate the pace of meaningful discoveries and cures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Statement: This project is relevant to public health in focusing on developing and evaluating predictive algorithms for glaucoma progression, which are necessary to tailor treatment approaches to individual glaucoma patients' needs and achieve optimal treatment outcomes to prevent blindness. The powerful artificial intelligence techniques we will develop and use for large-scale data from electronic health records can be extended to include a wide variety of data sources and shared with the research and clinical community to answer ophthalmic questions in many domains. In supporting personalized medicine for glaucoma patients to improve ophthalmic outcomes, the proposed research is relevant to the NEI's mission to protect and prolong vision.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Depression is the second leading cause of disability worldwide, due partly to the fact that existing antidepressants are not effective for all patients and it is often challenging to match individual patients to the treatments that are most likely to help them. This project will test a new strategy for using fMRI brain scans to predict antidepressant response and assist clinicians in choosing which of two antidepressant treatments— transcranial magnetic stimulation targeting one of two depression-related brain areas—is most likely to benefit an individual patient.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the proposed project, we will develop and apply population genetic tools to detect and disentangle signals of population structure and adaptation in contemporary and ancient genomic datasets. Identifying monogenic or polygenic adaptive genetic variation is a key step towards understanding the genetic mechanisms affecting disease prevalence in different population groups and unraveling the genetic architecture underlying complex genetic diseases. The tools will use explicit models of the underlying population genetic processes to detect the genomic patterns characteristic to complex migration histories and adaptive genetic variation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children with pediatric chronic non-infectious uveitis (NIU) are treated with methotrexate as the first line immune- suppressant despite failure rates of as high as 50%. This research will identify clinical, imaging and biologic risk factors that predict a child’s responsiveness to methotrexate. It is anticipated that results from this study will help us select the most optimal initial treatment for children with NIU that will control inflammation quickly, minimize ocular damage, and improve childhood vision.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current approaches to treat glioblastoma, an aggressive brain cancer, have been unsuccessful due to its ability to adapt and evolve. This is possible because the environment within the tumor presents signals that help glioblastoma cells evade therapies and continue to grow. Understanding how these signals in the tumor environment change due to treatments may help researchers identify new drugs and approaches that can target both the tumor environment and the tumor cells that benefit from it.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Larger structural variants (SVs) underlie a variety of genetic diseases, however accurately detecting SVs with widely used short read sequencing technologies remains challenging. As a result, there is a substantial gap between our understanding of the role of single-nucleotide DNA changes and SVs. This project will develop more accurate approaches for identifying true SVs to expand our knowledge of human genetic variation and to improve our understanding and diagnosis of genetic disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because emotion dysregulation contributes to the development of most mental health disorders and the investigation of emotion regulation is a public health priority. Autism spectrum disorder impacts as many as 1 in 44 children in the USA -- the majority of which have a co-occurring mental health disorder—and this study will contribute critical knowledge that can be used to reduce mental health disorders in children on the autism spectrum. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to NIH’s stated priorities to understand emotional development among children on the autism spectrum.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Photoinduced cleavage of chemical bonds is an efficient and noninvasive way for selective release and delivery of biochemically relevant compounds in vivo towards chemotherapeutic and diagnostic applications. Near- infrared (NIR) light is benign and penetrates deeper into tissues, which presents an efficient way to realize these goals. Towards this goal the proposed research will establish a new design of platinum-based framework toward NIR-uncaging of bioactive molecules.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Despite advances in treating many cancers, metastatic skin cutaneous melanomas that harbor a wild-type BRAF gene (“wild-type BRAF melanomas) remain very difficult to treat. Here we test the hypothesis that ERBB4 gain-of-function mutant proteins interact with the EGF receptor or HER2/Neu receptor to stimulate the PI3K pathway, which cooperates with the mutations in the RAS or NF1 genes to drive the proliferation of wild-type BRAF melanomas. Thus, we predict that the successful completion of the proposed research will lead to sorely needed improvements in treating a very aggressive cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In men with prostate cancer undergoing hormonal treatment (known as “ADT”), loss of muscle mass and function—“sarcopenia”— is one of the most prevalent and debilitating symptoms with a profound negative effect on quality of life, and without any known effective treatment. To set the foundation for the development of these much-needed treatments in the future, we are proposing a clinical trial where men with prostate cancer starting ADT will be followed for one year with the goals of establishing how best to measure and predict sarcopenia, as well as delineating skeletal muscle mechanisms leading to this complication, including the role of the mitochondria. The data generated will provide essential information on tools to measure sarcopenia that are clinically meaningful to patients, shed light on new biological targets for this condition, and identify markers of sarcopenia that can lead to early diagnosis and guide the selection of patients and outcomes for future clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Drug resistant cancer is virtually incurable, yet how cancer cells acquire resistance remains unknown. This is, in part, because the events that lead to resistance occur at low frequencies and at unpredictable times making it difficult to observe with conventional approaches. Here I propose the use of new technologies that enable continued monitoring of individual cells to pave the way towards treatment strategies that minimize the risk of acquired resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Platinum-based chemotherapy is the preferred first-line therapy for advanced bladder cancer; however, resistance is common and lethal. We hypothesize that interactions among tumor and immune cell states drive platinum chemotherapy resistance and progression in bladder cancer. We will use hypothesis-driven mechanistic, computational, and patient-centered strategies to dissect how cell states and interactions promote disease progression in bladder cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative As a consequence of Electronic Health Record (EHR) adoption there has been rapid and widespread growth in the use of documentation assistants such speech recognition and medical scribes to untether providers from the EHR by facilitating documentation, data gathering and data retrieval for providers. With the COVID-19 pandemic and the rapid adoption of telemedicine, these issues have been magnified spurring the evolution of 2 new forms of documentation assistance, virtual scribes and digital scribes, yet little data exists on their impact and efficacy and no data directly compares and contrasts all 4 of these forms of documentation assistance to aid health systems in selection and monitoring of these solutions. The goal of this proposal is to use a comprehensive, mixed-methods approach, including high-fidelity simulation, to establish a success matrix and means of monitoring to aid organizations in the selection, and impact evaluation of these 4 modalities of documentation assistance across ambulatory care environments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Leveraging decades of NCI investments in clinical trials, data infrastructure, and cancer screening research, the I-SCREEN (Improving Strategies for Cancer Reduction through Early-detection and ENgagement) CSRN ACCESS Hub consists of an NCI-designated Cancer Center, two integrated care delivery systems, one federally qualified health system, and one rural critical access hospital system. I-SCREEN will recruit some of the most under-represented populations in clinical trials, including Hispanics, Native Hawaiian/Pacific Islanders, Asian subgroups, and rural populations. Our goal is to reduce cancer-related mortality by rapidly investigating emerging, novel screening technologies in diverse study cohorts to ensure that efficacious new technologies have broad reach to decrease, and not widen, cancer-related health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic Ankle Instability is a common debilitating condition that negatively affects patient function and quality of life. Chronic ankle instability is often thought of as a single pathology across patients, however, several subgroups exist, and their underlying features are not well understood. Therefore, we seek to understand the underlying functional and neurophysiological characteristics of different chronic ankle instability sub-groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the successful development of multiple immunotherapeutic modalities, tumor immune exclusion mechanisms prevent many patients from reaping their benefits. Recent models suggest that tumors actively enforce a mechanical barrier at the tumor-stroma periphery to exclude antitumor immune infiltration and to prevent subsequent immune-mediated killing. This proposal seeks to systematically dissect the components of the tumor-immune mechanical barrier through approaches including in vivo preclinical mouse models, genetic screening, and multi-omics spatial analysis of patient specimens, which will reveal unanticipated immune suppressive mechanisms utilized by cancer and thereby shed new light on novel anticancer treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Identifying genomic mutations controlling the susceptibility to developing blood clots (thrombosis) is important for managing this disease. We have identified a mutation in the Arl6ip5 gene that has a major impact on reducing thrombosis in a mouse model of lethal thrombosis. The goal of this project is to use mouse genetics, assays assessing blood coagulation and platelet function, and molecular genomics techniques to determine the mechanisms by which Arl6ip5 deficiency reduces thrombosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal focuses on the role of p53-mediated Interleukin 17 Receptor B (IL17RB) repression in tumor suppression and inflammation inhibition. IL17RB, a cytokine receptor involved in inflammation, has been found to be overexpressed in various cancers through the activation of multiple cancer-prone signaling pathways. p53, one of the major cellular barriers against cancer, has been demonstrated to regulate innate and adaptive immune responses. Understanding the mechanisms of how IL17RB links p53’s crosstalk with other signaling pathways and how p53 attenuates oncogenic effects of chronic inflammation through repressing IL17RB will lead to the development of novel anti-cancer strategies and inflammation inhibitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Deep learning diagnostic accuracy for dermoscopic images can exceed that of dermatologists, however it fails to provide sufficient accuracy to serve as a reliable screening tool for in-person and virtual consultations and automatic triage of lesions. To improve diagnostic accuracy for skin lesion images, we propose an enhanced, publicly accessible database of critical skin lesion structures through expert annotation and curation of thousands of images, enabling a new paradigm for the automatic analysis of cancer images and providing a transparent foundation for cancer image processing. This three-year project will provide educational opportunities for undergraduate students in multiple fields of study at Missouri University of Science and Technology and pre-college STEM outreach educational initiatives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Irreversible vision loss is one of the top ten disabilities worldwide and is responsible for reduced quality of life and a substantial burden on national healthcare systems. Experiments in this study are designed to test the hypothesis that PNU-282987-induced neurogenesis of retinal neurons in adult mice occurs through activation of Müller glia. The results from this study could have serious implications for reversing vision loss due to traumatic injuries, degenerative retinal disease or age-related issues.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative Acinetobacter baumannii is responsible for a wide variety of infections in humans, including those of the lung, skin and soft tissue, bloodstream, and urinary tract. A. baumanii infections have become increasingly common and pose a significant health threat to the VA population. In addition, A. baumannii has been a leading cause of infections in injured military personnel. The inability to treat A. baumannii infections with currently available antibiotics has reached a critical stage and isolates resistant to all available antibiotics have become a reality and are increasing in frequency. New approaches to treat these infections are critically needed. To combat A. baumannii, we have developed a novel vaccine and identified new small molecule antibiotics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Tumor evolution is often the cause of outstanding clinical challenges, such as acquired drug resistance and metastasis. Recent work has demonstrated that oncogene amplification on extrachromosomal DNA (ecDNA) is a major driver of tumor evolution but remains difficult to study due to its elusive evolutionary dynamics and substantial variability. This project proposes the development of innovative new computational tools that will illuminate ecDNA heterogeneity and evolution at unparalleled resolution, which will in turn be used to nominate new therapeutic strategies that target ecDNA-mediated tumor evolution.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this proposal is to understand how different aspects of the robot-assisted training of the hand of chronic stroke survivors can affect their muscle control. First, we will apply two widely-used robot types (end- effector and exoskeleton) to hand movements of stroke survivors, and compare the changes in their muscle use during and after the training with these two devices. We will then examine how two different types of movement feedback (movement amplification or reduction) affect the way stroke survivors control their hand muscles. Finally, we will study if the dynamic condition of the training, i.e., force production or movement, can affect the way they control their hand muscles. The outcome of this study will help us design optimal robotic trainings for the hand of individual stroke survivors, targeting specific problems in their muscle use, which are the very underlying cause of their hand functional impairment. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Measures of purifying selection from large reference populations are critical tools for prioritizing variants in diagnostic settings and identifying disease-associated genes. In this project, we will take advantage of access to large and ancestrally diverse genomic datasets, advances in protein structure predicting algorithms, and functional annotations from proteomics to refine the signals of purifying selection in the human genome and improve our measures of this selective constraint.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to build on recent advances in the novel translation of a well-established animal model of addiction by delineating the neurobehavioral signatures of human sign- and goal-tracking. The long-term goal of this line of work is to identify early those who are at the highest risk for addiction. Ultimately, this information could be used by researchers and clinicians to limit the transition to addiction, reduce relapse rates, and improve human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: This research study proposes to quantify the relationship between daily step counts and body composition/cardiometabolic disease risk factors in young, middle-aged, and older adults who are overweight/obese, and to then employ that relationship in prescribing step counts to achieve predictable changes in body weight and composition, and cardiometabolic risk status. This research project is highly relevant to public health: the numbers of overweight and obese adults continue to rise in all age groups, and the epidemic prevalence of excess body fatness and its comorbidities imposes an increasingly serious burden on health care costs and quality of life. Results from this research study may provide a new and powerful tool for prescribing physical activity for weight/cardiometabolic disease management in people adults of all ages, and have significant clinical and public health applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vesicular stomatitis virus (VSV) is a promising oncolytic virus (OV) against pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC), which makes up to 95% of pancreatic cancers, and will soon be the second leading cause of cancer- related deaths in the United States. The proposed studies are based on our recently published work where we generated novel PDAC-targeted oncolytic VSV variants that can better infect and kill PDAC cells without harming non-malignant cells. The proposed study will investigate the mechanism of the improved oncoselectivity and will examine these viruses alone or in combination with FDA-approved drug Ruxolitinib and/or anti-PD-1 antibody using clinically-relevant immunocompetent orthotopic mouse models of PDAC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The psychological symptom cluster is a common and significant problem that impacts women receiving breast cancer treatment and is associated with several negative outcomes, including reduced functional status and quality of life. Unfortunately, the social, environmental, and molecular mechanism(s) that drive the development and persistence of this cluster are unknown which limits the development of effective prevention strategies and targeted interventions. This project will examine the role of multiple social determinants of health and epigenomic factors in the development and severity of a psychological symptom cluster in women receiving breast cancer treatment which will provide new knowledge to guide clinical assessment and the development of targeted interventions to mitigate the severity of this cluster.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The NIH Stroke Net is a research network infrastructure to efficiently conduct clinical trials to identify intervention for: (1) acute treatment of stroke; (2) prevention of stroke recurrence; and (3) recovery and rehabilitation after stroke. The National Data Management Center (NDMC) of the NIH Stroke Net offers economies of scale through its centralized clinical management system to conduct multiple stroke clinical trials simultaneously and efficiently. This is expected to have an impact on the public health by potentially reducing stroke occurrences and the burden of stroke to the individuals as well as to the society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Melanoma recurrence from the early-stage primary tumor accounts for most melanoma mortality but is often undetected until the disease has spread to lymph nodes or distant organs. While the recent approval of immunotherapy for managing patients with early-stage melanomas provides a potential opportunity to improve patient outcomes, it requires an accurate prognostic prediction tool to identify patients for whom the risk of melanoma recurrence and metastasis would justify the potentially significant adverse events of systemic immunotherapy. We propose to address this critical public health need by leveraging recent advances in multiplexed tissue imaging, spatial transcriptomics, and artificial intelligence to characterize the early-stage melanoma microenvironment, understand mechanisms underlying its recurrence, and build an explainable machine-learning-based forecasting platform that can be deployed in clinics to aid precision medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Following rapid growth early in development, dendritic arbors achieve apparent stability in size across adolescence but continue to undergo refinements that ultimately lead to dendrite- mediated signal selectivity and mature cortical circuits. This developmental epoch is a period of vulnerability for the onset of multiple neuropsychiatric diseases, yet the underlying mechanisms governing this crucial refinement remain incompletely understood. This project seeks to identify the role of OMGp in adolescent dendritic development, specifically integrating studies spanning anatomical and functional characterization, to better link dendrites to circuits to physiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Coronary revascularization (CR) is a common heart procedure used to treat patients with severe coronary artery disease. This research project aims to combine information about the heart muscle and arteries before the CR to improve treatment decisions. It not only helps doctors make better choices about how to perform the procedure but also introduces translational cardiology to the students at Michigan Tech, which will connect the university's engineering research with clinical practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  A significant proportion of individuals who undergo genetic testing receive an inconclusive diagnosis and a subset of which could be attributed to the technical limitations of short-read sequencing. We propose to address the shortcomings of the current technologies by developing a long-read sequencing assay to resolve inconclusive diagnoses and reduce the uncertainty in genetic test results. Our studies will provide new insights on the additional diagnostic yield from resolving prior inconclusive results and demonstrate the clinical utility of long-read sequencing as a comprehensive assay for rare Mendelian disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Improving screening and early detection is crucial for reducing the growing burden of cancer in our society. Such efforts have the potential to reduce cancer disparities and inequities if research is designed and conducted with equity and accessibility in mind. For the Cancer Screening Research Network, the Siteman Cancer Center Catchment Hub is focused on building equity in cancer screening through research and engaging diverse community members across Missouri and Illinois in this effort. Our multi-disciplinary team and region-wide partners are committed to reducing the burden of cancer for all.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Congenital heart disease (CHD) is a condition that affects a significant number of newborns each year, with approximately 40,000 cases in the USA and 1.35 million globally. Valve and conduit replacements are required for repairing or replacing right ventricle outflow tract (RVOT) defects associated with CHD. This is necessary for defects such as absent pulmonary valve, aortic stenosis (Konno procedure, Ross procedure), double outlet right ventricle (Rastelli operation), extracardiac conduit, and pulmonary valve replacement (Tetralogy of Fallot). Unfortunately, the current replacement device materials are suboptimal and have a high failure rate, requiring reoperations in pediatric and adult patients. This research proposal aims to commercialize a breakthrough TxGuardTM pulmonary-valved graft (PVG) device that is designed to resist early degeneration and allow for regeneration with host cells, ensuring that the device grows with the pediatric patient. The proposed Phase IIB SBIR grant will help to de-risk several critical aspects of the research and complete pre-clinical test data required for FDA humanitarian device exemption (HDE) submission. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it seeks to improve our fundamental knowledge about the disease-causing transporter Sialin and develop a new strategy to rescue dysfunctional pathogenic Sialin mutations. The results will have the potential for future pharmaceutical development to treat related human diseases, such as free sialic acid storage disorder, heart failure, and even Parkinson’s. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to NIH’s mission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Skeletal muscle wasting during cancer cachexia has been long deemed to be a mere reflection of overall body degradation. Challenging this assumption, we generated a mouse model that phenocopied cancer cachexia from within the skeletal muscle by impairing ribosome biogenesis, the synthesis of new ribosomes, specifically in skeletal muscle. This proposal seeks to determine the etiology of cancer cachexia by interrogating this intrinsic mechanism in skeletal muscle that leads to muscle wasting and cachectic phenotype.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stroke remains a leading cause of death and disability in the US, with the situation particular severe in southeastern states like North Carolina and Virginia. Stroke Net’s goal is to maximize efficiencies for developing, promoting, and conducting high-quality, multi-site clinical trials focused on promising interventions for stroke prevention, treatment, and recovery. The ENVISION Regional Coordinating Center brings two major academic institutions, Duke and UNC, along with over a dozen suburban and rural regional hospitals in eastern North Carolina and southern Virginia to form a large-scale Regional Coordinating Center to enroll and retain a diverse stroke population in stroke clinical trials and to contribute to the overall success of StrokeNet.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Narrative  The goal is to develop an integrated deep learning model to optimize 5'UTR, codon usage, and 3'UTR at same time that enables users to design the optimal mRNA sequence to enhance protein expression level, thus to improve the efficacy of mRNA medicines. mRNA based therapies hold great promise for the treatment of various types of diseases, but this therapeutic approach suffers from multiple challenges including the short half- life of exogenously administered mRNA and subsequent protein production. Our proposed studies will address the challenges in design of mRNA sequence to enhance mRNA stability and translation efficiency, and thus provide important information for the development and optimization of mRNA vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The current application will test the hypothesis that dysregulated Platelet Activating Factor (PTAF) and free fatty-acid (FFA) metabolism, via a novel epigenetic crosstalk featuring aberrant HNF4A transcription factor activation, is involved in growth dysregulation and early neoplastic evolution in cardia columnar cells at the human gastroesophageal junction (GEJ-cardia). This hypothesis will be tested by blocking the PTAF and FFA- HNF4A pathways, with lipidomic profiling in a human organoid model system and in human GEJ-cardia samples.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The development of the proposed virtual reality (VR) parent training tool maximizes the effect of critically needed parent training for parents of children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) who engage in severe destructive behavior. The VR training tool addresses access barriers to training by allowing parents to practice intervention implementation in the comfort of their own home at times convenient for their schedule and quality barriers by more closely resembling scenarios parents encounter with their own child than contrived practice opportunities. The proposed customizable VR technology has the potential to (a) be highly impactful for parents by teaching sustainable strategies for managing destructive behavior at home, (b) be efficient and informative for clinicians to collect data to support parents, and (c) mitigate the reoccurrence of destructive behavior by allowing parents to practice implementing intervention during treatment challenges.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to leverage our cumulative expertise in cancer screening and the resources of the University of North Carolina, UNC Lineberger, UNC Health, and Federally Qualified Health Centers (FQHCs) to create an ACCESS Hub in the new NCI Cancer Screening Research Network (CSRN). Our catchment area serves the entire state of North Carolina, offering a patient population that spans urban and rural locations, varied socioeconomic levels, and racial and ethnic diversity similar to the southeastern US population as a whole. In addition to capacity building and participation in the initial pilot feasibility study of multi-cancer early detection screening (Vanguard), we also propose exploratory qualitative research into perspectives of diverse communities regarding MCD screening that will inform future studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A mechanistic understanding of oligodendrocyte development and myelin repair after injury will shed light on cellular vulnerability to white matter injury. In this proposal, we will define new genes and pathways that drive stage-specific oligodendrocyte lineage development and myelin repair via Wnt signaling, and pinpoint potential targetable pathways for therapies that can stimulate remyelination in white matter disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Biomolecular condensates are membrane-less intracellular assemblies that play fundamental roles in cellular organization, physiology, and pathology. The functions of biomolecular condensates are closely linked to their molecular content. By developing a novel genomics platform for spatially resolved profiling of molecular contents within the condensates, we will provide novel insights into human health and disease through the lens of biomolecular condensates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stroke is the second leading cause of death and a leading cause of major disability globally, and is becoming more frequent with the aging population. NIH Stroke Net is a network of clinical sites and experts across the country working together to develop and complete multi-site clinical trials, the final step in proving that new potential treatments will work, and to train the next generation of clinical researchers. The National Coordinating Center leads and manages this network to test new ways to treat, prevent, and aid in recovery and rehabilitation from stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (from parent grant) Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDA) can be classified into quasi-mesenchymal (QM) and classical subtypes, but the genetic or epigenetic mechanisms driving subtype determination in PDA remain poorly understood. Our preliminary data suggests that loss of the histone deacetylase and PDA tumor suppressor gene Sirtuin 6 (SIRT6) may act an epigenetic switch that drives the more aggressive QM phenotype, while at the same time rendering PDA cells highly dependent on a specific targetable pathway. This proposal aims to elucidate mechanisms of SIRT6 downregulation in QM PDA, explore SIRT6 as a critical regulator of PDA subtype determination, and leverage this knowledge for the preclinical development of novel targeted therapies in this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative IL-1α exhibits dual functionality, acting as a traditional cytokine but also controlling a number of diverse cellular functions. We will interrogate the mechanism by which IL-1α is released from dying cells and its modulation of innate immune responses through the regulation of efferocytosis and mitophagy. We will further determine if IL-1α-mediated stromal cell crosstalk and interference with cellular eat-me signals modulates inflammation and pathology induced by a sterile inflammatory insult.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hemophilia A is a bleeding disorder resulting from factor VIII (FVIII) deficiency. The development of inhibitory antibodies against FVIII is not only a severe and important complication of protein replacement therapy, but also a major concern in gene therapy of hemophilia A. In this project, we will develop a novel approach by targeting the synthesis of FVIII to blood platelets to provide therapeutic protein and induce immune tolerance in hemophilia A even in the presence of inhibitory antibodies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative. Patients with metastatic lung cancer are living longer (i.e., metavivors), but they experience high psychological distress (i.e., depressive symptoms, anxiety, illness non-acceptance), persistent symptom burden (i.e., fatigue, dyspnea, pain), and poor overall quality of life. Given that existing psychosocial intervention paradigms are not designed to help metavivors navigate the emotional turbulence of living while dying, we created LiveWell, an 8- session adapted Dialectical Behavioral Therapy Skills Training protocol that teaches patients transdiagnostic, easy-to-use skills (e.g., mindfulness, distress tolerance, emotion regulation, interpersonal effectiveness) to enable them live as well as possible, with metastatic lung cancer. The proposed research enhances the health and quality of life of the growing number of lung cancer metavivors by addressing their unmet emotional needs and offers a promising psychosocial intervention paradigm for other groups of metavivors and patients living with chronic illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of the Vanguard phase of the Cancer Screening Research Network (CSRN) is to design and conduct a randomized controlled feasibility trial of two promising MCD tests. The CSRN Communication and Coordinating Center (CCC), in conjunction with the CSRN Statistics and Data Management Center (SDMC) and the NCI, will lead and support this critical national effort with exceptional scientific and clinical expertise, organizational and administrative infrastructure, effective communication, well-tuned recruitment and retention leadership and resources, and a comprehensive quality assurance program. The design of the Vanguard and future trials will be informed and extended by well-calibrated microsimulation modelling of cancer screening in at risk populations.

PHR: Project Narrative Malaria is a major impediment to the economic development in Myanmar, a country in the Greater Mekong Subregion of Southeast Asia, which has recently opened up during the democratization process. In this research training application, we propose to train a cadre of junior scientists from Myanmar to address important problems in malaria research, control, and elimination. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Anaplastic Large Cell Lymphoma (ALCL) is a T cell lymphoma frequently driven by chromosomal rearrangements involving the Anaplastic Lymphoma Kinase (ALK) gene. ALK inhibitors show potent activity in chemotherapy refractory ALCL, but resistance develops and lymphoma is never eradicated. We identified several molecular mechanisms that prevent eradication and propose to develop novel therapeutic strategies to overcome resistance and cure ALCL in most patients. ALK+ ALCL could become the first T cell lymphoma to be cured without chemotherapy by targeted therapy.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed investigation will be the first comprehensive study to evaluate a progressive and adaptive assist-as-needed intensive exoskeleton robotic (ER) intervention (30 hours of training) in the acute phase post stroke and its effect on functional recovery, neuromuscular adaptations, and neuroplasticity. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Latinos living in the 50 United States (US) have about 1.5 times the risk of Alzheimer’s disease as non-Latino whites with Puerto Ricans representing the Latino background with the highest prevalence of mild cognitive impairment and cardiovascular disease risk factors, both long associated with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) risk. The overall research and training goals of this K01 center around investigating protective factors to promote healthy cognitive and brain aging in middle-aged and older Latinos (ages 45+) and expand work currently being conducted in the continental US to the US territory of Puerto Rico. Findings may inform the development of culturally-targeted interventions to support healthy cognitive and brain aging in Latinos, the largest racial/ethnic minority group in the US, with a particular focus on Puerto Ricans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Atrial fibrillation (AF) is the most common heart rhythm disorder and is a major cause of stroke. The incidence of AF increases with age, making it an ‘epidemic’ in an aging population. Unfortunately, current treatments for AF – especially chronic or persistent AF - have low efficacy. We propose to study the role of three major molecular mechanisms – called autonomic nervous system remodeling, NLRP3 induced fibrosis and derailed proteostasis – in the genesis of persistent AF. The proposed approach will use novel biological agents (genes) to target these mechanisms. These genes, if successful in preventing persistent AF, will have immense therapeutic potential in the management of patients with this arrhythmia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM), a major cause of heart failure, enlarges the chambers and reduces the function of the heart. Damaging DNA variants are an important cause of DCM that are identified in 20-40% of patients, but the cause(s) of DCM in many patients remains unexplained. We propose to use new molecular technologies to study DNA sequences and single cells of unexplained DCM patient heart tissue hoping to identify new causes or contributors to DCM that will lead to improved diagnosis and treatments for these patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: The blood-brain barrier is a specialized feature of brain capillaries that protects brain tissue from harmful substances that may be present in blood. Dysfunction of this barrier contributes to many brain pathologies; therefore, the development of minimally-invasive approaches capable of modulating genes in the blood-brain barrier would represent a powerful technology. To this end, in this proposal, we will develop a therapeutic approach that uses MR image-guidance and focused ultrasound energy to deliver gene-therapy agents that modulate the genome of the blood-brain barrier with high spatial precision.

PHR: Project Narrative: Persistent smell loss after viral infections is common, especially in light of the COVID-19 pandemic, with significant impacts on quality of life. This research will study the role of the innate immune system and how local inflammation might cause hinder olfactory cell regeneration and cause persistent smell loss. A better understanding of these mechanisms has the potential to guide development of novel therapies to treat post- viral smell loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO MED SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Huntington’s disease (HD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disease which manifests between 35-45 years of age caused by a mutation consisting of an expansion of a CAG repeat in the huntingtin gene. The length of the CAG expansion correlates with age of onset, however, individuals with equal repeat length develop symptoms decades later than expected, suggesting that other factors in addition to the gene expansion can modify the age of disease onset. Our proposed work will address this question and is of direct significance to the development of new drugs to delay HD age of onset and progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a growing need to evaluate orthopedic metallic implants in patients, including hip replacements and spinal fixations. While magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is commonly used, the presence of metal causes substantial distortion in the images, preventing our ability to diagnose complications close to the implants. This project will develop improved MRI technology to take pictures of the soft tissues within a few millimeters of the implants, which doctors cannot see with any current technology, and where most complications occur.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  With nearly 17 million cancer survivors living in the United States and 1.7 million new cancer diagnoses each year, effective delivery of supportive care to reduce symptom burden and promote quality of life in cancer patients is critical. There is strong evidence demonstrating the benefits of supportive care at all phases of cancer care, but unfortunately, many barriers exist to integration into routine cancer care, leaving many patients without adequate support for common physical and psychological symptoms. This project will develop and pilot test a novel tool within the electronic health record system to facilitate systematic symptom assessment and the tailored delivery of supportive care in a real-world multidisciplinary oncology setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Older adults, a wealthy segment of the population, are known to exhibit compromised financial decision making especially in the context of age-related diseases such as Alzheimer's Disease. As the landscape of financial decision making has changed dramatically with rapid technological advances, there is a growing gap between the skills necessary for everyday financial decision making and the way it in which it is assessed clinically. Given the precipitous, ongoing and projected increase in the number of older adults and their use of technology, it is imperative to develop financial decision making measures that approximate real world functioning in the current technological culture that can inform clinical determination of financial decision making abilities, and shape public policies aimed at minimizing financial losses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a chronic, multi-system disease in which the immune system damages the body's own organs and tissues. This project aims to uncover the mechanisms whereby human genetic variants conferring increased lupus risk impact B cell function and the production of pathogenic antibodies against self (termed autoantibodies). The long-term goal of these studies is to guide the development of new targeted therapies for the treatment of SLE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer’s disease is a public health crisis in the US and a growing health disparity, with African Americans at disproportionate risk for the disease compared to non-Hispanic Whites. This project proposes to investigate earlier-life individual- and community-level stress exposures—adverse life circumstances and trauma (i.e., extreme poverty, residential instability, crime, police and community violence, incarceration, racial discrimination), mental disorders and their symptoms, and poor sleep (e.g., abnormal duration, fragmentation)—as determinants of known midlife risk factors for poor cognitive outcomes in later life in two predominantly African American cohorts followed longitudinally for 35 years. Results will help clarify links of stress exposures with estimated risk at midlife for later-life dementia, identify vulnerable subgroups for targeted prevention of Alzheimer’s disease and related disorders, elucidate the role of social inequities in determining racial disparities in dementia, and establish a midlife cognitive baseline for future longitudinal follow-up of this valuable cohort.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Surveillance is a cornerstone of public health, but no data system currently exists to monitor Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD). The ADRD surveillance system we propose to create will provide a vital resource to track progress towards the U.S. National Plan to Address Alzheimer's Disease goals, such as preventing ADRD and reducing ADRD diagnosis and management disparities. When completed, the new surveillance system will provide a public resource that the research community, advocacy groups, government, and non-governmental organizations can use in the fight against ADRD.

PHR: Narrative Neuromodulation by acetylcholine (ACh) plays a major role in regulating striatal circuits and downstream resulting behaviors. PHR: Project Narrative These studies will define the degree to which humans generate antibody responses that are reactive to different enteroviruses, allowing prioritization of vaccine efforts to those viruses with poorer natural response. Human monoclonal antibodies that we isolate will help determine which structural parts of these viruses generate the most broadly reactive antibodies, allowing vaccine design to focus on authentically replicating these structures. Finally, the monoclonal antibodies themselves have potential for use in prevention or treatment of enterovirus infections causing disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative:  Currently, a substantial effort is focused on understanding the mechanisms regulating the induction of thermogenic beige adipocytes as a potential therapeutic target for increasing energy expenditure to reduce and/or prevent obesity and insulin resistance. Although humans have the capacity to induce thermogenic adipocytes, only 50% of adolescents and 10% of adults display cold inducible beige/brown adipocytes. In contrast, all humans are born with brown adipose tissue that begins to decline during the first decade of life and continues to decline throughout the normal lifespan. Similarly, brown adipose depots in mice decline both in mass and function starting at approximately 8-12 months of age and continue to decline throughout their remaining life span. Our preliminary data indicate that the decline brown adipose tissue mass and function results the activation of a Nlrp1 pyroptosis cell death pathway that is the focus of this new grant proposal.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Secondary to the therapies that cured childhood cancer survivors, most will develop a chronic disease early in life. For example, survivors treated with abdominal or pelvic radiation are at significantly elevated risk of colorectal cancer (CRC) at a young age. The proposed study aims to reduce the morbidity and mortality faced by these survivors by testing a remote intervention aimed at promoting early CRC screening and detection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The objective of this proposal is to understand how sleep disturbances affect recovery in youth presenting to the Emergency Department (ED) with mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI). We will use subjective and objective tools to measure sleep quality in a cohort of youth admitted to the ED with mTBI, and will correlate those measures with the presence of post-concussive symptoms at 4 weeks follow up. Additionally, we will study how sleep disturbances affect the glymphatic pathway, a network of perivascular spaces surrounding the cerebral vessels, which is associated with waste removal from the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Cholesterol accumulation is critical for the pathogenesis of nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) with fibrosis, a rising public health threat with no available drug treatment. This proposal aims to study the role of the cholesterol- associated GWAS locus EHBP1 in liver fibrosis in the context of NASH and explore the novel crosstalk between EHBP1-mediated cholesterol homeostasis and inflammation resolution. Successful completion of our proposed studies will help meet the critical clinical need for novel therapies that can prevent NASH progression to fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This project is relevant to public health because it tests a molecular-targeted PET agent, 68Ga-P16-093, to guide prostate cancer surgery. When imaging confirms the absence of disease near the nerves and muscles adjoining the prostate, those key structures can be preserved, resulting in improved urinary and sexual quality- of-life. In keeping with the NIH’s mission, this research effort focuses on “improved imaging technologies and surgical interventions...in combination with standard of care therapies.”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Medicare pays for more than 70% of pretransplant services before kidney transplantation ($100,000 per kidney transplant in 2017). These services include evaluating patients with chronic kidney disease for addition to the waitlist, medical surveillance of candidates on the waitlist, and living donor evaluation and procurement. The proposed research will investigate how much each of these services cost and how much they are related to outcomes; the results will inform the transplant community and Medicare where value lies in the complicated process of pretransplant care and which high-value services to prioritize.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glaucoma is the leading cause of irreversible vision loss globally. A new screening paradigm that provides patients with better access to the technology needed to detect glaucoma is urgently needed. This proposal aims to develop a cost-effective technology that integrates optical coherence tomography, the clinical standard for detecting glaucoma, with smartphone devices that can be operated at the point-of-care in novel screening contexts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Metastasis is the leading cause of death in cancer patients, but the mechanisms such as how metabolic rewiring and metastasis interplay remain unclear. Through a customized mitochondrial RNAi screen, we found that alpha- aminoadipate semialdehyde synthase (AASS) and its product 2-aminoadipate (2-AAA) are essential for invasion and metastasis of various human cancers. In this proposal, we will examine by which AASS signaling coordinatively promote tumor metastasis by providing cellular and metabolic advantages to cancer cells and validate therapeutic efficacy of targeting AASS signaling pathway as a novel anti-metastasis therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative At the molecular level, how memory formation is gated such that only some but not all experiences result in long- lasting memories, is an important unanswered question. The proposed study intends to investigate how intron retention controls expression of memory-related proteins to confer selectivity to long-lasting memory. We aim to determine how splicing machinery senses internal and external stimuli, identify trans-acting factors and regulatory sequence motifs, and the consequences of intron retention in memory formation and consolidation. These studies will provide the first detailed insight of intron retention in adult nervous system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The retina, like most other tissues, maintains a physiologically optimal concentration of cholesterol by balancing local (de novo) cholesterol synthesis, vs. uptake from extraretinal sources (e.g., blood-borne lipoproteins, generated in the liver) and export— a process called “cholesterol homeostasis”. Dysregulation of this process leads to profound pathologies, such as Smith-Lemli-Opitz syndrome (SLOS), which can compromise retinal structure and function. This project seeks to further define how cholesterol homeostasis is achieved by the retina, utilizing a combination of novel, genetically altered mice (where cholesterol synthesis has been blocked in a cell type-specific manner) and in vitro cell culture studies (using SLOS patient-derived RPE cells, which exhibit defective autophagy), and to test candidate drugs that can rescue the autophagic defect, as a prelude to testing their ability to rescue retinal degeneration in the novel mouse models of SLOS to be generated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Ryanodine receptors facilitate the coupling of nervous excitation to muscle contraction, by releasing calcium ions from intracellular stores in response to depolarization of the plasma membrane. This is an essential process of fundamental importance to human physiology, and dysregulation of intracellular calcium release in skeletal muscle causes diseases such as malignant hyperthermia, central core disease and RyR1-related myopathies. We seek to understand this process at a molecular level, by interrogating the structural and functional regulation of RyR1 by molecules that modulate channel activity allosterically, including the therapeutic dantrolene.
