IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mounting of an effective and timely adaptive immune response depends on the continuous entry of naïve lymphocytes into lymph nodes via specialized endothelium. The chemoattractants driving migration of lymphocytes across the endothelium into lymph nodes are poorly understood and elucidating the signals mediating this process is important for developing novel and improved immunotherapies that modulate lymphocyte recruitment. We will define the role of oxysterols, which are metabolites of cholesterol, as chemoattractants that promote efficient transendothelial migration of cells into lymph nodes, and thereby advance basic understanding of a fundamental immune cell recruitment process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intestinal epithelial integrity is essential for maintaining homeostasis and requires active intestinal stem cells (aISCs) but is often compromised in individuals who must undergo chemotherapy or radiation therapy. This proposal will establish a functional and mechanistic understanding of how the chromatin modifying enzyme Tet1: (1) permits cellular plasticity to replenish the stem cell pool following aISC injury and (2) orchestrates global changes in gene expression through chromatin modifications during changes in intestinal epithelial cell identity. Findings from my studies will provide key insights into the genetic requirements and mechanisms that drive tissue regeneration and inform approaches taken to treat intestinal inflammation and injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Urinary tract infections and their complications are common and antibiotic usage for these conditions is a major driver of antimicrobial resistance, so alternative therapeutic strategies are needed. To meet this need, Fimbrion is proposing to develop a drug that recruits naturally occurring human antibodies to the pathogenic bacteria that cause urinary tract infections. This research program will begin the pre-clinical studies necessary to develop this drug as a narrow-spectrum, antimicrobial-sparing, antibody recruiting molecule therapy for the prevention of complicated urinary tract infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Centrioles are at the core of structures that organise cells and enable them to divide properly; they also generate cilia that protrude out of cells in some cases to enable the cells to signal and in others to provide motion. Centrioles are built in the same way in humans and in Drosophila and so, this work aims to use the genetic advantages of Drosophila to study how centrioles are made and how they function in different tissues. This will shed light onto a wide range of human diseases from cancer to the brain developmental defects of microcephaly in which centriole function is perturbed in different ways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Although most of ovarian cancer patients initially respond to platinum drug-based chemotherapy, up to 80% of patients become refractory to platinum drugs over the time. In this application, we will determine a novel mechanism regulating platinum drug resistance and evaluate effects of a potential new drug to overcome platinum resistance in ovarian cancer. These findings can lead to development of an innovative therapeutic strategy for treatment of platinum drug resistant ovarian cancer patients.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: Fetal membranes of the uterine cavity form microfractures (fissures that allow cells and amniotic fluid to leak through) that can disrupt pregnancy in response to infection or other unexpected conditions and lead to preterm birth. In normal pregnancies, these fractures are healed or sealed by cellular mechanisms called transitions, which are not easy to study using traditional cell culture methods because they do not facilitate observation of cell-cell interactions, as in an in utero environment. To study fetal membrane functions, we will recreate the entire cell and extracellular matrix components of the membrane on a chip (organ-on-chip) and study how infection and oxidative stress (factors associated with preterm birth) can disrupt and destabilize membranes, which will improve our knowledge of fetal membrane function as well as generate a methodology that is adaptable to various research fields.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: Social behavior is often prominently affected in many neurocognitive disorders such as major depression, schizophrenia, alcoholism and autism spectrum disorder. Yet, despite its importance, the single-neuronal bases and causal underpinnings of interactive social behavior are still largely unknown. The fundamental new line of investigation proposed here in primates will provide a crucial theory-based framework and roadmap for understanding social behavior and its dysfunction at the single-neuronal, population and circuit-based levels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A national consortium of diverse high-risk youth rigorously studied throughout puberty will provide foundational knowledge about the pathophysiology of youth-onset T2D. Findings from this work will shed light on the individual, familial, and social factors affecting youth-onset T2D risk which will, in turn, directly inform strategic investments in targeted approaches for prevention and risk management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Listeria monocytogenes is a foodborne pathogen responsible for the life-threatening disease listeriosis. This work will elucidate novel host pathways activated by the major L. monocytogenes virulence factor, the pore- forming toxin listeriolysin O, to promote host cell invasion and to elicit protective T cell immunity. This knowledge will broadly impact the development of vaccines and novel therapeutic strategies for a wide range of diseases in which pore-forming toxins are employed by pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: This proposal develops new methods to identify how age and genetic factors modify brain metabolism and promote neurodegeneration. It is known that many risk factors change metabolism in specific regions of the brain, but how and why these changes occur is unknown. Identifying the region-specific metabolic consequences of known risk factors will allow us to design strategies to quantify risk and stop neurodegeneration before real damage is done.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The substance use crisis in the United States increasingly involves the co-use of methamphetamine and opioids together. Given the unique sociodemographic characteristics and co-morbidities associated with co- use, existing hospital-based addiction services may not adequately serve patients who use both substances. This project will quantify patient demographics and outcomes following hospital discharge, by substance use profile, and identify facilitators and barriers to expanding hospital-based addiction services tailored to co-use in the inpatient setting, through a sequential explanatory mixed methods design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: In retinitis pigmentosa (RP), rod photoreceptors die, leading to blindness. Patients typically come to the clinic with mid/late-stage disease, after many rods have died. We will test the efficacy, efficiency, specificity and safety a gene therapy for this autosomal dominant orphan disease caused the P23H mutation in rhodopsin.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: RFA: PA-20-203 TITLE: Illuminating Glial Dysfunction in Alzheimer’s Disease with Optical Coherence Tomography PROJECT NARRATIVE: The majority of cells in the central nervous system are glial cells, which provide support for the health and function of neurons. Glial cell dysfunction occurs in Alzheimer’s disease, but non-invasive measurement of glial health is needed to translate this basic knowledge into enhancements in patient health, obtained through early diagnostic testing or assessment of glia-targeted therapies. We propose the use of a common and non-invasive tool for retinal imaging – optical coherence tomography – to explore a new marker of glial dysfunction in persons living with Alzheimer’s disease, and in Alzheimer’s disease mouse models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Abnormal contraction and proliferation of airway smooth muscle contributes to the progression of asthma which affects nearly 25-30 million people in the United Sates and 250 million people worldwide. This research project is to explore previously-unknown mechanisms that control airway smooth muscle contraction, proliferation and asthma pathogenesis using sophisticated biotechnology. Obtaining this knowledge is necessary to develop new strategies to treat the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project focuses on PPARα, a key regulator of fat metabolism in liver cells, and how it and the related factor HNF4α impact non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), a growing threat to public health related to the epidemics of obesity and diabetes. There are no drugs approved for NAFLD, but those targeting PPARα are strong candidates to be among the first. By using mouse and cell models as well as human liver samples, our genomic and genetics studies will reveal mechanisms of PPARα function related to the pathophysiology and treatment of NAFLD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The HIV-1 Gag protein mediates specific genomic RNA packaging during the assembly step of the retroviral lifecycle. The remarkable specificity with which Gag selects this RNA among a vast excess of cellular and spliced viral RNAs remains incompletely understood and is the focus of this work. The high level of sequence conservation in the 5′UTR makes this region especially attractive as a drug target and the results of the studies proposed herein will help guide the design of new therapeutic agents.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infertility affects approximately 10% of women, and recent evidence suggests that infertility is linked with chronic disease, including cardiovascular disease and metabolic syndrome later in life. Changes in gene regulation may proceed the onset of cardiovascular disease and metabolic syndrome, making it an ideal candidate for identifying women at future risk of disease. This would provide an opportunity for early intervention and allow these risks to be discussed as part of infertility evaluations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Urinary tract infections (UTIs), including multi-drug antibiotic-resistant UTIs, occur at an alarmingly high rate after kidney transplantation. The goal of this project is to establish the utility of urinary cell-free DNA as a versatile analyte that can detect a wide range of potential pathogens and can inform drug resistance and host-pathogen interactions. Successful implementation of these studies will lead to a highly informative diagnostic test for UTI which will inform antibiotic stewardship, improve graft and patient outcomes and translate into significant health care cost savings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Integrative Polygenic Genetic Studies of Non-alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease Narrative Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease NAFLD is becoming the number one cause of highly prevalent globally and imparts a significant economic burden but has limited therapeutic options due lack of understanding of its etiology. Here we will carry out integrative genome wide association meta analyses to identify genetic variants that causally associate with NAFLD; we will test implicated variants and genes alone and in combination for their ability to (1) predict hepatic steatosis, cirrhosis, and HCC as well as induce hepatic steatosis in liver cells. Results from our work will help define the etiology of NAFLD and inform development of potential therapeutics for this condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative The focal point of this project is to understand how transcription factors regulate the function of diverse astrocyte subpopulations in the aging brain. Given that astrocyte function is linked to a wide spectrum of neurological disease states, including Alzheimer’s and other neurodegenerative diseases, these studies are likely to reveal new mechanisms that can be applied to the understanding and possible treatment of these disorders. The transcription factor that we are studying, Sox9 and the astrocyte subpopulations that it regulates, have been implicated in a host of neurological disorders, underscoring the direct connections between these studies and associated disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Induction of fetal hemoglobin in adult red blood cells could serve as a functional cure for sickle cell disease and beta-thalassemia, which are among the most common single gene disorders in the world, continue to exhibit unmet clinical need, and affect populations impacted by health disparities. Recently a new molecular mechanism has been discovered to silence fetal hemoglobin in adult red blood cells based on a gene called ZNF410. This proposal explores the hypothesis that targeting ZNF410 could be a promising approach to therapeutically induce fetal hemoglobin—by understanding how ZNF410 controls gene expression, investigating the biological functions of ZNF410, and evaluating small molecules that degrade ZNF410.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative CellRADx is a handheld, rapid, easy-to-use biodosimetry device that will integrate cell-based biomarker assays and immunoassays of radiation injury biomarkers with novel algorithms to fill the unmet public health and medical needs to 1) distinguish individuals exposed to potentially lethal levels of radiation, 2) assess severity of radiation injuries in tissues and organs, and 3).predict early and late effects of acute radiation exposure during and after a public health radiation/nuclear emergency. The successful development and deployment of CellRADx will allow first responders and health authorities to 1) quickly screen (i.e., <2 Gy vs >2 Gy exposure) and triage individuals in a radiation mass casualty incident so that potentially limited medical countermeasures can be administered to those individuals most in need, and 2) predict acute- and late-effects of radiation tissue injuries so that medical treatments can be administered to decrease morbidity and mortality. The potential of CellRADx to help save many lives and enable timely medical treatment decisions will dramatically increase the Public Health emergency response capabilities for the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Older adults commonly have impairments related to aging, such as issues with memory or walking, but often these aren’t measured as part of routine medical care. We created an app called GeriKit, which can be used on a mobile phone or tablet computer, to make it easier for clinicians to measure these impairments. In the proposed study we will evaluate whether GeriKit can be used to predict what happens to patients, and also add new instruments to improve the app, all of which will provide new opportunities for junior scientists who are focused on aging research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT SUMMARY Alzheimer's disease (AD) affects half the US population over the age of 85 and the costs are staggering in human and financial terms. Multiple lines of evidence suggest the involvement of human brain immune cells in AD; however, the mechanisms remains unknown. The proposed studies will generate high-dimensional omics data in human brain immune cells, including single cell analysis, that will inform us about the etiopathogenetic mechanisms of immune cells on AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Targeting the Genus Leishmania with Small Molecules  Our research focus is the development of a new therapy for the parasitic disease leishmaniasis. We have a proof-of-concept and preliminary structure activity relationships (SAR) validating a new antileishmanial chemotype, and the overarching project goal is to expand this SAR and optimize the compounds and their formulations to evaluate lead drug candidates against the disease’s two different clinical manifestations: visceral leishmaniasis and cutaneous leishmaniasis. The work scope will also include important mechanism-of-action and target deconvolution studies that will contribute basic knowledge to the field of leishmania parasitology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Improving access to palliative care for older adults with life-limiting kidney disease is a public health priority because 1) it affects large numbers of people, 2) it can reduce unwanted intensive treatments and improve quality of life and 3) there is public demand to improve end-of-life care delivery. This project aims to address this priority by testing an intervention—a communication tool plus clinician training in its use—designed to improve decision making and facilitate receipt of palliative care for patients with life-limiting illness, specifically kidney failure. Given trends in the number of older patients starting dialysis, the intervention proposed in this study could impact more than 200,000 older Americans annually with end-stage kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE: Are there simple rules for how humans should choose plants to eat for supporting the gut microbiome? One observation has been that the diversity of consumed plant species is linked to the abundance and activity of different bacterial species in the gut. Here, we will test if this finding extends across different human populations, as well as compare the effects of diets that focus on either plant diversity or fiber intake.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current project examines the neural basis of Braille reading in proficient congenitally blind adults, late blind readers with varying degrees of proficiency and blind children learning to read, using fMRI and high-density diffusion imaging (dMRI). These studies of Braille literacy provide insights into human brain plasticity and the neural basis of culture.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE  The Authentic Bioinformatics in the Classroom (ABC) Project has the overall goal of developing bioinformatics and biomedical research interests and skills of high school students from underrepresented backgrounds by integrating this content to high school biology. Students will work on basic science discovery as well as cutting edge research questions related to COVID-19 while learning high school biology. The desired outcome is to stimulate an increase in students from underrepresented groups that go on to pursue STEM careers including biomedical sciences and bioinformatics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Malignant gliomas are the most common brain cancer in adults. Although patients with mutations in the isocitrate dehydrogenase 1 gene have better survival, they inevitably succumb to glioma recurrence and progression. This project explores the underlying mechanism of an inherited vulnerability within this type of glioma for treatment with FDA-approved drug.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Substance use initiation during adolescence is often associated with risky behaviors driven by heightened reward sensitivity, but increased susceptibility to substance abuse may also depend in part on the persistence of reward-associated memories. This proposal aims to determine how reward states – both in the lab and in the real-world – modulate lasting memories that can carry over to guide future behaviors from childhood to adulthood. This work holds the potential to define cognitive and neural mechanisms through which rewarding experiences persist in memory across adolescence, which may provide insights into vulnerability to substance use disorders and ultimately inform possible interventions to support healthy development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our inability to explain why some patients do not respond to immunotherapy, combined with our inability to predict the responders, poses a serious challenge to advancing cancer care and research. Currently, biopsies serve as the most informative way to assess the immunological activity within a cancerous area, but we are spatially and temporally limited in the number of biopsies we can obtain from patients, especially in cases of brain cancer. We propose here a novel strategy merging artificial intelligence and mechanistic modeling to reveal the spatial and temporal tumor-immune landscape within patients by connecting a unique resource of image-localized biopsies and clinical imaging for cohorts treated with standard and immunotherapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The growth of tissues and organs is regulated such that they stop growing when they reach the correct size and shape. In some instances damaged organs can grow back (regenerate) completely while in other cases they cannot. Our research, which aims to understand growth, will provide insights into diseases such as cancer and birth defects, which are characterized by growth abnormalities, and will also suggest ways to improve regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Trauma-induced acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) typically results as an indirect consequence of a severe physical trauma or infection. Once ARDS develops, it is particularly difficult to reverse, making it imperative to identify trauma patients at risk of developing ARDS and to administer preventative treatments before the onset of ARDS. Our overarching goal is to develop and commercialize a diagnostic tool that is capable of quantitatively and rapidly assessing the risk of trauma-induced ARDS at the point of care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative There has been an extraordinary growth in recent years of new techniques to predict common diseases using a new genetic intervention, polygenic risk scores (PRS). The Rational Integration of Polygenic Risk Scores (RIPS) project will use economic modeling to project the lifetime clinical impact and cost-effectiveness of screening a diverse population with PRS to predict the onset of heart disease, breast cancer, and colorectal cancer. The models produced by this study will account for the cost of genetic testing, the cost and effectiveness of the preventative care needed to reduce risk, and the potential pitfalls associated with using these novel interventions in underrepresented and underserved populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tumor relapse is a major clinical challenge for patients with rhabdomyosarcoma. The goal of this interdisciplinary proposal is to combine single-cell omics profiling, computational, statistical and experimental approaches to identify immature subpopulations in rhabdomyosarcoma samples, to investigate the effect of chemotherapy on selection for immature cells and to establish predictive promoter/enhancer activity markers of immature cells for analyzing clinical samples.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer treatment providers – whether or not they are aware – encounter adult survivors of sexual violence in the course of their practice, and yet few providers have the training needed to meet the unique treatment needs of this group. The goal of the proposed R25E is to implement a blended learning program (E-Learning plus Live Workshop) to train cancer care providers in research-based, sensitive practice techniques to help reduce distress, increase feelings of safety and empowerment, and reduce triggering and retraumatization in survivors of sexual violence undergoing cancer screening and treatment. Through this training, we hope to improve the sensitivity of the cancer care offered to sexual violence survivors across the nation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative There is an urgent need to better understand the interactions between sleep and, circadian function and dysfunction and their implications for human health including cardiometabolic health. Progress in this area is crucial for the development and implementation of preventive and therapeutic strategies to address the epidemics of chronic disease that represent a major threat to public health in America and elsewhere; if funded, the results from the research carried out by the Trainees and their preceptors will become public information. The proposed Training Program in Circadian and Sleep Research is uniquely poised to offer the multidisciplinary training needed to prepare investigators in basic, translational and patient-oriented research to lead efforts to improve our understanding of the roles of sleep and circadian function (and dysfunction) for health and disease, and to develop interventions to prevent the development, or reduce the severity and co- morbidities, of some of some of the most prevalent major chronic diseases of modern times.

PROJECT_TITLE: Training Grant in Circadian and Sleep Research

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Successful treatment of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) using targeted agents has been impeded by both disease heterogeneity and drug resistance. To address this challenge, we will identify unique, targetable differences in pathways activated by inflammatory cytokines in AML cells but not in healthy cells, and we will identify the mechanisms by which these pathways selectively drive the course of disease in AML patients. This study will improve our understanding of AML biology and aid in the design of new treatment strategies that effectively target AML cells and suppress disease progression while minimizing side effects by sparing healthy cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Narrative In spite of clear evidence that homeless adults have poor access to essential health services and that supportive housing can mitigate some consequences of homelessness, not enough is known about ways Medicaid and supportive housing policies can help reduce homelessness-related healthcare gaps. This project will analyze 10 years of linked homeless services and Medicaid data in NJ and PA to quantify the contribution of homelessness to gaps in healthcare access and evaluate how permanent supportive housing can help remedy those gaps. Project findings will inform Medicaid and supportive housing policies and programmatic strategies for improving healthcare access among homeless adults and reducing associated racial/ethnic and rural access disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project will examine patterns and predictors of change in alcohol misuse since the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic in coastal communities surrounding the Gulf of Mexico. Two factors unique to COVID-19 are massive increases in unemployment and growing feelings of loneliness caused by stay-at-home orders, both of which might change people's drinking behaviors over time. The study will use 4 waves of a longitudinal survey to answer critical questions about interactions between risk and protective factors, the role of stress and trauma, the co-occurrence of mental health symptoms, and reactions to prior disasters in the region.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Large-scale studies have identified thousands of genetic variants associated with immune diseases, most of them located in regions of the genome that alter gene expression. However, in most cases, it is not known which of these variants drive disease phenotypes, nor their mechanism of action. In this proposal, we will integrate complementary experimental approaches to identify potential causal genetic variants and determine the molecular mechanisms by which they affect gene expression and lead to immune disease. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Insufficient knowledge of early life immune development limits our ability to optimize vaccines and prevent, detect, and treat conditions such as infection and asthma. To gain insight into how early life immune development impacts vaccine responses, health and disease we will: (a) employ a systems biology approach to comprehensively measures changes in molecules such as proteins (proteomics), metabolites (metabolomics) and the bacteria that live in our gut and nose (microbiome); and (b) use liquid (plasma) and cells from human blood donations to model immunity and responses to potentially protective agents outside the body (in vitro). Identifying molecular patterns (“signatures”) of infant immune development that correspond to vaccine-responsiveness, susceptibility or resistance to respiratory infection and asthma will accelerate discovery and development of tests to better predict the risk of childhood disease and guide the development of medical interventions (e.g., vaccines) to optimize immune development, prevent disease and enhance childhood health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer is the third leading cause of cancer-related death in the United States and is associated with a grim 9% 5-year survival rate. The overall goal of this application is to develop a therapeutic strategy using a new therapeutic agent which by targeting tumor cell DNA repair will improve the efficacy of immunotherapy and radiation. The preclinical studies in this proposal will form the foundation for future clinical trials in patients with inoperable pancreatic cancers ultimately leading to urgently needed advances in the clinical management of locally advanced pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic cocaine use (as well as comorbid cigarette smoking and alcohol use) can cause vascular disease. Although the Crack-Cocaine epidemic from the mid-1980s has lessened, with a 3-fold increase in emergency department cocaine-related visits since the end of the 1990s, the vascular consequences of chronic drug use are evident among addicted individuals of that generation. There is a public health imperative to detect early markers of vascular disease, as associated with brain function, to reduce excess morbidity and premature mortality, especially in this aging population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Brain lesions and associated epilepsy are a significant challenge for patients with the genetic disease Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC). Given the clinical diversity in TSC and the varying severity of the disease, it remains unclear which patients will develop debilitating symptoms as a result of tumor growth, thus making surveillance and disease management difficult. In order to inform more personalized treatment approaches for TSC patients, we aim to understand if genome sequencing data can be used to predict disease severity and to associate genetic modifiers with biological outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Aging and carrying the APOE e4 allele are the strongest risk factors for developing Alzheimer’s disease (AD). There is good evidence identifying changes in brain endosomal proteins and ApoE aggregation as early events predisposing to AD pathology. However, there is a major gap in our understanding of the mechanisms by which the ApoE4 protein regulates endosomal trafficking. In this project, we study how ApoE protein aggregates affect brain cellular functions in human and animal tissues. We study whether inducing ABCA1 activity to make ApoE HDL can reduce ApoE aggregation and ameliorate the brain endosomal congestion observed with ApoE4.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE CAR-T cell therapy is an emerging option for cancer treatment, but its efficacy is limited, especially in solid tumors because the effector CD8+T cells that promote anti-tumor immunity become dysfunctional and exhausted in the tumor microenvironment (TME). Our studies demonstrate that Zbtb44, a member of ThPOK family of transcription factors forms a complex with the T-box transcription factor, Eomes which is critically essential for effector function of CD8+ T cells. In the ‘exhausted’ CD8+T cells, Trim47 degrades Zbtb44 and disrupts the Zbtb44-Eomes complex resulting in the inhibitory transcriptional profile. We aim to prevent CAR-T exhaustion by blocking the Zbtb44- Trim47 pathway. Our studies could lead to clinical trials to overcome the current limitations of CAR-T cells leading to improved outcome in patients with advanced solid tumors.

PHR: Health promotion efforts among African American men have produced limited results – these men have lower health-related quality of life than all other racial/ethnic and gender groups in the United States. Findings from this study will provide insight on the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary results of a theoretically-based tailored intervention to improve health-related quality of life among African American men, in addition to providing insight on the recruitment and retention of these men in health promotion efforts. Developing and implementing an effective intervention to improve health-related quality of life among these men can improve mortality rates, morbidity rates, and lower healthcare costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Gout, a metabolic condition causing the most common inflammatory arthritis, leads to painful flares and joint damage; fundamental questions remain about its development. Building on the advances made in our preceding NIH-funded research, and leveraging the unique resources of ongoing prospective cohort studies with decades of follow-up, confirmed incident gout cases, and rich dietary, lifestyle, biomarker, and medical data, we propose to determine the role of metabolites and gut microbiota in the pathogenesis of gout (particularly, hyperuricemia becoming gout) and gout’s distinctive sex predilection. We anticipate this rigorous approach will provide novel mechanistic insights in gout, thereby laying a foundation for new prevention strategies as well as novel predictive tools.

PHR: The relevance of this research to public health: Systemic cryptococcosis is a serious threat to public health, causing hundreds of thousands of deaths each year. This project is to characterize the RAM pathway that is essential for Cryptococcus adaptation to the host physiological conditions and consequently the ability of this fungus to cause disease. Findings from the proposed research will deepen our understanding of cryptococcal pathogenesis and suggest targets for the potential development of novel therapies to prevent or manage this fatal disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Mammals, including humans, are able to waste calories and generate heat to keep normal internal temperature when exposed to cold, a process that is being investigated by many groups as potential therapeutic target to treat obesity. The process requires careful systemic coordination of burning of many fuel sources, including sugars and fats, but how this occurs remains poorly understood. We propose here to use sophisticated state-of- the-art metabolic studies to quantify with precision what fuels are used, how much, and by what tissues, in acutely and chronic cold-exposed animals, ultimately providing a foundational quantitative framework for understanding how animals generate heat.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE

PHR: Project Narrative  Human autoimmune uveitis is a potentially blinding and disabling inflammatory disease affecting approximately 2 million Americans, and current treatments do not cure the underlying disease nor provide long-term prevention of recurrence. This proposal investigates mechanisms, using both mice and human samples, to reprogram the immune system to prevent, suppress, and cure uveitis while preventing blindness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pediatric patients with relapsed or refractory solid tumors have dismal long-term survival rates, which have not improved over the past 2 decades. This proposal seeks to improve outcomes for these patients by genetically modifying T cells to attack solid tumors, evaluate their safety and antitumor activity in a clinical trial, and perform studies to learn what leads to success or failure of this treatment, with the goal of improving and refining our therapeutic approach. While focused on pediatric solid tumors, the mechanistic insights and tumor targeting strategies developed could readily be applied to other cancers in both children and adults.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROYECT NARRATIVE Project: Graduate Program in Bioethics in Research PD/PI Names: Montoya, Juny and Fernández Pinto, Manuela Organization: University of los Andes Project Period: 07/05/2022 - 06/30/2027 The master’s program in Bioethics in Research from University of Los Andes will be offered jointly by the Center of Applied Ethics, the School of Medicine, and the School of Economics, offering a unique interdisciplinary approach to the study of bioethics, with an emphasis on research ethics and the health sciences. As an online program, the master’s program will fill the shortage of quality education in Bioethics and Research Ethics not only in Colombia, but in other Latin American countries. With an innovative design driven by active, practice-oriented, and problem-based learning, the program will ensure that participants develop the necessary skills and competencies to approach ethical challenges in health research today.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Fogarty African Bioethics Post-Doctoral Fellowship Program (FAB-PDF) is an 18-month advanced bioethics postdoctoral training program for scholars from sub-Saharan Africa who hold a bioethics-related PhD. This D43 renewal is a collaboration between Johns Hopkins University (USA), Makerere University (Uganda), and University of Oxford (UK) in which 10 select postdocs will spend modular, dedicated time in each institution, and in their home African institution, completing coursework, scholarly writing projects, a global health ethics leadership project, and participating in informal and formal global bioethics professional networks. By leveraging our experience and longstanding commitments along with well-developed institutional relationships, we offer this highly collaborative post-doctoral training program to further advance the analytic thinking, visibility, leadership capacity, and professional networks of the top doctorally-trained bioethics scholars from sub-Saharan Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tissue-resident macrophages (TRMs) play fundamental roles in health and disease, thus unlocking the biology of these cells is key to gaining a deeper knowledge of many human pathologies. This proposal’s objective is to understand the role of the amino acid hypusine in the maintenance and function of TRMs. Our approach will add new insight into how TRMs carry out functions essential for life, and will establish if hypusine synthesis is a tractable route to modulate TRMs in contexts where they influence disease, such as with tumor-associated macrophages and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Colorectal cancer (CRC) is a common cause of cancer death in the U.S. Yet, screening rates are less than optimal in many Federally Qualified Health Centers, even with new tests that can be done easily at home, such as the fecal immunochemical test (FIT). This study seeks to speed up the adoption of effective cancer prevention and control screening practices by promoting CRC screening in community clinics (rural and urban) in Central and Southwest Florida with added attention on repeat screening. A number of strategies will be implemented including low-literacy patient education combined with FIT distribution plus a cancer control champion. Our goal is to change the annual CRC screening rates at the clinics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Thiol groups can undergo numerous modifications, making cysteine a unique molecular switch. Cysteine plays structural and regulatory roles as part of proteins or glutathione, contributing to maintain redox homeostasis and regulate signaling within and amongst cells. Not surprisingly therefore, cysteines are associated with many he- reditary and acquired diseases – the research described herein will elucidate regulatory functions performed by protein cysteine residues and provide a framework for understanding how mutation and/or (in)activation of this key amino acid can cause disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: The present crisis caused by SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) has harshly illuminated the ability of coronavirus pandemics to sicken and kill millions of individuals, ruin large parts of the economy, and to lead to great social stress. Vaccines, oral and systemic medications, and monoclonal antibodies have all proven effective against SARS-CoV-2, but each has encountered problems with uptake and/or viral and societal resistance, and there is presently no drug on the market with pan-coronavirus activity that would anticipate SARS-CoV-2 evolution and outbreaks of new and deadly coronavirus infections. We have used targeted molecular engineering of a lectin (sugar-binding protein) to create a new broad-spectrum, well-tolerated antiviral agent with significant activity against all coronaviruses tested, including SARS-CoV-2 and variants such as Omicron, and here propose studies that will lead to the effective clinical implementation of intranasal use of this new agent to prevent and treat infection with SARS-CoV-2, diverse coronaviruses, and also ultimately influenza.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: HEALTH RELEVANCE This project investigates how the brain preserves and selects information about multiple sensory stimuli. Deficits in this ability contribute to poor communication performance in noisy scenes in central auditory processing disorder and age-related hearing loss. Insights from these experiments could ultimately lead to improvements in the treatment of these and related conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic skin wounds in patients with type II diabetes do not heal, as they are stalled at an inflammation phase without any growth of blood vessels that would typically close the gap. Exosomes, which are nanosized vesicles secreted by multipotent stromal cells and can be isolated from cell culture, show great promise in promoting faster closure in chronic wounds. In our study, we will investigate how exosomes and their cargo precisely affect major cell types in the wound, to resolve the stalled inflammation and let wound healing proceed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Digital health platforms (DHP) use computing technologies, connectivity, software, and sensors for health care. DHP have the potential to increase health equity for minority groups, the proposed innovative study evaluates a DHP model that leverages on a patient portal to engage race/ethnic groups, who has been disproportionally affected by COVID-19, digitally deliver an intervention (i.e., mindfulness) targeted to mitigate COVID related stress, and remotely collect self-reported psychological and physiological metrics of mental health and autonomic regulation. These findings have implications on precision medicine by providing access and remote/real-time report on the person’s health to offer a targeted intervention, while focus on increasing access to care for race/ethnic populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Autoimmune diseases afflict up to 12% of the US and lupus, as one autoimmune disease, remains a leading cause of medical death in young women of child-bearing age. This program is testing a number of potential drivers and protectors of autoimmune disease using unique patient cohorts and broad investigator expertise.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE  The goal of this research program is to overcome the multiple scattering limit in optical coherence tomography, and thereby address one of the grand challenges in the field of optical microscopy. We will synergistically combine the advantages of a long-wavelength spectral-domain OCT system with adaptive optics, and the principle behind the highly promising coherent accumulation of single scattering method. We propose to demonstrate the deepest OCT imaging to date, in both human skin and mouse brain tissues, which is significant from the perspective of both fundamental imaging science as well as the biomedical applications of OCT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application will investigate HAVCR2 (TIM3), recently identified genetic risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer’s disease, as a target to modulate microglial function and regulate development of Alzheimer’s disease (AD). We identified TIM3 as a key inhibitory molecule in microglia that inhibits their function resulting in progression of AD. Therefore targeting Tim3 in microglia can restore microglial functions and promote clearance of Ab plaques in animal models of AD. The outcomes of the project will have considerable impact on both advancing the basic science of AD and novel TIM3-based immuno-modulating approach for the treatment of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiac arrest is the most devastating disease in the United States affecting more than 550,000 people per year. Despite prompt emergency treatment and better resuscitation techniques, 70-90% of patients die from extensive brain injury, with only three to ten percent of patients able to resume their former lifestyles. Our goal is to understand the mechanisms of serum/glucocorticoid regulated kinases that cause brain injury after cardiac arrest, to lay the foundation for novel therapeutic interventions against cardiac arrest.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Some subpopulations of genetically identical bacteria are killed more slowly than others: this is termed antibiotic tolerance and this tolerance may contribute to the long treatment time for tuberculosis (six months) as well as the development of drug-resistance. However, there are many different forms of antibiotic tolerance with distinct molecular mechanisms and it is not known which forms are most prevalent in, and contribute most to antibiotic susceptibility in animal infection and development of drug-resistance. We will compare two different types of tolerance in clinical strains of Mycobacterium tuberculosis – the cause of tuberculosis -- and determine the genetic mechanisms by which they mediate antibiotic susceptibility and development of drug-resistance.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE  Surgeon scientists play key roles in discoveries and translation of research advances into improved health care for patients. To address a critical shortage in the next generation of otolaryngology surgeon scientists, a new training program that integrates basic, translational, epidemiologic, and clinical sciences into the clinical training of otolaryngology residents and medical students is proposed. This mentored research training program aims to address barriers that prevent trainees from achieving successful academic surgeon scientist careers that facilitate scientific discoveries and advances in hearing and communication disorders that align with the NIDCD mission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative (Public Health Relevance) An improved understanding of how the human lens establishes and maintains transparency over many decades of life is urgently required if therapies to delay the onset and/or progression of cataract in our increasingly aging population are to be developed. By identifying specific molecular changes to lens water channels, aquaporins, that occur with age and their functional consequences, specific therapeutic strategies can be pursued. Such anti-cataract therapies are expected to significantly decrease the incidence of cataract in our aging population, improving not only quality of life but also reducing the enormous financial costs associated with the current surgical treatments for cataract.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Although kidney cancers are typically infiltrated with large numbers of the patient's immune cells, these tumors often escape an effective immune response, and many are resistant to immunotherapy. We will test the idea that an effective T cell response to the cancer is inhibited by macrophages (a type of immune cell), driven by a protein called IRF8, and, using novel mouse models of the disease, we will test whether suppressing macrophages can reduce tumor growth and improve responses to therapy. This work may reveal strategies to improve the effectiveness of immunotherapy and combination therapies for patients with kidney cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Surgery and stereotactic body radiation therapy are the only recommended treatments for stage I lung cancer, a highly prevalent and curable disease. Since the lack of evidence-based treatment allocation in stage I lung cancer remains a critical unmet need, we will perform a prospective, pragmatic, multi-center cohort study to compare the effectiveness of surgery and SBRT for stage I lung cancer. Additionally, we will develop and compare prediction models for treatment outcomes for an individual patient with stage I disease and create a benchmark for personalized treatment allocation in lung cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE O-linked ß-N-acetylglucosamine (O-GlcNAc) is a sugar attachment on proteins. Breast cancer tissues show significantly elevated O-GlcNAc-ylation compared to corresponding adjacent normal tissue. The outcomes from our proposed investigations will enable us to (i) identify how O- GlcNAc-driven reprogramming in breast cancer cells aberrantly activates Hedgehog signaling; (ii) create mechanistic understanding of how O-GlcNAc-ylation programs tumor cell invasion and response to anti-neoplastic drugs, and (iii) discover how elevated systemic O-GlcNAc-ylation programs tumor-intrinsic and tumor-extrinsic (immune microclimate) features of breast tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE National guidelines do not support routine mammography screening in older women (ages 75 and older) and recommend consideration of life expectancy and patient preferences; yet many providers still refer and many patients still receive frequent mammography screening. This research seeks to advance our understanding of the most effective and feasible methods and patient, provider, and organizational solutions for reducing mammography overscreening across a large healthcare system serving a racially/ethnically diverse population of older women in New York City, with the ultimate goal of reducing the use of low-value care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: (K.220) 8. Project Narrative Opioid use disorder (OUD) is associated with disproportionate deficits in recovery capital (i.e. recovery resources) and while OUD medications (MOUDs) aid recovery, these recovery capital deficits often persist, increasing biobehavioral stress and relapse risk. Recovery Community Centers (RCCs) are a free, newly emerging tier of recovery support services that serve as ‘one-stop-shops’ for recovery capital, celebrate all pathways to recovery (including MOUD), and appear to be particularly beneficial for MOUD patients, but few patients or clinicians know of RCCs, clinical linkage to them is uncommon, and their potential benefit to MOUD patients has yet to be systematically investigated. To advance understanding of the clinical and public health utility of RCCs and help bridge the gap between clinical treatment and community-based recovery support services, this study will be the first to develop and test an intervention for peer-facilitated assertive linkage of MOUD patients to RCCs using a randomized design, with the potential to change clinical practice paradigms and address ongoing psychosocial deficits in MOUD patients by helping them obtain the needed resources to achieve and sustain OUD remission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Bladder cancer remains a highly lethal disease despite recent success of immune checkpoint therapy due to resistance to immune checkpoint inhibitors in the majority of bladder cancer cases. We identified that tumor- associated Schwann cells promote an immunosuppressive microenvironment in bladder cancer and determined that the expression of long noncoding RNAs in tumor-associated Schwann cells regulates the enzymatic activities of TDO2 and thus facilitates the expansion of immunosuppressive MDSC cells. Hence, targeting tumor- associated Schwann cells expressing noncoding RNAs should advance our understanding of bladder cancer immunoresistance and pave the way for developing combinatorial therapies for bladder cancer patients to overcome resistance to immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hallucinations are common in older adults with neurodegenerative diseases such as Parkinson disease or Alzheimer disease and carry a poor prognosis. The goal of this project is to determine whether visual impairment and age-related eye disease are associated with the development and severity of hallucinations in older adults. This information will be used to develop clinical screening and treatment guidelines for high-risk patients with the goal of preventing hallucinations and improving quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC RELEVANCE More than a third of adults in the United States are obese, as a result of overeating and sedentary lifestyle and obesity increases the risk for diabetes, heart disease, stroke, cancer, and other health problems. The goal of this project is to study the role of a novel energy-sensing enzyme, Inositol Polyphosphate Multikinase (IPMK), in muscle function and whole body metabolism under normal and overnutrition conditions. We anticipate that our research in mouse and cellular models will reveal how disruption of IPMK pathways in muscle potentially predisposes to obesity, diabetes and abnormal lipid metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) is an emerging Group 1 pathogen and the major cause of cancers in untreated AIDS patients. KSHV, like other DNA viruses, expresses a class of genes late during infection that are essential for viral assembly and escape from their host cell, but how the expression of these genes is regulated has long remained unknown. This grant is focused on revealing how a group of KSHV proteins orchestrates this process though a combination of molecular mimicry and co-option of host gene expression machinery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed application will use the mouse model to investigate how exposure to perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA) adversely influences maternal glucose homeostasis during pregnancy. Human studies suggest that PFOA exposure is associated with increased risk for gestational diabetes, however these observations have not been validated experimentally and the underlying mechanisms are not well understood. In this work, we will define how exposure to PFOA disrupts serotonin metabolism in maternal pancreatic islets and how genetic differences in vitamin B6 metabolism modulate the susceptibility to PFOA-induced gestational diabetes in pregnant mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Both maintaining tissue function and multiple diseases are associated with prostaglandin signaling and collective cell migration, but little is known about the relationship between these two processes. The work in this proposal will increase the understanding of how prostaglandin signaling promotes collective cell migration. This information will provide insight into the origins of numerous diseases ranging from birth defects and impaired wound healing to cancer metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Optimizing the mental health and cognitive abilities of people living with HIV-1 will require an understanding of the biological connections between these functions and HIV-1 infection in the central nervous system (CNS). We will examine, at a single cell or provirus level, the CNS disease profile of both viremic and antiretroviral therapy (ART)-suppressed participants over time. Discovery of the mechanism of how HIV-1 impacts the CNS will lead to innovative targeted therapies that could modulate immunological factors or block specific viral effects to improve neuropsychological outcomes even without total elimination of the CNS HIV-1 reservoir.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The population of the United States is becoming increasingly diverse and research and healthcare issues are becoming increasingly diverse and complex as well. Despite this, the biomedical research workforce remains largely undiversified and there are urgent needs and demands for workforce and experiential diversity for creative problem solving, which will improve the health and lives of all. The UMB STAR-PREP program was designed to holistically, rigorously and comprehensively prepare diverse students to enter and be successful in strong MD-PhD and PhD programs and then in careers to address critical biomedical workforce diversity needs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The objective of this proposal is to engineer a load-bearing, allogeneic, zygapophyseal articular resurfacing system to provide a long-term solution to pathologies related to the facet joint. This joint plays a pivotal, though not fully elucidated, role in chronic pain, being directly and solely responsible for pain in 9M-26M Americans; facet joint degeneration is found in 57% of adults by the age of 30 and 100% of adults over 60 years old. The proposed work aims to provide deeper understanding of this poorly characterized joint in both sexes and then, following a systematic tissue engineering process, to develop a motion-preserving prosthesis that is both biological and functional.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Collagen linearization in breast tumors is a key pathogenic event that leads to enhanced tumor cell invasion and metastasis, and to poor prognosis. However, despite its recognized clinical prognostic value, little is known about the mechanisms responsible for collagen linearization. This project will determine the function of novel secreted regulators of collagen linearization and test whether they could be exploited to normalize collagen architecture in tumors and as anti-metastasis therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Evidence from our laboratory have indicated that gut microbiota plays a key role determining outcome for cancer patients treated with immunotherapy, however, the mechanism by which bacteria within the gut can impact immunity at a distant tumor site remains largely obscure. To address these knowledge gaps, during the remainder of my Ph.D. I intend to work towards identifying how the microbially sourced signal reaches the tumor microenvironment, and to determine the key pathways and cell types involved. In my post-doctoral research, I aim to bioinformatically mine patient stool metagenomics for biosynthetic gene clusters associated with response to immunotherapy, and using synthetic biology approaches study the product of these genes to assess immune potentiating or anti-tumorigenic capacity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal aims to evaluate the ability of the cell adhesion molecule Netrin-G ligand 2 (NGL2) to rescue synapses and protect photoreceptors from degeneration. It will also elucidate the molecular composition and signaling mechanisms of synaptic NGL2 complexes and the contributions of NGL2’s interaction partners to synapse maintenance and neuroprotection. To accelerate translation, the proposal examines the function and therapeutic potential of NGL2 and its interaction partners simultaneously in mice and human retinas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application seeks to continue a long-term training program in the Contemporary Approaches to Cancer Cell Signaling and Communication focused on cancer research at the University of California, San Diego, building on an outstanding history of mentoring young scientists to become future leaders in academia and biotech. The faculty includes thirty-two distinguished mentors spanning many areas of biological chemistry, chemical engineering, bioengineering, computational biology, and molecular oncology, who are committed to state-of-the-art laboratory research and training. The overarching mission of this program is to provide training to outstanding pre-doctoral PhD students and post-doctoral scientists in a highly interactive scientific environment in order to prepare them for future high-impact careers in cancer research.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Indiana University Medical Student Program for Research and Scholarship at the Indiana University School of Medicine has established a pipeline for medical students to enter research intensive programs such as MD/PhD, MD/MS, or gap year programs, and more broadly to encourage them to embrace the career of physician-scientists. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Public Health Relevance Work by the applicants and collaborators has identified 3 candidate drugs for repositioning for alcohol use disorder (AUD) that are currently in different stages of clinical testing and that are likely to act at least in part via modulation of neuroinflammation. Using these 3 candidate drugs for AUD and a panel of selected anti- inflammatory drugs with different mechanisms of actions, we aim to reverse engineer the effects of alcohol on neuroinflammation to identify mechanisms behind alcohol-induced tissue damage and therapeutic efficacy. This approach is expected to highlight specific alcohol-induced inflammatory pathways of motivational significance and that their delineation will point to new and more effective therapeutic targets and medications for AUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research addresses the critical public health need for sufficiently intense speech treatments, without which ~6 million Americans adults live with unresolved speech sound disorders. The project’s investigation of intensive motor-based treatment bootcamps and artificial intelligence-driven treatment potentiates an evidence-based paradigm shift in which combined speech-language pathologist/artificial intelligence service delivery overcomes existing access barriers to sufficiently intense treatment. The project is relevant to the NIDCD’s and NIH’s missions of conducting behavioral research to reduce disability, as those with unresolved speech sound disorders may experience reduced educational, social, emotional, and occupational outcomes throughout the lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative  In the past few decades, the human papilloma virus (HPV) has been driving an epidemic of head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) emphasizing the need for a clear understanding of HPV-driven carcinogenesis in these tumors. The goals of this proposal are to characterize a previously unrecognized subset of HPV-associated HNSCC that harbors somatic inactivating mutations in NF-κB regulators and to explore roles of NF-κB signaling in an alternative mechanism of HPV tumorigenesis. This work should help to define an alternative mechanism through which HPV causes cancer in the head and neck, personalize cancer care and de-escalate therapy to improve quality of life amongst survivors, while providing a basis for discovery and testing of novel therapies that may benefit patients at high risk of dying from HPV-associated cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer epidemiology is complex due to the long induction period between when a risk factor occurs and when a cancer develops. However, most of the cancer literature uses standard methodology to analyze cancer incidence and survival data. In the current application, we propose to make more efficient use of cancer incidence and survival data by considering four distinct types of innovations: (a) lethal cancer models to predict which disease-free subjects will die due to a specific cancer in the future, (b) latency models to make optimal use of repeated measures of exposure data, (c) cure models to assess which pre-diagnostic risk factors predict whether a patient will be cured of a cancer, and (d) Colorectal cancer screening models to incorporate previous colonoscopy data to more accurately predict future CRC risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The US Government is the leading funder of HIV prevention and care in low- and middle-income countries, and there is a need to allocate resources with evidence-based strategies proven to work in the most efficient manner possible. This project will provide needed policy and program advice on what is working in global HIV prevention based on the strength of evidence from the scientific literature using systematic reviews and meta- analyses to address the most salient needs emerging in the field, including the impact of COVID-19 on HIV services. The study will provide essential information to guide intervention programming to improve the public health impact of US investments in global HIV/AIDS prevention and control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposed research project has significant public health implications given the profound increase in the incidence of diabetes mellitus and the ensuing exponential increase in health care expenditures required to treat its complications. Diabetic complications are optimally prevented when euglycemia is achieved through the use of insulin infusion pumps that approximate normal glucose homeostasis for insulin-dependent diabetes patients. The resultant knowledge will extend infusion pump lifetime by providing additional insights into the causal role of mast cell activation and products following insulin excipient and device induced tissue reaction to allow the identification of new targets that will advance the development of more effective and specific approaches that will optimize future diabetes therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This grant is to support the investigators of the Dana-Farber/Partners Cancer Care (DF/PCC) NLAPS in their efforts to provide scientific leadership and accrual to the national fight against cancer. The Harvard-affiliated DF/PCC investigators have for decades been leaders in developing critical clinical trials that have set the standard for cancer treatment in the US, in developing the scientific rationale for those trials, and in enrolling patients on the most important studies that move the field forward. Investigators from DF/PCC have made and continue to make contributions as leaders in critical NCTN trials that have in recent years improved outcomes for patients with prostate cancer, lung cancer, breast cancer, melanoma, myeloma, leukemia, ovarian cancer and other tumor types, helping reduce the burden of cancer in American society, and improved survival for patients in the US and across the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Obesity will soon be the leading cause of preventable cancers and a large proportion of cancer patients are obese, but little is understood about how obesity influences the effectiveness of cancer therapy. Clinical studies as well as our pre-clinical data show that obese cancer patients are more resistant to radiotherapy and have higher rates of cancer recurrence. Based on our previous data showing that obesity profoundly impacts tumor biology we will examine mechanisms inducing radiotherapy resistance and how to improve outcomes in obese patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In previous studies with adolescent girls and young women (AGYW) at risk of HIV in sub-Saharan Africa, 20- 50% have symptoms of common mental disorders (e.g., depression, anxiety, stress) which are associated with suboptimal adherence to HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP), a highly effective HIV prevention approach. In this K99/R00 project, the candidate, an epidemiologist and behavioral scientist committed to HIV and global mental health research, seeks to address poor PrEP adherence and mental health among AGYW at risk of HIV by adapting, testing, and optimizing an evidence-based mental health intervention for the context of PrEP delivery. This study will provide important insights on approaches for integrating mental health interventions in PrEP delivery and the optimized intervention has the potential to improve both PrEP adherence and mental health outcomes for AGYW in South Africa and other high burden settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative ERα-positive cancers remain a major clinical need and proposed herein (F99) we seek to explore novel derivatives of ErSO, our newly discovered cytotoxic drug for the treatment of ERα-positive breast cancers. Further, hepatocellular carcinoma is a highly lethal cancer type with a major breakthrough for disease management yet to be elucidated. This proposal (K00) seeks to address this clinical need via study of the mutant allele imbalance (MAI) of CTNNB1 oncogenic mutations, studying this imbalance on tumor metabolism, and ultimately provide insights into CTNNB1 MAI with implications for targeted therapies for hepatocellular carcinoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: In all organ systems, efficient clearance of senescent, damaged, dead and infected cells is necessary for tissue homeostasis and immunosurveillance against viral infections. Understanding this process at a deeper molecular level may reveal novel therapeutic strategies for many age-related and infectious diseases. This application breaks new ground by defining the regulation and function of ion channel TRPM7 in this process and may therefore advance TRPM7 as a novel drug target to modify immunity and tissue regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE . The goal of this project is to establish the molecular mechanisms regulating the expression of key components in the signaling of the cardiac natriuretic peptides ANP and BNP in adipocytes and adipose tissue: in particular the transcriptional regulation of the genes encoding natriuretic peptide receptor-C (Nprc), the cGMP-specific phosphodiesterase-9 (Pde9), and the NP-degrading enzyme neprilysin (Mme). We will also test the hypothesis that the elevated NPRC expression in adipose tissue in obesity results in excessive uptake of the peptides ANP and BNP from the circulation and (iii) and to test in mouse models the efficacy and utility of a longer-acting ANP analogue to increase brown/beige adipocyte amount and activity, thus raising energy expenditure and protecting from obesity-induced insulin.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The main aims of this study are to: 1) Determine the extent that Smad2/3 activation contributes to myopia progression, structural changes indicative of pathological myopia (PM), and retinal degeneration in mouse models of Marfan syndrome (MFS) and Rbp3-mediated retinitis pigmentosa (RP); 2) Determine a role for TGFβ- dependent mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) signaling in myopia progression, PM changes and retinal degeneration in MFS and Rbp3-deficient mice. The scientific goal of this proposal is to elucidate the mechanisms driving excess eye growth, its structural complications, and concomitant retinal degeneration in two etiologically- distinct causes of monogenic myopia to identify and target common drivers of disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Interventions such as fasting that lower food intake have long been known to extend lifespan. This application shows that increasing energy expenditure rather than lowering food intake, an intervention we call reverse fasting, also increases lifespan even in animals that eat more than ad libitum fed animals. Our result strongly argues against the view that damage from energy metabolism is a significant driver of aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it rooted in the social ecological model framework, which considers the myriad levels of our healthcare system in the quantitative and qualitative evaluation of social factors, facilitators and barriers, and surgical outcomes for patients with limited English proficiency (LEP). With the findings of this research and the evaluation of a mobile medical interpretation application deployed to patients with LEP, we have the potential to design and implement future scalable interventions built with patient-centered communication and mitigating negative social factors at the core across hospitals across the US for maximum impact. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIMHD’s mission as it aims to reduce health inequities and improve the care of millions of patients by mitigating language and communication barriers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Rates of alcohol use disorders (AUD) in women have increased by 84% over the past 10 years. All FDA- approved medications for AUD have relatively low efficacy and none target factors that maintain drinking in women. This research will contribute to the public health effort to improve AUD treatment by providing a neurobiologically-informed approach to the development of sex-appropriate therapeutics for AUD, mentoring the next generation of interdisciplinary and translational researchers focused on alcohol use and women’s health, and providing an institutional, regional, and national center of research excellence on sex differences in alcohol use spanning T1 to T4 translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Colorectal cancer is the 2nd most common cause of cancer death among men and women in the Unites States, with a majority of the mortality associated with metastasis that has spread to other organs. We have proposed to investigate the mechanisms of how lipid metabolism promotes CRC metastasis. The completion of this study will help to advance our knowledge of the contribution of lipid metabolism to CRC metastasis and to further guide the development of novel therapeutic strategies to treat CRC and potentially other solid cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: The Career Enhancement Core of the Yale-SCORE contributes to public health by responding to the dramatic need for interdisciplinary and translational scientists, focused on applying sex as a biological variable (SABV) to the study of alcohol use. The Career Enhancement program provides: a team of mentors who are leaders in translational, alcohol, and SABV science, salary support for junior faculty, a pilot project program, and a core curriculum that provides foundational knowledge, professional development and leadership training.

PHR: Rates of alcohol use disorders (AUDs) in women have increased by 84% over the last decade, relative to the 35% increase in men. The key purpose of the Resource Support Core is to provide essential research-related resources to Yale-SCORE investigators, trainees, and collaborating researchers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Recruitable thermogenic beige adipocytes have been thought to be short-lived, rapidly converting to “white-like” adipocytes after discontinuing the stimuli. This creates a key challenge to explore beige adipocytes as a sustainable therapy for chronic metabolic diseases. We have recently discovered that beige adipocytes have the ability to stay long-lived and subsequently improve energy expenditure and metabolic fitness. This proposal is designed to leverage our expertise in adipocyte biology and mouse genetics and study the mechanism on how beige adipocytes lose their cellular identity under both physiological and pathological conditions, and how this progress can be maintained to combat obesity and insulin resistance.
