IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Rates of alcohol use disorders (AUD) in women have increased by 84% in women over the past 10 years. All FDA-approved medications for AUD have relatively low efficacy and none target factors that maintain drinking in women. This research contributes to the public health effort to improve AUD treatment, by establishing whether guanfacine, a selective alpha2a adrenergic agonist, demonstrates efficacy for AUD by preferentially attenuating stress-induced drinking in women and stimulation-induced drinking in men.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  We have discovered through in-depth analysis of unique sets of matched samples from patients before and after carboplatin/paclitaxel treatment, chemosensitive/chemoresistant patient-derived xenograft (PDX) models, and platinum or taxane-resistant cell lines, that chemoresistant ovarian cancer cells have a preferential dependence on ribosomal biogenesis for their survival. Targeting ribosomal biogenesis with inhibitors of RNA Polymerase I (Pol I) are effective in eliminating chemoresistant cells, without damaging noncancerous cells at equivalent doses. This proposal will identify the optimal approach to target chemoresistant ovarian cancer cells with a new class of inhibitors, elucidate the fundamental mechanisms causing chemoresistant cells to be more dependent on ribosomal biogenesis than nonmalignant cells, and identify new targetable genes that can be used combination with Pol I inhibition for enhanced therapeutic effect.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is currently the third most lethal cancer in the United States with poor prognosis in part due to the late-stage diagnosis and treatment. We propose to develop a novel nano- formulation of miRNA that reverts pancreatic cancer at an early stage of cancer development. These nanotherapeutics can be used as a pre-malignant stage treatment or prophylaxis for individuals with high risk of pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: In the United States, approximately 33 million men and women have an alcohol use disorder (AUD) and their alcohol use has devastating consequences on their health and mental well-being, with women suffering greater consequences than men. Current treatments for AUD show only minimal efficacy. This research contributes to the public health effort by identifying neurochemical mechanisms, including microglia and synaptic density, that underlie the sex differences in alcohol-related dysfunction, informing novel sex-appropriate therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Income volatility, i.e., fluctuations in income over time, creates uncertainty for low socioeconomic status families of whether they will have enough money to make ends meet, which may cause anxiety, worry, and stress. Chronic stress may in turn accelerate aging. This project will investigate the association between income volatility and anxiety, worry, and stress and the association between income volatility and physiological aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Women are more likely to drink in response to stress than men. Project 3 will study mechanisms for sex differences in negative reinforcement drinking to be studied in Projects 1 and 2 to help provide new targets for the treatment of problem drinking. We will contribute to the public health by investigating sex differences in nerve cell function, neuroimmune signaling, and metabolism that respond to alcohol and stress, and determine whether these factors can be targeted to develop sex-appropriate treatments for alcohol use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative__ ______________________________________________________________________ Family caregivers to persons living with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias provide complex care tasks (e.g., medication management, pain management, and mobility assistance) with no training, resulting in a lack confidence when performing complex care tasks and an increased likelihood of experiencing experience emotional difficulty. Learning Skills Together is a psychoeducational skills-based intervention developed by a multidisciplinary team of healthcare experts to improve caregivers’ self-efficacy with the performance of complex care tasks and to reduce their emotional distress. We propose to test caregiver participation in the Learning Skills Together program in a randomized controlled trial and compare its effects on caregiver self-efficacy with an active control group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Metastatic disease, the most common cause of breast cancer-related mortality, is mediated by cancer cells capable of disseminating and colonizing distant organs. We will determine the signaling events within tumor microenvironment required for emergence of disseminating cancer cell phenotype (invasive and stem). We will also determine the mechanisms by which these cancer cells re-disseminate from metastatic foci, a process that may perpetuate metastases even after the removal of the primary tumor. Since the majority of patients with metastases are treated with chemotherapy we will determine the effect of chemotherapy on these two processes.  To capture the true biology of the tumor microenvironment we will employ novel technologies for in vivo imaging of large volumes of tissue along with our novel biosensors, both in primary tumors and in the lungs, with single cell resolution, and over many days. The findings will likely lead to new approaches for treatment of metastatic disease which is responsible for 90 percent of cancer related mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative TET enzymes remove DNA methylation and their activity is often lost or diminished in many different cancers, including B cell lymphomas. Why loss-of TET function causes development of cancers remains unclear. This proposal will investigate mechanisms by TET proteins prevent the accumulation of unusual structures in the DNA, called G-quadruplexes, which cause genomic instability and transcriptional perturbations; that are hallmarks of cancer cells. These studies will be pivotal in understanding how TET proteins suppress development of cancers and will pave way for new therapeutic regimens for treatment of B-cell and other malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This premise of this project is to develop the fundamental understanding of the structural factors that underlie the formation and deconstruction of supramolecular assemblies, due to covalent and non-covalent interaction between polymers and proteins. These molecular assemblies are programmable, in that these can be triggered to disassemble in the presence of a biologically relevant stimulus or a combination such stimuli. Such programmed assemblies have utility in a broad range of unmet biomedical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Deep brain stimulation (DBS) of the subthalamic nucleus (STN) is an effective therapy for Parkinson’s disease (PD), however, some patients experience an unintended decrement in cognition which impacts quality of life and independence. This study will evaluate neuroimaging biomarkers to help identify the neural basis for increased vulnerability to cognitive decline. The proposed research is relevant to the NIH and NINDS missions to reduce disability and seek fundamental knowledge about the brain to reduce the burden of neurological disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Oxygen is essential in the retina, and the deficiency of oxygen is a culprit in a broad spectrum of retinal diseases. However, it remains challenging to measure oxygen in vivo in the eye. This multidisciplinary proposal is to develop a disruptive imaging method to provide unprecedented volumetric oxygen mapping in living mouse retina, as well as a deep learning method, to translate our oxygen measurements into label-free retinal oximetry for future clinical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Staphylococcus aureus is a leading cause of human infection. In spite of many years of research on this pathogen, we have limited knowledge of host genetic factors that govern susceptibility to infection. The focus of this proposal is to evaluate a human genetic polymorphism that may shed light on risk for S. aureus infection. The successful identification of an informative polymorphism will engender novel opportunities to develop a bedside-accessible, patient-specific genetic marker that can inform the approach to clinical care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Methamphetamine use is an emerging threat to the health and well-being of Black gay, bisexual and other men who have sex with men (GBMSM). The proposed project will examine pathways between four forms of structural racism and discrimination (housing discrimination, gentrification, racial and income segregation, and discriminatory community climate for lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender individuals) and methamphetamine use in this population. This information will be used to inform structural interventions to prevent methamphetamine use and related harms among Black GBMSM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Oral wound healing is an ideal model for scarless tissue regeneration. Our proposal will test the hypothesis that Prx1+ oral fibroblasts are responsible for accelerating the healing process by functioning as stem cells that regulate immune response. Upon successful completion, our work may have a direct impact in the clinical utilization of connective tissues or ex vivo stem cell therapy using Prx1+ cells to treat a wide variety of human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Alcohol use increases the risk for treatment dropout, relapse, and overdose in patients receiving opioid agonist treatment for opioid use. This project will develop and evaluate a modified alcohol-focused intervention tailored to address alcohol use in patients in opioid agonist treatment who are struggling with alcohol use disorder. This brief and scalable tailored intervention will have the potential to decrease alcohol use and improve opioid agonist treatment outcomes with minimal resources, adding in an innovative way to efforts to address the ongoing opioid overdose crisis in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative We recently discovered that reducing collagen expression from gliomas has a major effect on tumor progression and malignant behavior. We now propose to analyze a poorly understood collagen receptor, i.e., LAIR-1, which is expressed on glioma cells and on infiltrating immune cells. We will explore the mechanisms by which LAIR-1 simultaneously controls tumor growth, invasion, and which mediate inhibition of anti-glioma immunity; we will also explore the potential therapeutic benefit of inhibiting LAIR-1 signaling in glioma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is growing evidence that defects in myelination, a process that insulates neurons and facilitates brain activity, may be an important aspect of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) pathology. Oligodendrocyte progenitor cells (OPCs) give rise to oligodendrocytes, the myelin-producing cells of the brain, and have recently been shown to become dysregulated during pathology, exhibit toxic functions and shape chronic disease. The current project will investigate how alterations in OPCs and mature oligodendrocytes are affected by two factors closely linked to AD (tau and ApoE4), to shed new light on a novel, disease-causing role for OPCs in AD progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Recent scientific evidence indicates that Staphylococcus aureus small colony variants are contributing to lung function decline and other poor outcomes in persons with cystic fibrosis (CF) lung infections. The standard-of- care for detecting lung pathogens in CF is by culturing sputum, but new CF therapies make it more difficult for patients to produce sputum, although their risk of lung infection is still high. The aim of this project is to identify breath biomarkers of S. aureus small colony variants and methicillin resistance (MRSA) that would enable the non-invasive and rapid detection of these infections in patients that can’t produce sputum.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: We have shown that disruption of the muscle circadian clock mechanism through loss of the core clock gene, Bmal1, is sufficient to induce significant muscle weakness and surprisingly, increased mortality. Based on these findings, the overall objective of this grant is to pursue the fundamental understanding of the role of the muscle circadian clock in regulating a daily program of gene expression and how clock disruption leads to significant muscle weakness and diminished systemic health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative  This is a renewal of NIH grant DK031036 which is focused on the insulin and IGF-1 receptors, their signaling pathways and their alterations in physiologic and pathologic states. Over the past decade, we have made tremendous progress in understanding the signaling and biological roles of these receptors through both in vitro and in vivo studies, including extensive studies using gene targeting to create over a dozen models with single, combinatorial and tissue-specific knockouts of insulin and IGF-1 receptors to determine their role in normal physiology and the pathophysiology of disease. During the coming grant period, our aims are to continue to expand our understanding of insulin/IGF1 action by 1) defining the differential roles of the extra- and intra-cellular domains of IR and IGF1R in signaling in vitro and in vivo; 2) determining the nature of signaling by the unoccupied insulin and IGF-1 receptors involved in control of gene expression, autophagy and apoptosis and 3) continuing to determine the role of insulin signaling in brain on astrocytes vs neurons and the role insulin resistance in brain in pathogenesis of Alzheimer’s Disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: A thorough understanding of cells and molecules that regulate tissue fibrosis is essential for the generation of tissue-specific regenerative therapies to effectively treat human disease. Since the manner in which adipocytes function during skin fibrosis is largely unknown, we will define how these major but poorly understood cells function during fibrosis using mouse models and human patient cells in culture. Our work will improve our understanding of the cells and molecules that control fibrosis development, how adipocytes function in this disease progression, and will have global relevance for other tissues like heart and lung that undergo fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Coxiella burnetii, the intracellular bacterial pathogen the causes Q fever, has few described virulence factors outside of its Type IVb Secretion System and lipopolysaccharide. Using a unique cellular model of Coxiella infection, we discovered that multiple genes related to the bacterial cell wall are specifically required for replication in primary macrophages. These genes represent a novel class of cell type-specific virulence determinants for C. burnetii.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative In the proposed project entitled, “2/2-GEOHealth Health Effects of Selected Environmental Exposomes Across the Life CourSe (HEALS)-US” we have assembled a multidisciplinary group of researchers, mentors, and program faculty from the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health (HSPH) and the Centre for Chronic Disease Control (CCDC) to build the capacity of public health professionals in India to generate data needed to address the unique characteristics of exposures in India. Our goal is to build scientific capacity in India to conduct high quality research and gain knowledge that can be translated into policy improvements. We will advance capacity by providing a robust platform of training programs for postdoctoral, early- career and short-term researchers, Doctor of Public Health training at HSPH, curricula that benefit current researchers and support the development of a Master’s of Science in Environmental Health program in Indian Institutes of Public Health, and support for CCDC faculty involved in the U01 to complete mentored research activity at HSPH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE This study will examine a novel immune-modulatory mechanism through which statins impede the progression of lethal prostate cancer. The research plan includes the construction of tumor microarray (TMA) set from a clinical cohort of men sampled based on their statin use at the time of prostatectomy, and a proof-of-principle pre-prostatectomy randomized trial to test the effect of statins on this pathway in men diagnosed with prostate cancer schedule for prostatectomy. The research project is complemented by a comprehensive training program that will prepare the applicant for an independent research career as a translational cancer epidemiologist.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current study will examine correlations between T cell senescence and the severity and progression of sporadic inclusion body myositis (IBM). Further, the capacity of senolytic drugs to inhibit or ablate senescent IBM T cells will be evaluated. The proposed studies promise to advance our understanding of the role of T cells in IBM and provide mechanistic insight on the regulation of T cell senescence in IBM muscle.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Cryptosporidium is a water-borne parasite that causes diarrheal disease that in immuno- compromised people can be severe and sometimes fatal. There is no drug to effectively treat cryptosporidiosis. In this application we will study a group of related natural product fungal metabolites that inhibit Cryptosporidium to identify an optimal compound that can be developed into a clinical therapeutic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on identifying previously unknown molecular mechanisms mediating abnormal synaptic communication triggered by soluble oligomers in Alzheimer’s disease, and the modifications of those mechanisms which ultimately promote synaptic protection in people resilient to soluble oligomers effects. This is expected to provide new knowledge about potential targets of pharmacological intervention and drive the development of a novel, effective therapy for AD, thus improving these patients’ health while driving down the societal cost for their care. The proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission concerned with fostering creative discoveries and their application to advance the Nation’s capacity to protect and improve health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this proposal for a P50 Center is to is to expand existing strengths and expertise in Nebraska to develop a novel niche in alcohol research, by creating a Center focused on the Alcohol Exposome. We hypothesize that under the comprehensive schema of the exposome, alcohol represents an environmental exposure that should be considered in context with other internal and external factors to understand the etiology of disease and the subsequent manifestation of alcohol pathophysiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  New classes of bright and stable fluorescent dyes will be developed and converted into valuable molecular probes for biomedical imaging. The fluorescent molecular probes will be used for advanced microscopy studies of cells, in vivo imaging of animal models of cancer and glaucoma, and emerging clinical imaging procedures such as fluorescence guided surgery and rapid pathology. In some cases, biomedical researchers will be able to synthesize their own molecular probes using a machine, thus greatly facilitating the clinical translation process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this research is to better understand the neurobiological basis of consciousness and its modulation by the anesthetic agents. The project will use cognitive testing, functional magnetic resonance imaging and noninvasive brain stimulation with low intensity focused ultrasound in awake and sedated volunteers. The findings should provide insight into how recovery of consciousness could be facilitated in anesthetized patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic limb threatening ischemia (CLTI) is a condition with increasing prevalence in the United States that puts patients at a high risk for wounds, limb loss, and death. Treatment is complex, often evolving over time, and involves medications, wound care, and surgical or endovascular revascularization. The results of this study will yield a comprehensive staging system for CLTI by jointly estimating initial limb outcome and survival risk, and quantifying how those risks evolve over time as key treatments are administered.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One of the major complications of hypercholesterolemia is atherosclerosis, which is the leading cause of death in the US. Using a panel of diverse inbred mouse strains, we have recently uncovered a novel sex-specific role for a liver gene, L-PK, in regulating mitochondrial functions and liver triglyceride accumulation, while also suggesting a possible role in regulating plasma cholesterol levels. This R01 proposal aims to address a major public health problem and will define the sex-specific mechanisms by which L-PK regulates cholesterol metabolism and its implications with regards to atherosclerosis progression using state-of-the-art experimental approaches and a team of experts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This research investigates the pharmacological mechanisms underlying the efficacy and resistance of lenalidomide, a molecular glue degrader for the treatment of multiple myeloma. Furthermore, this study proposes an innovative approach for identifying novel molecular glues. By enhancing our comprehension of molecular glue activities, and offering a pathway to discover novel molecular glue compounds, this research has the potential to broaden the scope of druggable proteins and facilitate the development of novel therapies for presently untreatable cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The role of placental hormones in securing metabolic homeostasis in the mother and fetus during pregnancy is poorly understood; and the potential role of placental hormones and other placental products in maintaining maternal health and treating metabolic disorders outside of pregnancy is insufficiently explored. The present proposal aims to understand the effects of the placental hormone kisspeptin in regulating liver metabolism as well as blood glucose homeostasis. The studies will also elucidate kisspeptin-activated signaling mechanisms in liver cells with the potential to identify novel targets for treating metabolic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will help elucidate how the tumor suppressor BRCA1-BARD1 antagonizes the DNA damage response protein 53BP1 to promote DNA double-strand break repair by homologous recombination (HR) post-replication. This work is relevant to public health because by revealing the mechanisms of action of BRCA1-BARD1, it will help identify in patients BRCA1-BARD1 mutations that inactivate HR and may be causative for cancer, especially breast and ovarian cancer. Furthermore, because several anti-cancer drugs target HR-deficient cancer cells, in the long term the new knowledge gained on BRCA1-BARD1-mediated HR DNA repair could help develop new means of inactivating HR and counteracting drug resistance that patients with cancer often acquire over time.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES A. HALEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Serum amyloid A (SAA) proteins are critical to the regulation of inflammation in systemic as well as neurological diseases. Studies have shown that during an acute phase response (APR), SAA levels increase 1000-fold and can stimulate the inflammasome, trigger the recruitment of immune cells to inflammatory sites, and elicit the induction of enzymes that degrade extracellular matrix. SAA levels are significantly elevated following stroke/cerebral ischemia linking systemic inflammation and neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Multiple sclerosis (MS) is the most common neuroinflammatory disease among young adults. The overall goal of this proposal is to identify the signaling pathways and their effector mediators that regulate the interactions of pathogenic CD4+ T cells and antigen-presenting cells within the central nervous system that exacerbate neuroinflammation. Targeting these pathways and mediators may become a novel strategy for the treatments of MS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research is relevant to public health because it has significant promise to impact implementation strategies to increase human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccination and other health contexts where provider communication and reminder messages are important (e.g., cancer screenings and shared decision making about cancer treatments). The project maximizes the impact of the Text & Talk study by extending the findings with additional data to understand the factors related to for whom and why the implementation strategies were effective and sustainable. The proposed research is relevant to NIH’s mission to prevent cancer and eliminate disparities in cancer within the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: The proposed research is highly relevant to public health, as it investigates the connection between a neurexin1-mediated core synaptic pathway and the heparan sulfate-mediated pathway, which have both been implicated in autism, schizophrenia, and intellectual disability. Our proposed studies aim to link two pathways and shed light on the biological significance of the heparan sulfate attachment to neurexin1 in vivo, as well as uncover the underlying molecular mechanism. By doing so, we hope to unravel a unified mechanistic understanding of the synaptic abnormalities in these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although colorectal cancer (CRC) is enriched with pathogenic mtDNA mutations, the role of the mitochondrion in CRC remains unknown. In this proposal, we will leverage our expertise in mitochondrial biochemistry, state- of-the art in vivo, in vitro, and ex vivo CRC models, and viral genetic manipulation to define the molecular pathways linking mitochondrial metabolism to CRC growth. By providing a mechanistic link between mitochondrial bioenergetics and CRC, this work will move the field forward in our understanding of the role of mitochondria in CRC, ultimately paving the way for CRC-specific mitochondrial interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acutely ill patients with diabetes are often unable to maintain good glucose control in the hospital and are at risk of potentially devastating outcomes. The proposed project seeks to transform inpatient diabetes management through the implementation of automated insulin delivery (AID) utilizing a strategy that simultaneously addresses key safety elements surrounding in-hospital use of diabetes technology (i.e. use of disposable devices, nursing staff rapid response with alarms, electronic health records documentation, and remote monitoring of continuous glucose trends and insulin delivery rates). Findings from this project, including a randomized clinical trial and a detailed assessment of diabetes technology adoption, will inform the design of a larger study aimed at evaluating clinical outcomes and initiate a trajectory of research focused on the implementation of advanced diabetes technologies in the hospital.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative People with cancer are vulnerable to SARS-CoV-2 infection and often experience severe outcomes of the resultant COVID-19. We have gathered more than 17,000 case reports of people with cancer and COVID-19 through the COVID-19 and Cancer Consortium registry. This project will lead to a greater understanding of outcomes in these patients, in particular cancer- related outcomes that may not be evident until years after the primary infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The public health significance of this study lies in its potential to develop an improved understanding of the components of lifestyle interventions that are necessary to help adult cancer survivors with overweight and obesity improve dietary patterns to reduce weight and improve cardiometabolic health. Results will lead to optimized interventions that balance effectiveness with affordability, scalability, and efficiency to improve clinical implementation. These findings, coupled with integration and interpretation of multi-omic assessments to predict and evaluate response, will address a growing need for translational science that can result in more effective nutrition interventions for this population, and ultimately, advance survivorship care and move the field toward precision health.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Because mammalian reproduction takes place deep inside the body, the cilia function in the fallopian tube is not well understood and open to conjecture, thereby limiting the progress of infertility treatments. Here, we propose the first live dynamic investigation of cilia function in the mouse fallopian tube and the effect of ciliopathy on reproductive function. Our investigation of the role of oviduct cilia during reproduction will fill a significant knowledge gap and likely inform strategies to alleviate fertility defects and ectopic pregnancies in ciliopathy patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Type 1 diabetes (T1D) is a complex disorder, arising from the action of multiple genetic and environmental risk factors. We have identified over seventy T1D risk loci and via fine mapping efforts showed that T1D risk variants mapped to regulatory regions of the genome, especially in immune related tissue. We aim to define the distinct role these risk variants play in initiation and progression of islet autoimmunity in circulating immune cells and identify biomarkers predictive of disease stage (islet autoimmunity and T1D) to guide development of risk prediction models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE More than 891,000 U.S. women have an endometrial cancer history, making it the second largest cancer survivor group among women. Racial disparities have been reported across the endometrial cancer continuum—from recognition of symptoms leading to diagnosis through receipt of guideline recommended cancer therapy and survivorship care. The Carolina Endometrial Cancer Study is a diverse, population-based cancer epidemiology survivor cohort that collects detailed information on novel molecular characteristics; medical history; cancer treatment and follow-up care; individual- and contextual-level social determinants of health; and behavioral and lifestyle factors to advance our understanding of endometrial cancer survivorship.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research on evidence synthesis via cancer-focused data integration is relevant to public health because it is a critical tool for evaluating lung cancer screening strategies and ultimately reducing cancer mortality. As lung cancer screening is implemented in more diverse settings, the applicability of trial findings to nationally representative populations is challenged. This work aligns with NCI’s priority to increase health equity across the cancer continuum because as a result of applying the proposed methods, we will produce high-quality evidence of lung cancer screening strategies for populations traditionally underrepresented in trials.

PHR: NARRATIVE Clinical trials for stroke treatments should include patients who represent all communities, including those from communities who often lack opportunities to participate. The highly successful Wake Forest Stroke Net has grown as a regional network that 1) includes multiple hospitals across the entire state of NC, across the borders of neighboring states, and recently WI and IL; 2) serves diverse race-ethnic, urban, and rural populations, and 3) is committed to improving clinical trial success by connecting with communities to advance stroke care. We have the leadership, experience, and passion to continue to positively impact Stroke Net clinical trials focused on acute stroke treatment, stroke prevention, and stroke rehabilitation and recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cadherin-11, an adhesion molecule, expressed on various cells during the development of tissue fibrosis, is an important mediator of the development of fibrosis and systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) is a potentially devastating disease clinically manifesting as progressive fibrosis of skin and lungs. The current proposal will extend these findings and determine the extent to which cadherin-11 regulates macrophages, type II alveolar epithelial cells and fibroblasts during the development of fibrosis. We will also use cadherin-11 to identify novel mediators of fibrosis and target cells with cadherin-11 targeted nanoparticles to treat lung fibrosis.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JOHN D DINGELL VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative The Nominee's projects involve the study of repetitive mild traumatic brain injury (rmTBI), Gulf War Veterans' Illnesses (GWVI) and substance abuse disorders (SUD). These conditions are chronic, the symptoms worsen over time, they are associated with numerous co-morbid disorders, and there are no effective treatments for them. rmTBI and GWVI are often associated with SUDs, particularly opiate drugs. Opiate abuse represents a significant problem by itself, and can increase the risk of overdose, but it compounds the problems associated with rmTBI and GWVI. It is known that rmTBI, GWVI and SUDs can significantly alter the gut microbiome so it is important to understand if these conditions can be improved by rebalancing the disease-altered gut microbiome. Work on this project will capitalize on prior VA instrument grant support that allowed our lab to acquire automated, high-throughput instrumentation to analyze the gut microbiome. This project is highly relevant to Veterans health and to the VA healthcare mission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative To survive in the nutrient- and oxygen-deprived tumor microenvironment (TME), cancer cells undergo a drastic metabolic reprogramming where they upregulate both their endogenous lipid synthesis and exogenous uptake of lipids. Although this altered lipid metabolism has the potential to serve as a powerful diagnostic approach and research tool in cancer biology, current methods to evaluate lipid profiles are unable to provide single-cell analysis and lack spatial precision. Here, we describe a unique platform for lipid profiling of cancer and cancer- associated cells in intact tissue samples at single-cell level by probing inherent molecular vibrations using spectral coherent anti-Stokes Raman scattering (CARS) microscopy, simultaneously with RNA imaging by stimulated Raman excited fluorescence (SREF).

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Insulin resistance causes metabolic diseases such as type 2 diabetes, heart attacks, strokes and liver failure– diseases that disproportionately affect veterans as compared to the general US population. Using genetic and genomic data from veterans treated for insulin resistance, this project aims to identify new human insulin resistance genes and prove through nature’s own clinical trials that they would make good targets for therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Colorectal cancer is one of the major causes of all cancer related deaths and a critical challenge in colorectal cancer outcome is lack of therapies designed to combat metastatic disease. Diet and obesity are among the major lifestyle choices that can affect colorectal cancer risk, however not much is known about how pro-obesity diets can affect cancer metastasis. This proposal investigates the molecular mechanisms underlying how pro- obesity high fat diets impact colorectal cancer metastasis, revealing therapeutic vulnerabilities and enabling evidence-based effective dietary recommendations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this research is to understand the role of lung afferents in controlling eupneic breathing, and how the breathing network reconfigures to generate gasping and arousal. This basic science research is translational and will provide important insights into breathing disorders associated with autonomic dysregulation and the failure to arouse in response to hypoxia. The research will also test a concept how breathing controls emotions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 10 million individuals in the United States are opioid tolerant due to current or prior opioid exposure, which is correlated with poor outcomes and greater health risks during surgical care, but current strategies to optimize postoperative pain management and ensure safe opioid prescribing focus primarily on patients who lack exposure to opioids. In this prospective study, we will examine the perioperative experiences of patients with preoperative opioid tolerance following surgery in order to create and test a clinical care pathway to reduce high-risk prescribing practices, readmissions, and length of stay, and enhance patient-reported outcomes including pain. These findings will provide the necessary evidence to guide appropriate opioid prescribing during surgical care and optimize surgical recovery for patients with opioid tolerance.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to help us better understand how individual differences in our genes can affect some of the most commonly prescribed hormone-containing medications, combined oral contraceptive pills. Individual genetic differences may place some women at higher risk of contraceptive failure while using combined oral contraceptive pills, while other genetic differences could increase the risk of bothersome side effects that lead to early contraceptive discontinuation and higher risk of unintended pregnancies. The results of this project will help us incorporate precision and personalized medicine into individualized counseling for hormonal contraception based on individual genetic differences, leading to patients making more informed decisions about their use of hormone-containing medications.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Stroke is the 5th leading cause of mortality in the US and the leading cause of adult disability and thus constitutes a major public health burden. Utah Stroke Net is one of 27 Regional Coordinating Centers that form the national NIH-sponsored Stroke Trials Network (Stroke Net). Utah Stroke Net aims to assist in development, promotion, and provision of the highest quality clinical stroke trials in stroke prevention, treatment, and recovery to patients across the Mountain West, whether urban, rural, or frontier.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Both germline and somatic alterations contribute to the development of kidney cancer, though how these processes biologically converge to promote oncogenesis and evolution is incompletely understood. Through integrative and hypothesis-driven computational, functional, and clinical approaches, we will dissect related germline and somatic events in kidney cancer to yield novel and translatable discoveries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Multi-cancer detection tests are becoming commercially available, yet little is known about their feasibility, acceptability, and effectiveness for cancer screening in practice. This application is to establish an Accrual, Enrollment, and Screening Site Hub embedded across 21 medical centers in urban, suburban, and semi-rural populations within a large and diverse integrated health care system with comprehensive data capture. This setting, with a proven ability for effective recruitment in large cancer screening trials, will support efforts of the National Cancer Institute’s Cancer Screening Research Network to evaluate early cancer detection tests within diverse populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) is FDA cleared for treating depression that does not respond to antidepressant medication. Despite being a brain-based treatment, there is a gulf between knowledge from the brain imaging literature and how rTMS treatment is generally applied. We seek with this project to support a link between TMS evoked brain responses recorded during interleaved TMS/fMRI sessions and depression improvement to rTMS treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Individuals born prematurely are at increased risk for asthma, the origins of which can be traced back to factors set at and even prior to the time of birth. Better understanding these influences may lead to opportunities for earlier diagnosis, improved treatment, or even prevention of asthma. The proposed research will address previously uncharacterized role of placental gene regulation and expression, and how that interacts with biological sex in leading to the onset of asthma during childhood among a cohort of children born extremely preterm.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Multi-cancer detection assays offer new opportunities to screen for many different cancers that currently have limited options for early detection; the Cancer Screening Research Network (CSRN) will conduct definitive clinical trials and studies to evaluate these assays. We bring together statistical leaders and database systems experts with experience in major clinical trials networks who have expertly designed, implemented, analyzed, and reported cancer screening, prevention, and treatment trials and studies, in collaboration with clinicians, scientists, patient advocates and other experts. The Statistics and Data Management Center (SDMC) of the CSRN will offer a rigorous system for CSRN trial design, management and analysis so that the information generated by CSRN trials forms a sound basis for national cancer screening policy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An deficit in understanding of the molecular events that contribute to the development of age-related macular degeneration represents an obstacle to the design and implementation of therapeutics that more fully address its molecular pathogenesis. The present application will identify a novel mechanism that contributes to the failed antioxidant and inflammatory responses in retinal pigment epithelium with aging. These findings are expected to provide new targets for intervention and lead to the development of innovative therapies that target a leading cause of blindness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anemia, the most common blood disease that affects over 1.6 billion people worldwide, currently requires a clinic or hospital-based blood count for diagnosis. We have recently developed a novel, multi-faceted anemia screening and monitoring suite of products comprising 3 key products for home testing: 1) AnemoCheck Home test kit (under FDA interactive review)– a “single drop of blood” fingerstick test that utilizes our clinical FDA- cleared technology to elicit a color change that correlates with degree of anemia, 2) AnemoCheck app – a smartphone app that screens for anemia using only smartphone photos and the phone itself with no additional equipment and 3) AnemoCheck MyMobile– a marriage of the AnemoCheck Home test kit and AnemoCheck app products in which the app is “personalized” for each patient to significantly improve accuracy and enable self-monitoring of anemia. In this proposal, we aim to expand upon testing in Phase II answering to a request for additional data from FDA to 1) conduct human factors validation 2) implement quality control features and changes in workflow informed by human factors and 3) characterize the performance of AnemoCheck MyMobile head to head against comparator, reference method and when trained with AnemoCheck Home (versus a traditional blood test to train AnemoCheck MyMobile, versus traditional blood testing) for chronic anemia management to expand our use and allow for a completely home-based access to cost-effectively empower patients to manage their own care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Summary Influenza virus epidemics result in severe illness, hospitalizations, and deaths, especially among elderly people. To better understand aging related mechanisms in host defense to respiratory viral infection, we will use cutting- edge technology to decipher cellular locations and cell-cell interactions amongst heterogeneous cells in the lung, which enables a broad overview of interactions among various immune, endothelial, and epithelial cells. We anticipate that our project will identify potential targets for the development of new therapeutic strategies to prevent and treat severe flu symptoms in elderly people.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Recent FDA-approval of new irreversible inhibitors for cancer therapy has renewed interest in drugs which exert their influence via covalent modification of protein targets. However, our inability to accurately assess the full repertoire on- and off-target proteins bound by covalent inhibitors, as well as the inhibitor occupancy of any given target, represent major obstacles to the expansion of covalent drug programs. Herein we develop a new modular platform to rapidly synthesize and test chemical tools for target discovery and target occupancy with the ultimate goal of accelerating development of new covalent inhibitors.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stroke is a devastating disease and a major public health burden in the US and worldwide. Evidence-based medical practice depends on rigorous scientific methods conducted in multi-center clinical trials. Funding for NIH Stroke Net Regional Coordinating Stroke Centers (PAR-17-276) provides a mechanism for developing, promoting, and conducting high-quality, multi-site clinical trials focused on key interventions in stroke prevention, treatment, and recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Smoking is a significant public health problem that results in over 480,000 premature deaths in the US each year. While many smokers attempt to quit annually, most relapse to smoking within a year, meaning that there is a critical need for better treatments. The objective of this proposal is to estimate the effects of different medication treatment strategies used for both initial smoking cessation and for "rescue therapy" among those who fail to quit or relapse to smoking, which may lead to more personalized smoking cessation treatments.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Randomized controlled trials evaluating presumptive treatment with a broad-spectrum antibiotic among children with uncomplicated severe acute malnutrition (SAM) have found conflicting results, and thus the role of antibiotics in the management of uncomplicated SAM in children without clinical signs of infection is unclear. Here we propose a large-scale individually randomized controlled trial to determine whether azithromycin, which has recently been shown to reduce all-cause mortality in children aged 1-59 months, is superior to amoxicillin or placebo in children with SAM. We anticipate that the results of this study will provide definitive evidence of the role of antibiotics (including both azithromycin and amoxicillin) in the management of uncomplicated SAM and provide additional insight into whether presumptive antibiotic therapy is helpful for recovery in these children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Huntington's disease (HD) is caused by a CAG repeat expansion in the huntingtin (HTT) gene, leading to the pathogenic expansion of a polyglutamine tract in the huntingtin protein. We recently discovered that mutant HTT interacts with NLRP3 protein and activates the NLRP3-imflammasome in HD mouse and human brain tissues, suggesting a role for specific neuroinflammasome pathways in HD pathogenesis. We will investigate these pathways, which may provide novel targets for development of disease-modifying therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Only 15-25% patients with lung cancer respond to immunotherapy while more than two thirds of patients experience its side effects. Exercise training yields various physiological changes that can help improve immune function and has the great potential to improve immunotherapy outcomes and reduce its side effects. This multi- level clinical research will explore the mechanisms and efficacy of exercise on immune function and treatment- related outcomes and side effects in patients with lung cancer receiving immunotherapy, which will provide insights of the roles of exercise in immuno-oncology settings and ultimately to improve long-term cancer survivorship in this patient population who are vulnerable yet understudied.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: MICHAEL E DEBAKEY VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Head and neck cancer (HNC) survival among Veterans is low (<65% alive at 5 years post diagnosis) in large part because of the high rate of tobacco exposure that suppressive anti-tumor immunity and reduces treatment response. We hypothesize that adaptation designed to allow HNC tumors to survive oxidative stress de-activates immune cells and prevents them from killing tumor cells. By understanding the mechanisms which support this adaptation we can better risk stratify Veterans with HNC and develop new therapeutic strategies for this deadly disease and other smoking associated malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Millions of people suffer from a communication deficit that impairs speech perception. This research proposal investigates how the human brain integrates across time-varying structures such as phonemes and words, which have highly variable durations. Understanding dynamic temporal integration is critical to understanding the neural mechanisms that allow people to perceive speech and their impairments in communication deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will determine the role of prolonged enterovirus infections in triggering the development of autoantibody responses to islet autoantigen targets and the development of Type 1 Diabetes in children under the age of six. We will find additional children within the TEDDY study with prolonged virus infections, analyze antibody responses to enterovirus in plasma samples, we will deeply characterize the global and EV-specific immune response in the PBMCs of these children using single cell gene expression analyses. This study will clarify our knowledge of exactly which virus(es) can trigger the development of IA and T1D disease, when that may occur in early childhood, and provide insights into the mechanisms involved, links to key genetic variants in the children and can lead to preventative strategies in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stroke is a major public health problem in the United States, where it is the 5th leading cause of death and the leading cause of adult disability. Indeed, there is great need to develop interventions that prevent, treat, or enhance recovery after stroke. We have been honored to be a part of the first cycle within Stroke Net, having successfully grown the Mid-America Regional Coordinating Center (MARCC) at Washington University to include six high-volume tertiary care Stroke Centers spanning MO, KS, IL, TN, MS and AR. We look forward to expanding our network and patient enrollment further in the next Stroke Net cycle to continue to meet the joint goals of this network.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The National Cancer Institute (NCI) is creating a Cancer Screening Research Network (CSRN) to conduct national randomized controlled trials and longitudinal studies to evaluate new technologies for cancer screening and close critical evidence gaps. To assist in this effort, we propose to create the Virginia CSRN Accrual, Enrollment, and Screening Sites (ACCESS) Hub from long-standing inter-institutional partnerships between three health system, two medical schools, two cancer centers including an NCI-designated comprehensive cancer center, an NIH-funded clinical and translational science center, and a 500+-practice primary care practice-based research network. The Virginia CSRN ACCESS Hub will participate in the proposed Vanguard study – a randomized controlled trial of multi-cancer detection tests – and demonstrate its distinct ability to recruit and retain inclusive and diverse participants onto national cancer screening trials and evaluate factors necessary to broadly disseminate and implement new cancer screening practices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer is a major worldwide health concern where delays in the diagnosis and treatment of cancer lead to increased mortality. The proposed project will enable large-scale artificial intelligence studies using radiomics, deep learning, and physics-based generative modeling in nuclear medicine imaging for the automatic characterization of malignant diseases. The developed approach will be generalizable across a range of cancer types and will help improve patient outcomes by facilitating the early detection, diagnosis, prognosis, and treatment of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will combine tissue clearing, two photon microscopy, and multiview imaging to develop new and quantitative tools for investigating animal models of musculoskeletal injuries. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Stroke remains the 5th leading cause of death in the United States (US) and a leading cause of adult disability. In the past decade, there have been tremendous strides in discovery of beneficial approaches to treat and prevent stroke, aided in part by conduct of large-scale clinical trials in StrokeNet. Leveraging our prior contributions to trial enrollment, proposal development, and trainee education, our renewal application as a regional coordinating center (RCC) in StrokeNet seeks to provide continued access to a diverse stroke patient population, consolidated multidisciplinary and multi-institutional expertise and leadership for StrokeNet trials, and ensure mentoring for trainees and junior faculty seeking academic careers in stroke. These efforts will identify new stroke treatments that reduce death and disability from stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Social behavior deficits are key features of many neuropsychiatric disorders, yet little is known about how the brain controls normal social behaviors. We propose to create a new artificial intelligence framework for social behavioral quantification that integrates diverse sources of behavior data to quantify spatiotemporal signatures or “motifs” of social behaviors. The easy-to-use toolkit which we call the Social Motif generator (So-Mo) will enable future studies to probe neural circuits during complex mouse behaviors at unprecedented resolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT SUMMARY Our objective is to prevent degeneration of the tendon and enthesis following injury by leveraging the physiological processes associated with hypoxic cell survival and extracellular matrix production that are critical for tendon and enthesis development. In this project, we will determine the mechanisms of HIF1-alpha and hypoxia-dependent cell behavior of tendon and enthesis progenitor cells and their potential to modify extracellular matrix deposition using innovated and parallel approaches of in vivo murine models (for investigating cell autonomous and non-autonomous responses to hypoxia and HIF during development and healing) and in vitro synthetic biomaterials (for visualization of nascent protein deposition). The completion of this study will establish the role of Hif1a and hypoxia in maintaining, establishing, and protecting tendon and enthesis progenitors during development and healing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Skeletal muscle stem cells and endothelial cells are key cell compartments responsible for proper muscle regeneration, vascularization and plasticity during physiologic or pathologic conditions such as exercise and growth or disorders such as dystrophies or injuries. Here we propose to study the interaction between these two cell types derived from human induced pluripotent stem cells, which are one of the top stem cell sources for cell therapy in case of skeletal muscle disorders. These studies allow identification of the involved molecular mechanisms of the cross-talks between skeletal muscle stem cells and endothelial cells, as well as their combined therapeutic efficiency in mouse models for muscular dystrophy or muscle injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Assessment of treatment response for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is often difficult and inaccurate due to treatment-related non-specific changes on imaging tests. Recently, our team has successfully developed an HCC EV Digital Scoring Assay to detect early-stage HCC and measure the tumor burden. This study aims to conduct a revision application of HCC EV Digital Scoring Assay for evaluation of HCC treatment response, which may provide an accurate assessment and prevent frequent imaging tests.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: LAY NARRATIVE  Obstructive sleep apnea is a common disorder and there is evidence that there are differences between patients with this disorder that are not explained by traditional measures of disease severity. Clinical subtypes based on patient-reported symptoms have been identified and validated. This project uses existing data to determine how objective measures of sleepiness, sleep duration, and sleep quality differ among these subtypes, as well as how subtypes based on subjective and/or objective data differ in cognition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The Stroke Central Atlantic Network for Research encompasses the Mid-Atlantic region. As a Regional Coordinating Center (RCC), it will continue recruiting people with stroke for trials ranging from prevention to acute intervention to rehabilitation. The unusual features of this RCC are its capture of nearly all stroke patients in DC and much of the Mid-Atlantic, its ability to recruit underserved individuals from both urban and rural settings, and its research strengths in multimodal MRI, genetics, Neurorehabilitation, and disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The proteome is the entirety of all proteins in a cell, tissue, or body fluid. It constitutes the functional and structural backbone of biological systems and is the closest molecular link to the system’s phenotype. However, unbiased proteome mapping (proteomics) is still underused in our attempts to understand diseases, and it is largely untapped in clinical studies. A major reason for this is a lack of sample throughput when compared to genomics technologies. We propose to address this issue by building on the enormous recent progress in artificial intelligence (AI) to develop a novel mass spectrometry-based approach for analyzing proteomes. This allows for increasing the sample throughput by up to 10-fold over existing methods. We will evaluate the method by mapping blood plasma biomarkers for lung cancer detection in 500 clinical plasma samples.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPR) is a commonly performed procedure (more than 15,000 children in US alone) to resuscitate a stopped heart and the conventional procedure is not very effective especially for pediatric patients since less than 50% survive to discharge. The proposed research will use already collected data and develop a computational model to identify patients who are unlikely to survive with conventional CPR and can beneﬁt from a special procedure called ECPR that has been known to improve survival under certain circum- stances. The proposed research will provide a systematic and mathematically sound procedure to pick ECPR candidates and is expected to result in substantial improvement of survival rates for pediatric populations.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Glaucoma is the leading cause of irreversible blindness worldwide, and Veterans have twice the prevalence of glaucoma compared to the general US population. Overall, women represent 59% of the affected population; however, the number of women Veterans have doubled over the last ten years. Studies have recently demonstrated that early menopause, which corresponds with a decrease in circulating estrogen, mutations in estrogen receptors, and polymorphisms along the estrogen metabolic pathway are linked to developing glaucoma. Therefore, we must better understand whether menopause directly affects developing glaucoma in women. In this proposal, our goal is to perform a retrospective analysis using the national VA database (VINCI) to assess if menopause is related to the onset of glaucoma in a Veteran population. In addition, we will determine if hormone replacement therapy (HRT) delays the onset of glaucoma in postmenopausal women. This study will identify how menopause is associated with glaucoma and the potential of HRT as a novel treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sensitive, inexpensive, and rapid genetic sequencing is changing how people interact with and study everything involving living organisms (e.g., medicine, public health, agriculture, biotechnology, natural resources, etc.) by making enormous quantities of sequence data easily available. We are developing and using methods that exploit voluminous protein sequence data to help design biochemical experiments that yield results broadly applicable beyond the specific example tested. Our work may allow prediction of the information processing capabilities of microorganisms and may influence design of therapeutic agents to disable regulatory systems that control virulence, viability, or drug susceptibility of microbial pathogens.

PHR: NARRATIVE Approximately 28% of guide extension catheters fail to achieve successful treatment in patients undergoing complex percutaneous coronary intervention due to inability to access, and deliver stents to calcified lesions in tortuous vessels. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clinical decision support tools for oropharyngeal cancer (OPC) using diagnostic imaging and clinical data have the potential to improve metastatic cervical lymph node auto-segmentation and extracapsular nodal extension detection, which could subsequently guide actionable treatment planning for improved efficacy with minimal side effects. We propose novel probabilistic deep learning methods that can simultaneously detect, segment, and classify of metastatic lymph nodes using pretreatment multi-modality imaging and clinical data with patient- specific probabilistic estimation of segmentation and classification accuracy. These advancements would improve public health by enhancing the accuracy of the risk stratification of OPC patients for appropriate treatments, ultimately improving treatment outcomes and quality of life of OPC survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human communication evolved in a social context. Its natural ecology is face-to-face dyadic conversation, which entails mirroring of facial expression/gaze and spoken language, and rhythms in turn-taking. In this planning grant we convene a diverse multidisciplinary team, including ethicists, to develop and validate a tool for quantification of dyadic communication behavior across modalities, sensitive to temporal patterns, and computational frameworks for analysis. The tool will be both in-person and via remote platform.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The genome is stable in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) compared to other myeloid malignancies, permitting long-term successful treatment with tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs). However, with progression to blast crisis (BC), genomic instability increases. Also, ~50% of CML patients develop mutations in the CML-specific BCRABL oncogene that lead to TKI-resistance. We found aberrant activation of the innate immune response in human subjects and a murine model of CML. We also found enhanced reactive oxygen species production with efficient detoxification in CML until TKI-resistance or BC develop. The first goal of these studies is to determine the role of immune dysregulation in disease progression in CML. 50% of CML patients with a sustained, major molecular response to TKIs remain in remission after stopping these agents. Current clinical tools do not define who will relapse, but we found that interaction of CML cells with αβT cells predicted relapse after TKI-discontinuation. Our second goal is to determine if this interaction enhances leukemia cell persistence during TKI-treatment.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Life expectancy is increasing worldwide and is expected to hit 90 years by 2030. Sarcopenia (the age-related loss of muscle mass and function), is associated with a high risk of morbidity-disability, decreased quality of life, increased burden of treatment and caregiving, and increased mortality. No medication is currently available to treat sarcopenia. Therefore, there is a substantial unmet clinical need for effective treatments of sarcopenia. Fortunately, we have identified a Chromogranin A peptide called Catestatin, which improved grip strength in older mice. In addition, we have identified a Catestatin mimetic small molecule pharmacophore TKO-10-18 that works in a similar fashion as Catestatin. The results obtained in older mice studies can then be translated to humans where these compounds can promote healthy rehabilitation by increasing grip strength and the resultant improvement in muscle function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Here we seek to use mechanistic insights to develop a novel RNA-based approach targeting regulatory T cells as a potential therapy for acute myocarditis. We will investigate the mechanisms whereby a long noncoding RNA, BCYRN1, increases the proliferation, migration and activation of human regulatory T cells. Studies in a mouse model of virally-induced myocarditis will test whether BCYRN1, or shorter synthetic derivatives, will abbreviate the disease course, and/or decrease the severity, of acute myocarditis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE The changing demographics of Western societies include an aging population with a near epidemic of obesity, insulin resistance, and diabetes mellitus, causing a dramatic rise in the prevalence of peripheral artery disease (PAD) and its worst form, critical limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI), which impairs the ability to walk, causes pain, nonhealing ulcers and gangrene, and can lead to major amputations in the lower extremities. Among individuals most severely affected, revascularization of the lower extremities to restore circulation is the most effective therapy; however, to date, there has been no effective pharmaceutical strategy to reduce the incidence of restenosis due to intimal hyperplasia in below-the-knee (BTK) peripheral arteries. Therefore, the relevance of this proposal lies in its potential to improve patency of lower extremity interventions, reduce morbidity, and reduce the significant financial burden currently associated with the treatment of PAD and CLTI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE 683,000 women are sexually assaulted annually in the United States, half of whom develop chronic posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and thus have markedly increased risk for cannabis use disorder (CUD). The current proposal will test the acceptability, initial efficacy, and mechanisms underlying a novel digital therapeutic targeting risk for PTSD-CUD, which could address the critical need for PTSD-CUD prevention for the 100,000 women who annually present for emergency care after sexual assault. In this research context, the applicant will receive key training in multisite, emergency-care based RCTs, advanced statistical analyses for RCTs and ecological momentary assessment data, biobehavioral mechanisms underlying PTSD-CUD prevention, and professional development, launching her independent research career focused on reducing the public health burden of PTSD-CUD among sexual assault survivors by leveraging digital therapeutics.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: HARRY S. TRUMAN MEMORIAL VA HOSPITAL
PHR: Project Narrative Blast-induced mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI) can cause long-term disabilities in service personnel exposed to blast in combat or during military training. These disabilities impose socioeconomic burdens on patients, families, and society. Using an established, highly reproducible open-field blast mouse model, our studies demonstrated ability for the high-energy blast waves to rupture membranes and intracellular components in the brain tissue. This project is aimed at investigating mechanism(s) of the signature ‘invisible injury’ sustained in affected service personnel. Using a transgenic mouse model expressing human tau, studies will further examine the role of tau on key linkages between low-level blast exposure(s) and underlying ultrastructural damage as well as molecular changes reflecting oxidative stress and mitochondrial dysfunction. Understanding of the pathogenesis of mTBI-induced cognitive deficits due to blast will advance opportunities for preventative and treatment strategies.

PHR: The current treatment for brain tumors is often not effective and causes substantial side-effects. Molecular profiling of these tumors in recent years has uncovered genetic alterations which may render them sensitive to drugs targeting these alterations. The goal of our research program is to determine how to exploit these potential vulnerabilities with new drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exercise offers great potential as a first-line, formally prescribed intervention for anxiety disorders, but research is needed to improve exercise engagement, establish the optimal titration for exercise prescriptions, and identify which mechanisms to target to optimize outcomes in practice. This Career Development Award project examines a novel exercise titration method as compared to low intensity exercise with objective assessment of heart rate based intensity goals (as target engagement), assessment of real-time changes in mood following exercise (through ecological momentary assessment), neuroeconomic assessment of exercise decision-making, and their association with anxiety and adherence outcomes in sedentary individuals with a primary anxiety disorder and moderate to high anxiety sensitivity. Findings will inform optimal exercise titration methods as well as identify potential mechanisms to support the development of personalized approaches to prescribing exercise as an evidence-based intervention for anxiety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Apache-JHU Bright Horizons study will conduct qualitative research in collaboration with a Community Advisory Board to design and evaluate the impact of a brief alcohol use intervention for adolescents who have engaged in recent severe drinking through a randomized controlled trial. The intervention will be delivered by Apache Community Mental Health Specialists to address cultural and logistical barriers to care and build local capacity in alcohol use interventions and research methods. This study will address critical public health needs—the rise of severe alcohol use nationally, the prevalence of polysubstance use, and the impact of the current COVID pandemic on alcohol and drug use—by targeting risk and protective factors identified through previous community-driven research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the Southwest United States, the American Indian population is disproportionately affected by morbidity and mortality related to Staphylococcus aureus infections. Existing strategies have not been sufficient to control S. aureus disease and new approaches are urgently needed. This proposal will address this public health need by designing and evaluating a community-informed approach to education and decolonization to prevent S. aureus disease among high-risk individuals that could be adapted and replicated in other American Indian populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE MYODL122R mutated rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS) are a particularly aggressive pediatric muscle cancer that has an extremely poor prognosis, even despite multi-modal treatment with surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy. Here, we will identify the molecular programs underlying these aggressive RMS, including those that modulate cancer stem cell function, cell state, and therapy resistance. This work will define new pathways and therapeutic targets to kill MYOD1L122R mutant RMS that are likely shared across RMS subtypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Suicide in LGBTQ young adults has reached a crisis level, but our ability to predict and prevent suicide has not improved in 50 years. We will use brain imaging, actigraphy, and smartphone technology to measure critical social precipitants of suicidality and their interaction with general risk factors. With machine learning, a technique based on artificial intelligence, we will combine these sources of data to determine the way suicidal thoughts and behaviors develop over hours, days, and months.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative At the intracellular level, life's events unfold at spatiotemporal scales whose direct observation presents pro- found challenges to ﬂuorescence-based imaging and spectroscopic methods. To unravel life's events at the single molecule level, current methods exploit specialized hardware, long data acquisition periods, and other techniques thereby stressing sensitive samples with light and often compromising either spatial or temporal resolution altogether. Here, instead, we propose novel mathematical tools to resolve biological events with minimal spatiotemporal compromise often using orders of magnitude less data on our way toward capturing reaction-diffusion of single interacting molecules from just thousands of recorded photons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We identified a novel candidate driver of cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC), a disease that disfigures one million and kills thousands of people annually. Preliminary results indicate that this candidate regulates the expression of extracellular matrix genes and DNA repair pathways, which are critical both for maintaining epidermal homeostasis and for cancer progression. This proposal will define the regulatory mechanism in normal epidermis and determine how mutation alters cSCC progression.

PHR: Fragile X-Associated Tremor/Ataxia Syndrome (FXTAS) is a progressive degenerative disease of the brain that results from a repeat expansion mutation that triggers production of a toxic protein. We will explore how this toxic protein is made, how its production contributes to FXTAS relevant symptoms in model systems and how we might block its production. Our long term goal is to leverage these findings to develop novel therapies for FXTAS patients and patients with other repeat expansions that cause neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Atherosclerosis is an inflammatory/metabolic disease in which cells of the artery wall remodel to form a plaque that can narrow vessel lumens or rupture and block blood flow. This grant aims to understand the changes in endothelial cell fate that govern vessel remodeling and the pathways by which these changes promote disease. We will identify spatial and gene expression characteristics of susceptible EC subpopulations that mediate these transitions and elucidate the cellular positive feedback loops that mediate disease progression.
