IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Stem cells in the bone marrow produce all blood cells over the lifetime of an individual. We can, however, not maintain these cells in vitro, which would have major applications for the treatment of genetic and malignant blood diseases. The goal of this proposal is further study the specific cell biology of these cells and, using these findings, develop a novel strategy to maintain and expand blood stem cells in vitro.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Early exposure to research is a key component to increasing the number of physician-scientists. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE The identification of genetic factors that influence the size and shape of typical human facial features can provide important insights into the biological mechanisms that contribute to both normal and atypical facial development. The current proposal seeks to expand our knowledgebase by leveraging existing datasets to map genomic regions associated with human facial morphology, delineate functional variants at implicated loci with high-throughput experimental screening tools, and identify variants across the genome that impact clinically-relevant aspects of facial growth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Structural plasticity of neurons in the brain can rewire circuits during development, in response to experiences, injury, diseases, and aging, and is crucial for brain function and health. Our knowledge of the genes and mechanisms regulating structural plasticity between development, adulthood, and in aging is limited, in part due to technical barriers in studying this complex process in mammalian brains. We propose use of a robust model of experience-dependent structural plasticity in C. elegans to identify conserved genes and molecular mechanisms that regulate structural plasticity across the lifespan, which will provide fundamental knowledge about this understudied form of plasticity and potentially uncover novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Cerebellar injury is a frequent complication of pre-term birth and can lead to reduced cerebellar size and contribute to long-term neurodevelopmental problems, including in motor, cognitive, social and language development. We recently found that the newborn mouse cerebellum has remarkable regeneration potential, as it can recover from the loss of three cell types. Our model systems therefore represent a powerful system to uncover the cellular responses and molecular mechanism required during brain regeneration as a basis for developing strategies to enhance repair of cerebellar injuries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the importance of math skills in daily life tasks and the role of mathematics as a symbolic communication system, relatively little is known about the neural correlates of math or its interaction with language processing in the brain. The proposed research will explore this relationship by utilizing the lesion method and converging with a functional dataset, which will inform cognitive models of how numeracy abilities are organized in the brain and linked to language areas during both functional and disordered performance. This novel work investigating the neural correlates of numeracy through the lens of known language areas and pathways will shed light on math abilities, particularly as they relate to language, and will improve understanding of the consequences of related disorders, such as the frequently co-morbid aphasia and acalculia following stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE We will develop new types of fluorescent proteins, reporters and optogenetic tools for imaging, detection and light-regulation of molecular processes and interactions in mammalian cells, tissues and model animals. These probes will emit or be activated in the near-infrared spectral range where tissue transparency is the highest and will use the heme-derived compound biliverdin, naturally available in mammalian tissues, as the chromophore. The planned genetically encoded near-infrared optical probes will allow non-invasive visualization, sensing and light-control of the biochemistry and physiology of cells, organs and whole organisms in normal and pathological conditions, as well as spectral multiplexing with optical reagents of the visible range.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Cellular crosstalk is a process through a message transmitted between cells. Intercellular crosstalk of hepatocytes and non-parenchymal cells (i.e. Mφ and LSEC) is crucial for the maintenance of liver homeostasis. Under the pathological condition, hepatocyte damage results in the activation of fibrotic Mφ and LSEC. Thereby these cells play a critical role in the control of hepatic inflammation and the development of liver fibrosis. Exosomes are small membrane-bound extracellular vesicles and serve as natural carriers of signaling molecules such as cytokines for prompting cellular crosstalk. This project will identify a major cellular and molecular mechanism for the role of exosomes released from HCV-infected hepatocytes in promoting intercellular communication with non-parenchymal cells (i.e. Mφ and LSEC), leading to the development of liver fibrosis. The findings from our proposed research will provide a rationale basis of novel immunotherapeutic strategies that target molecules inducing pro-fibrotic factors through HCV-derived exosomes.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-human primate (NHP) models of human genetic diseases provide valuable platforms for testing the safety and efficacy of novel strategies to prevent, delay, or reverse disease pathophysiology. Although numerous such models have been identified, multiple challenges, including the long-term availability of carriers with particular mutations, threaten both the propagation and availability of these models to investigators. The goal of this project is to develop a National embryos, to NHP Model Embryo Resource (NNMER) to help investigators cryopreserve gametes, and fibroblasts from NHP models of human disease and which will provide investigators with access these valuable disease models for studies of disease pathogenesis and to test the safety and efficacy of novel therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Most patients diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia (AML), a lethal blood and bone marrow cancer, must face disease recurrence (or relapse), which emerges due to development of chemoresistance. This proposal seeks to leverage drugs that target the anti-apoptotic pathway using functional biological tools to prevent and treat relapse. This work will provide a deeper understanding of pathways that are essential to the development of chemoresistance and reveal novel therapeutic opportunities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diversity in science and research is important in meeting the health needs of the nation. The long-term goal of this proposal is to maintain a sustainable biomedical and behavioral research training program that will more than double the number of underrepresented (UR) students graduating with a STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Math) degree and pursuing a Ph.D. in biomedical or behavioral research. This goal will be achieved by providing UR students an increased awareness of graduate research, by better preparing UR students to enter Ph.D. granting programs, and by graduating and enrolling more UR students in Ph.D. granting programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Studies of reinforcement learning over the past two decades have shown that the brain possesses multiple decision systems, including an inferential or “model-based” system that utilizes an internal model for planning, and a retrospective or “model-free” system that repeats reinforced actions. This proposal seeks to determine the connectivity patterns and dynamics of local and long-range synaptic inputs that arbitrate between these decision- making systems. A greater mechanistic understanding of arbitration holds promise for developing novel therapies for disorders in which arbitration is thought to go awry, such as obsessive-compulsive disorder, which is thought to reflect a predominance of the model-free system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Charting mental illness trajectories to determine when, where, and how to intervene is a key  objective of the NIMH mission to transform the understanding and treatment of mental illness. This  project will: (1) deepen our understanding of the trajectory leading to hospitalization discharge  with knowledge about behavioral biomarkers and their relationship to symptoms and  discharge-readiness; (2) contribute to the knowledge on how social context impacts patient's  behaviors since some symptoms or predictive biomarkers may only be seen in a specific context such  as social or solitary interactions; and (3) contribute a credible, objective framework for  behavioral measurement by defining interpretable biomarkers and latent factors for symptoms and  discharge assessment. The project will also enable a judicious use of remote sensing and non-direct  clinical encounters (e.g., telemedicine), which are increasingly viewed as essential capabilities  in the medical fields to reduce costs while maintaining or elevating care standards.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Single important nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), the most common type of human genetic variants, play roles in shaping complex human traits and causing diseases, andadvancements in high-throughput technologies have enabled researchers to generate multiple types of omics data used in the identification and analyses of these SNPs. Our group constructed a series of data portals for molQTLs, including data portals for expression QTLs (eQTLs), methylation QTLs (meQTLs), and splicing QTLs (sQTLs) based on a large number of patient samples, and these related data resources have been broadly accessed since their releases. The goal of this proposal is to enhance, expand, and promote our existing data resources that will bridge the genetic variants and different molecular features through molQTL analysis, providing a unique data resource for understanding the functional effects of genetic variants and facilitating access to and understanding of complex datasets for non-expert users.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: NARRATIVE Advanced prostate cancer remains an incurable disease that often colonizes the skeleton, causing bone destruction and pain. Drugs used to mitigate bone destruction can induce changes in bone metastatic prostate cancer cells that, in turn, attract and activate specific immune cells (γδ T cells). Based on this observation, we propose to study 1) how prostate cancer cells and bone microenvironmental cells namely, mesenchymal stromal cells (MSCs), affect the activity of γδ T cells; 2) how γδ T cells can be manipulated to make them more effective cancer killers by introducing cancer-specific chimeric antigen receptors; and 3) how γδ T cells modify the bone microenvironment response; with the long-term goal of developing novel and more effective immunotherapies for prostate cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Relevance  This project is relevant to public health because it has a high likelihood of finding new, or improving current, asthma medications. Furthermore, the results could alter our understanding of beta-2-adrenergic receptor function in asthma at a paradigm-shifting level. Finally, the signaling pathways and ligands we reveal in this project could be highly applicable to drug discovery for many other diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: In a subset of diseases called myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPN), mutations of a protein called calreticulin cause abnormalities in bone marrow cells and aberrant production of platelets from their precursor cells. Mechanistically, the mutations affect calcium handling by cells, induce aberrant interaction with a growth factor receptor to amplify cell proliferation, and also negatively influence key immune system processes to help abnormal cells evade the immune response. Understanding these processes could elucidate new pathways to combat MPN, and thus the proposed research contributes to the mission of the NIH relating to advancement of fundamental knowledge to reduce the burden of human disease and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Decompensated HF is the leading cause of hospitalization. HF leads to water accumulation in the tissues (lungs and legs) resulting in shortness of breath and leg swelling. This project will advance the development of an accurate, inexpensive, easy to use device (“NIVAHF”) for volume measurements in patients with HF. Use of these devices will ultimately help health care providers and patients prevent water overload. The long-term goal is to prevent costly hospital readmissions, improve quality of life, and reduce mortality in patients with HF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Incidentalomas may indicate significant health problems, such as malignancy to the patient in the short or medium term, but also may lead to overtreatment, which comes with substantial downstream expenditures as well as patient anxiety. In this project, we will build natural language processing approaches to extract cancer related incidentalomas reported in radiology reports (Aim 1) and create the first large scale incidentaloma database for half-a-million patients who received radiologic imaging tests in University of Washington Medical Center, Harborview Medical Center, Seattle Cancer Care Alliance, and Northwest Hospital and Medical Center between 2007 and 2019 (Aim 2). This database will be used for clinical and economic analysis of incidentalomas (Aim 3).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative To stem the epidemics of substance abuse and sexual risk factors related to health disparities among American Indian and Alaska Native (AIAN) youth, this collaborative partnership between a Native school, an AIAN organization, and a university team of Native researchers will focus on the development of sustainable health practices and youth leadership development. Targeting at-risk AIAN youth for primary prevention efforts and enlisting them to become positive youth development health leaders may stimulate important individual and community-wide changes. Better information is needed on cost-effective and culturally-grounded methods to prevent substance use as well as sexual risk reduction results among AIAN youth so that current and future generations of Native communities can thrive and live healthfully.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Therapeutic application of CRISPR/Cas in solid tumors is currently limited by the stiff and fibrotic tumor microenvironment that acts as a barrier to nanoparticle uptake. In this grant application, we propose a unique combination of siRNA-mediated gene silencing of focal adhesion kinase (FAK, a key modulator of tumor extracellular matrix (ECM)) and CRISPR-mediated gene editing (deletion) of programmed death-ligand 1 (PD- L1, a brake that blocks cancer immunotherapy), via an all-in-one Selective ORgan Targeting (SORT) lipid nanoparticle (LNP) approach. Outcomes of this work will include elucidation of the fundamental mechanisms how and why FAK inhibition improves LNP uptake and gene editing, optimized Liver and Lung SORT LNP formulations for multiplexed siRNA + Cas9 mRNA + sgRNA delivery, and therapeutic benefit in orthotopic and genetically engineered mouse models of cancer, ultimately revealing a new strategy to enable CRISPR therapies in solid tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Men who have sex with men (MSM) are often at an increased risk of gonorrhea and other sexually transmitted diseases. Despite WHO and US CDC recommendations for routine gonorrhea testing, many MSM have never received a gonorrhea test. The proposed community-based pay-it-forward intervention will engage local MSM, generate donations to sustain the testing service, and improve sexual health services for sexual minorities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Antibiotic resistance is a looming crisis, with the real possibility of common infections becoming untreatable if we do not increase our ability to combat antibiotic resistant pathogens. This U19 will target the development of antibiotic-sparing therapeutics including rationally designed glycomimetics, peptidomimetics and pyridones, as well as mAbs, that can inhibit key host-pathogen interactions and affect the viability of pathogens that are both antibiotic-sensitive and antibiotic-resistant. Thus, this U19 has great potential to impact human health by combating the rising antibiotic resistance problem.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We are interested in understanding at a molecular level how nerve cells conduct electrical signals and how this process is affected by cellular cues, genetic variation, disease, and injury. Chemical synthesis makes possible access to precision reagents that are needed to investigate these complex biological phenomena. Our studies are expected to reveal new insights into the mechanisms through which cells shape neuronal activity and help guide the development of new medicines for treating nervous system disorders.

PHR: The San Francisco State University U-RISE program prepares undergraduate students to continue into biomedical PhD degree programs en route to careers in the biomedical research workforce. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Soluble guanylate cyclase (sGC) is an enzyme central to the nitric oxide (NO) signaling pathway in animals. However, a complete structural and mechanistic understanding of the 3-stage activation of sGC by NO has thus far remained elusive. This proposal will harness a newly discovered NO-specific sGC from the colonial single- cell choanoflagellate, Choanoeca flexa, to explore the structural and evolutionary trajectory of sGC regulation using mutagenesis, cryo-electron microscopy, and small-angle X-ray scattering.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Public Health Relevance. Substance use disorders comprise some of the most devastating and expensive to treat disorders in modern society. Determining the neurochemical imbalances underlying such disorders is a key step in developing appropriate therapies; however, in most cases the neurochemistry, especially of extracellular proteins, is not well understood. In this project, we are developing novel instrumentation and techniques that enable proteins to be monitored in the living brain and testing them in an animal model of cocaine use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), a major cause of lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS), is a highly prevalent debilitating disease in aging men, and its annual treatment costs exceed $4 billion. There is an unmet need for prevention and more effective medical treatment of clinical BPH or LUTS. The proposed mechanistic and preclinical studies will investigate how histological BPH leads to clinical BPH, which will help guide future clinical studies to develop and/or optimize therapeutics targeting mechanisms driving progression from histological BPH to clinical BPH or LUTS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many chemotherapies kill cancer cells by inducing genome instability during DNA replication. Emerging evidence suggests that chemotherapy resistance can arise from over-stabilization of replicating DNA due to different mechanisms. This project investigates the molecular mechanism and therapeutic potential of a novel regulator of DNA stability during replication, named profilin-1.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cranial joint defects such as temporomandibular joint disorders are common craniofacial defects, and while vertebrate heads have a diverse number and type of joints, how the location and subtype of joints are specified remains unclear as a result of the limb being the focus of many joint biology studies. My project investigates 1) how cranial joints are specified separately from replacement cartilage of bone and 2) how they are given regional information to specify the joint subtype they eventually become. These findings will lead to a better understanding of the genetic underpinnings of cranial joint diseases, and potentially inform new and improved approaches to prevent or treat craniofacial defects resultant from improper patterning or maintenance of cranial joints.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Lung cancer is the second-most commonly diagnosed cancer among U.S. Veterans. Significant advances have been made in screening and treatment of lung cancer. Longevity following lung cancer has increased. After lung cancer treatment however, many Veterans experience losses in functional capacity and increased symptoms. Rehabilitation services are needed to address these health issues. This project seeks to better understand Veteran lung cancer survivors’ health goals following treatment, knowledge and outcome expectations for exercise and rehabilitation, and feelings towards technology to guide rehabilitation services. It will also test a telerehabilitation intervention with Veterans after lung cancer treatment, with goals to improve their function and quality of life. This project will advance knowledge on strategies to better meet the rehabilitation needs of Veteran lung cancer survivors. It will also develop the career of a physician researcher to acquire expertise in rehabilitation services for many Veteran lung cancer survivors.

PHR: Public health statement The proposed work will study the causes for certain acquired and inherited heart diseases associated with cardiac arrhythmia (=irregular heart beats) and a high risk for sudden and premature deaths. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent single cell genomic studies of the human intestine have revealed new biological observations about human development, homeostasis and disease; opening the door to uncover novel insights about fundamental human biology. Using single cell genomic approaches, we have identified a new growth factor, Epiregulin (EREG), which is expressed in the stem cells of the developing human intestine, but which is absent from the murine intestine, suggesting a unique role in human development. These studies will shed light onto normal human intestinal homeostasis and may lead to insights into how perturbations to this homeostasis leads to disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metabotropic glutamate receptors (mGluRs) are G protein-coupled receptors, which modulate synaptic transmission and serve as drug targets for a variety of neurological disorders. Due to the receptor’s complex multidomain structure and dimerization, the allosteric mechanisms that couple ligand binding to receptor signaling remain poorly understood. Using structural and biophysical approaches, this proposal will elucidate the conformational dynamics and inter-domain interactions that shape the mGluR activation pathway.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a prevalent early-onset disorder, reliably identified by preschool age, that impairs acquisition of normative milestones, presages chronic mental health problems, and evidences marked disparities in timeliness and prevalence of identification for minoritized racial and ethnic groups. The proposed research builds from a growing research base on neurodevelopmental risk markers for ADHD at toddler age, focusing particularly on dense measurement of toddler attention (dys)regulation and modeling developmental patterns at individual and group levels, to determine if patterns can be meaningfully characterized during this period of rapid development and whether accounting for change can optimize models of neurodevelopmental vulnerability to ADHD. As their inclusion has important implications for risk assessment and health disparities related to emergent ADHD, this work carefully considers the role of structural and familial risks and protective factors in the pathway toward an impairing disorder of early childhood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research aims to expand the capability and performance of ultrasound tomography as a non-ionizing radiation imaging modality that enables greater sensitivity and specificity for breast cancer screening. To achieve this goal, we plan to incorporate both reflection and transmission information in our modeling and inversion approaches to improve and expand the tissue characterization capabilities of ultrasound tomography. Successful completion of this project will improve fundamental understandings of acoustic models and inversion techniques for reflection and transmission ultrasound and further enable quantitative and spatially resolved imaging of tissue properties for the early detection and diagnosis of cancer.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Toxoplasma gondii pathogen of humans and can cross the placental barrier where it represents a significant health threat to the developing fetus. How the placenta resists and responds to pathogen exposure is poorly understood. Our goal is to better understand what happens when T. gondii encounters the placenta with the goal of ultimately developing new ways to predict infection outcomes and specifically if the fetus is at significant risk of infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: 17 Hsp90 inhibitors that target the N-terminal domain of Hsp90 have undergone clinical evaluation for the treatment of cancer. Unfortunately, most have failed and the remaining IND’s are likely to follow suite due to an identical mechanism of action, which leads to induction of the pro-survival heat shock response and consequently, dose- escalating toxicities. Through a series of key studies, C-terminal inhibitors of Hsp90 have been identified that manifest potent anti-cancer activities and do not induce Hsp90 levels, creating a new opportunity to develop cancer chemotherapeutics that target Hsp90. In this application, the optimization and in vivo evaluation of these compounds against HNSCC will be pursued the hope of delivering a new IND for subsequent clinical evaluation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transient Receptor Potential (TRP) channels are regulated by a broad range of stimuli, including chemicals, temperature and mechanical stress and are directly involved in sensory perception such as taste, olfaction, thermal perception and nociception. TRP channels are implicated in the pathogenesis of numerous diseases and some of them represent important prognostic markers and promising targets for new therapeutic strategies to treat a variety of human cancers. Our goal is to study TRP channels using a combination of biophysical and biochemical techniques and to obtain detailed information about their structure and function that will help to develop new drug design strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE High levels of prenatal stress exposure can have long-lasting effects on infants’ abilities to regulate their emotions. Because early problems with emotion regulation increase risk for a wide range of later psychological disorders, identifying factors that protect mothers and their infants from the negative effects of stress during pregnancy is a public health priority. This proposed project, a first step to informing early prenatal prevention of psychological disorders, will provide information about how pregnant women’s day-to-day fluctuations in stressful and positive experiences influence infant outcomes in emotion regulation, particularly among mothers exposed to high levels of chronic stress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative  Early detection of young people at clinical high risk for psychosis offers a critical opportunity for early intervention to improve the course of illness, and perhaps even prevent onset entirely. Current interview-based methods for psychosis risk detection lack specificity, and are only available in a handful of research centers in the United States. The proposed study aims to improve accessibility and broaden impact of high risk screening by testing brief computerized measures, ultimately able to be administered on the internet, and to improve prediction by focusing on tasks specific to underlying mechanisms driving emerging psychotic symptoms.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gastric cancer (i.e., stomach cancer) is a major public health burden with a high incidence and mortality worldwide. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We plan to develop a multipurpose prevention technology (MPT) intravaginal ring (IVR) that releases a safe and effective combination of an estrogen, a progestin, and a non-ARV antiviral agent to prevent pregnancy and HIV infection. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immune checkpoint blockade (ICB) treatment has played a pivotal role in cancer therapy but only benefits a minority of patients. While growing numbers of studies have emphasized the microbiota's contribution to ICB clinical response, there is a struggle to elucidate immunological mechanisms – an issue compounded by the lack of consensus in microbes reported among studies, as well as different tumor models and cancer types used between studies. This collaborative grant proposal investigates multiple tumor models and ICBs using germfree and gnotobiotic mice to understand how generalizable microbiome influences on ICB are across disparate tumor models and cancer types, as well as identify ICB-inhibitory effector species and possible mechanisms through which the intestinal microbiota can be modified in cancer patients and unlock immunotherapy to its fullest potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Many current recommendations for dietary intake (DI) and physical activity (PA) to maintain optimal health and minimize risks for chronic health conditions, such as obesity and type 2 diabetes (T2D), are based on statistical analyses of data prone to measurement error, including those collected from self-reported questionnaires and wearable devices. To overcome these barriers, we will develop new and robust statistical methods to 1) identify latent groups of PA patterns based on device-based functional curves prone to heteroscedastic measurement errors and determine the association between the identified PA patterns with T2D status adjusting for PA biomarkers, age, sex, and race/ethnicity; 2) better reduce the impact of measurement error-related biases in PA and DI data on the quantile functions of body mass index and fat mass index; and 3) correct for measurement error biases associated with device-based PA and self- reported DI when evaluating their influences on T2D status. These newly developed models and related software will be widely applicable in studies of objective measures of PA and DI in chronic health conditions, which can lead to more targeted and effective interventions and address health outcomes disparities among vulnerable populations in various biomedical contexts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative When someone suffers a severe brain injury, a portion of the skull must be removed so that the brain can swell. Unfortunately, a second surgery is required to replace that missing piece of the skull, and the patient can experience neurological problems up until the day that missing bone is replaced. In a rat model, we believe that placing our new flexible material during the first surgery that can later turn into bone will still allow the brain to swell initially, while avoiding the second surgery and the neurological problems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An increasing number of patients with serious mental illness receive care in Medicaid Accountable Care Organizations (ACOs), an alternative payment model in which global payments and quality benchmarks are used to incentivize quality and lower spending, but little evidence exists on quality of ACO care for this patient population. We propose to identify features of Medicaid ACOs (e.g. provider-led vs. hospital-led ACOs) that produce the highest quality ACO care for adults with serious mental illness. We will compare stability of enrollment, care quality, and patient experience between differing ACO types using mixed methods, including quantitative analysis of claims data and qualitative interviews with patients and case managers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Glaucoma is the most common neurodegenerative disease in the world and there are no treatments to prevent or rescue the degenerative cascades that lead to blindness. We discovered a neuroprotective lipid mediator pathway in the healthy retina that is disrupted in disease. This project will define the regulation and mechanism of these lipid signals and develop therapeutic methods to restore their protective function in order to stop or prevent glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE High prevalence of intestinal diseases, such as colon cancer, suggests that we still don’t fully understand their underlying causes. We have discovered a mechanism linking colon tissue integrity, which is commonly compromised in these diseases, with regulation of cell behavior, through molecules called microRNAs (miRNAs) and long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs). The current proposal will provide insights into the regulation and role of this mechanism in maintenance of colon homeostasis, which could lead to novel diagnostic and therapeutic approaches for intestinal diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This grant proposal will determine the impact of the pathogen, Staphylococcus aureus (which is commonly present on the skin of atopic dermatitis patients), on systemic inflammation (measured in the circulation), response to treatments, and viral skin infections in atopic dermatitis patients. Lastly, we have designed experiments to determine if a bacterium called Cutibacterium acnes, commonly present on the skin of healthy individuals and remarkably reduced in atopic dermatitis patients, may function to suppress the growth of the pathogen, Staphylococcus aureus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rigorous evaluation of how parents shape their children’s behavior has major implications for our understanding of family functioning and motivates policies or interventions promoting specific parenting practices. We propose examining the intergenerational impact of marijuana use and disorder using two complementary natural experiments in 6,457 individuals from 1,902 families in Colorado and Minnesota. We will use the children of twins design to test the extent of direct environmental impact of parents while controlling for genetic confounds, and conduct a state-by-state comparison of parental and adolescent marijuana use and disorder, parenting practices, and family environment, leveraging the marked differences in marijuana laws and substance use norms in Colorado and Minnesota.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Schizophrenia is a chronic disorder and is among the most highly disabling diseases in all of medicine, impacting approximately 1.5% of the population. This study will use novel state-of-the-art electroretinography, optical coherence tomography and angiography imaging to capture retinal biomarkers that inform pathophysiology and clinical associations in early course schizophrenia. This study is expected to have an impact on the growing consensus in psychiatry and neuro-ophthalmology that the retina provides a window into the brain that can be useful for understanding brain pathophysiology and for developing biomarkers of illness progression and possibly treatment response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Melanoma is an aggressive cancer with an increasing incidence. Metastatic melanoma to the liver is frequent and associated with poor prognosis and resistance to novel therapies, such as immunotherapies. The current study will use novel models, methodologies and a large cohort of patient biopsies to elucidate the molecular underpinnings of the development of liver metastasis and how these lesions confer resistance to immunotherapies. This will inform rationale design of novel therapeutic avenues for patients with metastatic melanoma to the liver.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Massive effort has been expended collecting gene expression profiling data in attempts to understand human brain function and disease, but interpreting these data remains a challenge. In this project we build on our investigations in which we re-analyze thousands of published studies to add insights, develop new analytic approaches, and provide databases, tools and data to the neuroscience research community to improve gene expression and gene network analysis. By applying our approaches to disorders of the brain such as schizophrenia and autism, we will increase understanding of the molecular underpinnings of these human conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Obesity is a rapidly increasingly problem in the US that increases health care costs, reduces quality of life, and reduces productivity of millions of Americans. It is one of the greatest threats to public health. Finding ways to stop increases in obesity and to reverse current trends requires intensive scientific study. Program faculty on this training grant have successfully mentored 23 promising young scientists in the last eight years, all of whom have been actively involved and productive in multidisciplinary research and 17 of whom have already matriculated. The proposed renewal will continue to provide the training necessary to fill this need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative This program provides a uniquely translational and interdisciplinary training opportunity for scientists in the field of Communication Sciences and Disorders. The training is designed to address critical challenges facing the field including a national shortage of PhD level researcher, increased need for translational, interdisciplinary, and cross-methodological training, and a lack of training in implementation science and health equity. The overarching goal of the program is to prepare a number of highly trained and qualified researchers who are well-equipped to address the challenges facing the field of Communication Sciences and Disorders.

PROJECT_TITLE: Translational Interdisciplinary Research Training in Communication Sciences and Disorders

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children in Sub-Saharan Africa are burdened by significant unmet mental health needs, including disruptive behavior disorders that persist through adolescence and adulthood if left untreated. The proposed study will examine the mechanisms by which economic empowerment and family strengthening interventions targeting social, familial and context-specific drivers affect the mental health of children in mid-upper primary schools in Uganda. Findings from this study can inform group, community and population approaches that are needed for scalable solutions to address the social drivers negatively impacting child behavioral health in low-resource settings, including in Sub-Saharan Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project explores how the sex-specific steroid hormone, ecdysone, promotes intestinal stem cell proliferation, gut expansion, and metabolic changes in reproductive Drosophila females. We also test the hypothesis that sex- specific steroids regulate progenitor cell proliferation and adaptive gut growth in mice. These studies will advance our knowledge of how steroid signaling affects the sex-biased incidence of stem-cell based diseases including cancers, inflammatory conditions, degenerative and metabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Combating rapidly evolving pathogens, such as Ebola, SARS-CoV-2, West Nile and Zika viruses, and their associated disease burden is a tremendous challenge requiring sustained research effort and deliberate public health measures. Viral genome sequencing and phenotyping from infected individuals as an outbreak unfolds has the potential to guide intervention and clinical management, if the phylodynamic toolset can scale to 1000s of samples. This proposal aims to develop scalable statistical models and computational tools to provide this data integration and equips us for large-scale epidemics and pandemics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will provide fundamental information on the impact of O3 and ultrafine CB inhalation co-exposure on ALI pathogenesis and will discern how co-exposure differ from individual particle/gaseous exposures in inducing aggravated/differential lung injury. We anticipate identifying key mechanistic pathways in lung progenitor (AT2) cells which alter epithelial regeneration in ALI after environmental insults. In the short term, this research will quantify pulmonary responses to separate vs co-exposure to a gaseous and particulate constituent of the environmental pollution, and in the longer term, it will help to reduce the burden of environmental diseases by providing evidence on whether current single toxicant exposure-based regulations are sufficient to protect workers and the general population.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The public health relevance of this project lies in its comprehensive approach to studying the genetic and environmental contributions to the development of chronic pain among twins across childhood and adolescence. The results gleaned from this study of a large, ethnically-diverse sample of community-dwelling twins will yield a better understanding of the influences of stress exposure, emotion dysregulation, and epigenetics on youth's pain, and of the potential for social resilience to buffer risk for pain development. Thus, findings will help clinical scientists interested in pediatric pain prevention and resilience by identifying critical developmental periods, and targets for intervention efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is a leading cause of renal failure, affecting over 600,000 individuals in the United States alone and more than 12 million people worldwide. This research will provide novel insights into the mechanisms of cyst formation by evaluating and discovering candidates regulating cystogenesis using cutting edge multidisciplinary approaches including biochemistry, bioinformatics, cell biology, genetics, human cell models, and animal models of the disease. This research will evaluate a new drug target and likely discover new ones.

PHR: Project Narrative Obesity and metabolic syndrome and the associated complications of these disorders including type 2 diabetes mellitus, liver, kidney, and cardiovascular disease affect a large number of Americans. Nearly 40% of adults and over 20% of adolescents in the US are obese. Our training program is designed to prepare the next generation of biomedical scientists to work in multidisciplinary teams that bring together an in depth understanding of nutrition, metabolism, cell biology and genomics to address this critical public health problem.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative During brain tumor surgery, brain tissue surrounding the tumor can deform by as much as two centimeters due to shifting of the brain making safe and effective tumor removal challenging. Several approaches have been developed that allow compensation for this deformation by non-rigidly registering preoperative imaging to the shape of the brain during surgery. This project will investigate ways to convey uncertainty in the non-rigid registration to surgeons, thereby allowing them to make more informed decisions during tumor resections to help maximize the extent of tumor resection while minimizing damage to surrounding tissue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Proper folding of proteins underlies nearly every aspect of cellular function and physiology and is ensured by the protein homeostasis (proteostasis) network. Defects in proteostasis result in protein aggregation, a hallmark of neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's, Parkinson's and ALS, while an overactive proteostasis network can support cancer cell growth and tumor progression. In support of the NIH mission, the research proposed here aims to elucidate the fundamental regulatory mechanisms, feedback loops, and organizational principles that govern the proteostasis network in healthy cells to gain insight into the ways it breaks down and is hijacked in disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Caused by the parasite Trypanosoma brucei, human African trypanosomiasis (HAT) is a neglected tropical disease that is in need of effective, non-toxic drugs. We have identified a class of proliferation inhibitors with promising potency, selectivity, and pharmacokinetic profiles that represent a new chemical series for HAT drug discovery. This proposal outlines a medicinal chemistry optimization project that will deliver lead compounds for new HAT therapeutics, as well as an understanding of the mechanism of action of the leads.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Outcomes of gliomas, the most common type of primary brain tumors in adults are highly infiltrative with poorly defined margins, such as time to progression vary considerably, even for patients with the same pathological grade and recent studies have indicated that more uniform outcomes are observed in sub-groups of glioma with molecular markers such as IDH, 1p19q, ATRX, p53 and MGMT. The recent development of the consensus Brain Tumor Imaging Protocol (BTIP) has reduced the variability between scans but the lack of specificity and ambiguities in interpreting changes in anatomic images remains to evaluate 1) the extent of the disease, 2) the integrity of the blood-brain-barrier (BBB), and 3) response to treatment. The integration of 1H and 13C metabolic imaging into the acquisition protocol enables a more direct assessment of the biological properties of the lesion and has been shown to improve the evaluation of changes in the spatial extent of tumor associated with response to therapy.

PHR: NARRATIVE To help train the next generation of culturally diverse environmental health scientists improve the current environmental landscape that contributes to disparate health burdens, develop approaches to identify and evaluate environmental health disparities, and build skills in community-engaged research and research translation to improve public health, we introduce the “Environmental Health MethodologicAl, Training, and Teaching EnterpRiSe” (EH MATTERS) program. ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Safely expanding the donor pool for solid organ transplantation, and optimally matching donors to the right recipient, is one of the most critical concerns for patients, transplant physicians, and referring nephrologists and hepatologists. This award will allow Dorry Segev, MD, PhD and his team of mentees to better guide clinical decision-making and policy in transplantation, particularly in the context of novel expansions such as HIV-infected donors and recipients, expanded criteria for living donation, and immunological incompatibility. It will also support Dr. Segev's training of new investigators to study ways to improve the health of transplant patients through rigorous patient-oriented research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Craniofacial congenital anomalies are amongst the most common birth defects, but current treatments remain limited to surgical correction; this is in part due to a lack of understanding of the way cells move to give rise to craniofacial structures and how these behaviors are controlled. We have established new approaches that allow us to observe cell behaviors during craniofacial morphogenesis in mouse embryos. These techniques give us an unprecedented view of craniofacial morphogenesis, which ultimately may lead us to discover new approaches to treating these common conditions.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Radiation is a cornerstone treatment for glioblastoma but tumors inevitably recur due to radiation resistance. We have found that abnormal purine metabolism is a key mediator of this resistance. This research proposal will define how radiation and purine metabolism regulate one another and whether inhibitors of purine metabolism could be combined with radiation to treat patients with glioblastoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Nerves are found in many types of solid tumors; however, tumor innervation has long been viewed as passive bystanders in cancer. Although increased innervation is associated with aggressive tumor phenotype and poor prognosis in cancer patients, the underlying biology of these clinical associations has been elusive. Our research aims to develop an in-depth and broad understanding of neuro-immune interactions in cancer with a particular focus on the bi-directional crosstalk between the nociceptive sensory neurons and the tumor microenvironment (TME), and to explore whether we can target such interactions for more effective cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alveolar bone defects are one of the most clinically relevant situations in patients with periodontal disease and trauma. The objective is to develop and validate if injectable highly porous nanofiber microspheres in combination with biomimetic delivery of signaling molecules and/or stem cells can greatly promote alveolar bone regeneration after minimally invasive administration to critical-sized alveolar bone defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE Training the next generation of chemosensory scientists is essential for developing new treatments for chemosensory dysfunction, promoting better eating habits, enhancing quality of life, and even diminishing disease transmission by vector insects and parasites. The impact of chemosensory dysfunction alone is highly significant, particularly in the age of COVID-19: it is estimated that 10% of people exhibit smell or taste impairments, negatively influencing their diet, danger avoidance, interpersonal relationships and quality of life.

PROJECT_TITLE: Training Program in Chemosensory Science

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stressful life events significantly degrade qualify of life and mental health in some individuals, but other individuals seem resilient to its effects. We still don’t have a satisfactory understanding of the differences in the brains of those individuals who are impacted by stress and those who are not. This proposal seeks to study the activity between two brain regions that are important in arousal to understand how their activity can drive some individuals to be more vulnerable to the effects of stress.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed research examines to what extent the observed quality of childhood and adolescent experiences with maternal and paternal caregivers shape young adults’ basic expectations about the degree to which significant others are likely to be available, responsive, and helpful under challenging circumstances and, in turn, to what extent those expectancies among adults predict both: (a) mental and physical health and (b) interpersonal adjustment in adulthood, as reflected in the quality of adults’ romantic relationships as well as their infants’ attachments in the next generation. There is increasing evidence that these expectations—which are reflected in variation in secure base script knowledge—represent fundamental psychological resources that support healthy adult interpersonal relationships along with mental and physical health in the years of maturity. Our proposal seeks to provide more definitive, large sample evidence regarding the origins of secure base script knowledge in interpersonal experiences with primary caregivers from infancy through late adolescence, along with precise estimates of the transmission of such expectancies from parents to their children across risk status, participant sex, and two racial groups (White/non-Hispanic and Black), Aims fundamental to the goals of NIH generally and the EKS NICHD in particular. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ultimate goal of the proposed study is to establish an interdisciplinary speech intervention model for speakers with communication disorders who cannot receive speech therapy in English in the United States. As a first step, the proposed project aims to develop and conduct a small-scale clinical trial study in which the linguistic and cultural diversity of the participants (Korea-born immigrants with Parkinson’s disease) is taken into account. In recognition of the family-centered decision making (FCDM) among East Asian health service users, families of PD participants will be also regarded as active participants of the intervention program with respect to their communication skills with PD patients and health/well-being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVACE TO PUBLIC HEALTH This project investigates neuromodulation of emotional responses using intercranial depth electrodes and the relationship between anxiety symptoms and these responses in treatment resistant epilepsies (TRE). This research is expected to identify brain areas that mediate emotion network dysfunction, leading to anxious symptom experience. The research project will identify potential treatment targets for anxiety and epilepsy disorders and provide data for a subsequent R01 clinical trial proposal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as sulindac can exert immunopotentiating effect by inhibiting the activities of cyclooxygenases (COX). However, long-term inhibition of COX can cause severe toxicities in some vital organs. This project will develop novel non-COX inhibitory sulindac derivatives and employ them as immunomodulators to augment the efficacy of cancer immunotherapies by targeting specific phosphodiesterase (PDE).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Using rigorous quasi-experimental methods with a high-quality, longitudinal, linked health and education dataset on Tennessee children with a Medicaid record, we will generate timely, generalizable knowledge on the implementation and impact of school-based health centers (SBHCs) and policy and program levers that can be employed to increase their efficacy in improving child mental health and education outcomes. We will advance our understanding of the mechanisms by which SBHCs may improve children’s outcomes by elaborating and testing a child-centered conceptual framework for examining in-depth the organization and implementation of SBHCs and comprehensively documenting the operations and services of different SBHC types (traditional on-campus, school-linked, mobile, and telehealth) and the extent to which they are effectively serving disadvantaged or underserved subgroups of children, including in rural areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This Interdisciplinary Training Program in Auditory Neuroscience (TPAN) will provide graduate student training, research experience, and a vibrant community at the interface of neuroscience and neurotechnology, in both human and animal models. This training program will prepare students for independent research careers that can improve our understanding of auditory system function and treatments of auditory system dysfunction using innovative tools and technologies. It is expected that graduates of this training program will develop creative solutions, devices and strategies to advance sensory neuroscience and to ultimately assist and prevent hearing loss in human patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Head and neck cancer is the sixth most prevalent cancer in the world and treatment efficiency is still limited. Therefore, a therapy that can effectively control growth and prevent this disease with minimal off-target side effects is highly desirable. We anticipate our results will identify the efficacy of momordicine-I along with additional chemotherapies in controlling tumor growth in preclinical models and will help in driving therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Knee pain with imaging evidence of meniscal tear is common among middle aged and older persons. The great majority of physicians suggest an initial course of physical therapy for persons with this condition, but there are no studies addressing the best treatment for persons whose pain persists despite PT. This planning grant proposes a range of planning activities to prepare the team to conduct a trial of surgery vs. rigorous nonoperative therapy in persons 45-85 years old with persistent knee pain after PT for meniscal tear.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative A major function of the proximal tubule of the kidney is to recover proteins that enter the nephron to prevent their escape in the urine. Defective proximal tubule function as a result of genetic mutations or kidney injury leads to tubular proteinuria that can progress to end stage renal disease. Our studies here focus on understanding how mutations in an ion transporter that is mutated in Dent disease leads to impaired protein recovery by the proximal tubule. The results of our research will provide important new information about the mechanism of protein recovery that may help in designing therapies for tubular proteinuria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Hyde - Project Narrative: Venezuelan equine encephalitis virus (VEEV) is a mosquito-borne virus that causes significant human and veterinary diseases, however few vaccines and therapies exist to treat VEEV infections. Viral RNA structure is an understudied determinant of pathogenesis. Understanding how VEEV RNA structure contributes to immune evasion and pathogenesis will shed light on mechanisms of viral emergence and inform development of RNA- based therapeutics.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Narrative Currently there are highly effective treatments and prevention for HIV infection, but they are not being optimally utilized in low- and middle-income settings. Sociobehavioral determinants and mental illness represent significant obstacles to their full implementation. This D43 application, "Building Research Capacity for Sociobehavioral Sciences and HIV Infection in Tanzania", will continue to build research expertise to address and overcome these obstacles in Tanzanian context.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The goal of this proposal is to develop and validate a new magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) approach for measuring the severity of fibrosis in the left side of a heart chamber called atrium, for the purpose of predicting whether patients will revert to atrial fibrillation following initial successful intervention. Unfortunately, standard MRI and analysis methods have two fundamental deficiencies (inadequate spatial resolution, unreliability) that hinder accurate reading of fibrosis. Our new approach integrating advanced engineering and MRI physics techniques successfully addresses the deficiencies associated with standard methods and enables doctors to correctly predict recurrent atrial fibrillation following intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer poses a debilitating public health crisis. A hallmark of cancer cells is their ability to grow in the face of stressors such as aneuploidy, nutrient scarcity, and xenobiotic compounds. The proposed research will investigate a novel gene, C16orf72, which we recently discovered to be a powerful regulator of stress resilience in cancer cells and may be a viable target to reduce cancer growth and prevent the development of therapy resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Protein glycosylation and trafficking is an essential biological process that is intimately linked to tumorigenesis and cancer progression. Our structure-function studies on enzymes involved in protein mannosylation and the coupling between lipid flipping and membrane bending will fill a knowledge gap. The derived structures will facilitate the development of small molecules targeting these enzymes for potential cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many bilingual students entering US schools learned foundational concepts in a language other than English, leaving them at a potential developmental disadvantage compared to their monolingual peers when tested on this knowledge in English. This proposal investigates how the bilingual brain processes foundational knowledge that is thought to be affected by the unique experience of being bilingual, including memorized multiplication facts and basic scientific concepts. The outcome of this research will help determine how bilingual children learn and use foundational knowledge in each of their languages, as well as elucidate the relationship between language, development, and the bilingual brain more generally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Relapse remains a leading cause of death for patients with B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Using single- cell studies of primary diagnosis samples from patients, we can identify cells responsible for future relapse at the time of diagnosis. Building a model of relapse risk prediction based on the presence of these cells will enable rapid, accurate, and actionable relapse prediction moving closer to the goal of preventing relapse.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed program, “Integrating prevention and treatment of non-communicable diseases and HIV care through research training in Kenya-INTEGRATE,” will train health professionals at Kenyatta National Hospital (KNH) and the Kenya Ministry of Health (MOH) to conduct implementation science and epidemiology research that will improve non-communicable disease (NCD) prevention, diagnosis and treatment for people living with HIV (PLWH). This renewal application strives to build sustainable research capacity through advanced research training at University of Nairobi (UoN) and University of Washington (UW), as well as support career development of junior researchers at KNH. In this way, our program will contribute solutions to the pressing need to provide comprehensive HIV and NCD care, and achieve higher quality of life and sustainable reductions in preventable deaths among PLWH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  This project will advance statistical methodology for measuring HIV incidence and develop a new class of efficacy trial design to evaluate future HIV preventive interventions. These methods are greatly needed because use of current highly resource-efficient estimates of incidence (HIV recency assays, which provide information on the timing of HIV acquisition) are limited due to lack of precision. In addition, traditional clinical trial designs may soon prove infeasible since effective HIV preventive interventions currently exist. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The T cell-specific DNA binding protein TCF-1 has two main isoforms and performs multiple stage- and lineagespecific epigenetic functions during T cell development but there is a gap in our knowledge on how TCF-1 leverages these stage- and context-specific functions. Optimally addressing this gap in knowledge without confounding developmental defects resulting from long- term TCF-1 deficiency requires inducible short-term manipulation of the protein levels of selective TCF-1 isoforms at specific stages of T cell development. Therefore, we propose to generate and validate animal models that allow auxin-inducible, in vivo short-term degradation of TCF-1 isoforms to record in time their molecular and epigenetic functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In pre-clinical models of head and neck cancer (HNC), exposure to chronic stress leads to increased tumor growth and metastasis. Although the underlying mechanisms remain uncertain, our preliminary data have implicated the SDF-1/CXCR4 pathway in this stress-induced cancer growth. Through both pre-clinical and clinical investigations, including a novel mouse model of chronic stress with a humanized immune system, this study will shed light on the underlying mechanisms and clinical relevance of stress-induced HNC growth, providing a foundation for the development of precision therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The pandemic of obesity is a major cause of the increased incidence of type 2-diabetes and cardiovascular diseases. Excessive storage of calories in white adipose tissue (WAT) leads to infiltration of inflammatory cells and deposition of fibrogenic material, which with time causes disruption of overall metabolism and energy balance. The proposed studies are designed to identify the mechanisms responsible for the progressive decline in adipocyte functions and the role of changes in cellular complexity of WAT in response to the consumption of chronic high fat diet.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Hantaviruses such as Andes virus (ANDV) and Sin Nombre virus (SNV) are rodent-borne viruses that cause highly lethal disease in humans. No approved drugs or vaccines exist to treat or prevent hantavirus infection. We will exploit proprietary technology and an experienced multidisciplinary team to develop potent neutralizing antibodies against ANDV. The successful development of this potent antibody-based therapeutic against ANDV has the potential to be a first-line antiviral for the treatment or prevention of hantavirus cardiopulmonary syndrome (HCPS).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Retinal diseases lead to visual impairment or blindness and we are in search of approaches to regenerate the retina and restore vision. This project examines microRNAs as key regulators of retinal progenitor cell state and subsequent neuronal cell fate specification in postnatal retinal development. The results will reveal microRNA candidates that can not only function as reprogramming factors to convert endogenous retinal glia cells into neurons but also can serve as therapy to prevent cell degeneration in order to restore or preserve normal retinal function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Cognitive dysfunction is central to neurological disorders such as PD and related dementias, and several psychiatric disorders. We will for the first time decipher the individual roles of cortical norepinephrine and dopamine in motivation, learning, and their contribution to cortico-striatal circuits and striatal dopamine dynamics. Through our proposed studies, we will not only advance our understanding of basic catecholamine biology in the brain, but also help devise innovative strategies to modulate activity of these neuromodulators and cortico-striatal subcircuits, and develop novel targeted therapies to counteract cortical catecholamine dysfunction in dementias and neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative STING is an essential adaptor protein in the innate immunity against pathogens and cancer. Small molecular drugs targeting STING have potential in treatment of viral infection and cancer. This project is aimed at deepening our understanding of the regulatory mechanisms of STING and designing novel drug-like activators of STING for research and potentially further usage in clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Lung cancer accounts for about 25% of all cancer deaths in the US, since it is often caught at an advanced stage when treatment options are limited. This has led to the institution of screening programs with low-dose CT, resulting in ~1.6 million pulmonary nodules detected every year, most of them (~80%) in the periphery of the lung. We propose the development of an FDA-cleared medical device that allows microscopic imaging of fresh, unprocessed tissue biopsies in the treatment room and that would provide accurate, near real-time diagnosis based on deep learning to identify tissue biopsies that are of diagnostic quality.

PHR: Project Narrative The Michigan Institute for Clinical & Health Research (MICHR) catalyzes clinical and translational research (CTR) and advances clinical and translational science (CTS) at the University of Michigan (U-M), throughout the state of Michigan, and nationally. We have transformed CTR at U-M and have been a collaborative partner with university units, Michigan communities, and the Clinical and Translational Science Award Consortium. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: NARRATIVE This is a competing renewal application of a very successful Program Project Grant that has received continued funding for the past 11 years. During this time we have maintained a strong productivity, we have built a very collaborative and synergistic team and we have implemented substantial expertise and resources to study Chronic Wasting Disease (CWD), a prion disorder that continue to spread uncontrollably among cervids in USA. In this project, we will investigate the mechanism of CWD prion replication and the generation, adaptation and evolution of prion strains, the atomic resolution structure of infectious prions, the routes of transmission of the disease among animals, the evaluation of the zoonotic potential of CWD, the role of the environment on prion transmission and the development of efficient procedures to detect the infectious agent.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 80% of breast screening facilities in the US currently use 3-D digital breast tomosynthesis (DBT) to screen women for breast cancer, which offers superior tissue visualization compared to 2-D mammography and allows for estimation of true volumetric breast density. We will establish a large, diverse DBT consortium to enable the evaluation of novel commercial and research DBT volumetric density measures to predict invasive breast cancer, interval and advanced cancers, and to evaluate the impact of these DBT density measures on risk prediction models, AI algorithms, and risk-based thresholds for preventative therapy and supplemental imaging across a diverse population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: Narrative Mantle cell lymphoma (MCL), an aggressive cancer arising in the lymphoid organs, is often the subject of acquired drug resistance (DR), posing a significanct challenge and unmet need for therapeutic treatment of the disease. In order to combat this DR, which can emerge from BCL-2 inhibitors such as ABT-199, we propose a combinatorial genetic and chemical approach to prevent further DR by targeting drug tolerant persister (DTP) and the DTP expansion population (DTEP) using CDK7/BRD4 and BCL-2 antagonists to target transcriptional machinery. We expect to (a) develop a comprehensive mechanistic epigenetic atlas to understand the development of drug resistance in MCL biology and (b) uncover a novel mechanism-driven therapy for MCL patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Modified Public Health Relevance Section There are currently 1.5 million new HIV infections each year. Thus, there is a great need to develop a safe and effective prophylactic HIV vaccine. In this application, we propose to evaluate an innovative algorithm to identify protective CD8+ T cell epitopes, HIV envelope trimer immunogens and a novel vaccine delivery platform of heterologous replication-incompetent chimpanzee adenoviral vaccine vector and lipid-nanoparticle messenger RNA within the non-human primate model in order to further inform the components that are necessary to achieve a prophylactic vaccine for HIV.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project narrative People with HIV have a higher prevalence of mental disorders compared to the general population, and the co- occurrence of these conditions are associated with adverse health outcomes in HIV, including poor adherence, poor viral suppression, and early mortality. A research training programme at the intersection of mental disorders and HIV is urgently needed to address the synergistic stress associated with these conditions. A Fogarty training programme at the University of Cape Town will allow us to train the next generation of researchers and clinician- scientists in behavioural medicine to address the challenges associated with co-occurring HIV and mental disorders and to become local and international leaders in HIV-associated behavioural medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: Project Narrative Most neuropsychiatric disorders have developmental origins, but knowledge about early risk factors, ontogeny, and mechanism remains scarce. We have identified a sensitive developmental period around adolescence, during which dopamine and serotonin modulate brain development to permanently and bi-directionally alter aggressive behavior and response to psychostimulants. Here we propose to study the underlying circuit-based mechanism, to ultimately improve diagnosis, prevention, and treatment strategies in psychiatric.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding how leukemia cells hijack the translation machinery to allow high expression of short-lived oncoproteins is critical to develop effective therapies to treat this lethal blood disease. Recently, we identified a novel regulatory axis in AML in which PRMT9 overexpression induced eEF1A1 arginine methylation to promote AML cell maintenance. In this project, we will evaluate the functions of PRMT9 activity and eEF1A1 arginine methylation in human AML patient specimens and genetic mouse models with a goal of developing novel AML therapies based on PRMT9 inhibition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: Project Narrative Protein glycation is a spontaneous reaction that is linked to a multitude of human diseases. Cells harbor a “hybrid” kinase/deglycase enzyme, fructosamine-3-kinase, to repair glycated proteins, yet despite its biological importance, we have a poor mechanistic understanding of how this enzyme works. We will use a multidisciplinary approach that integrates structural biology, enzymology, and systems biology to develop a compressive mechanistic understanding of FN3K-mediated protein repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The WISDOM study is a pragmatic trial designed to improve screening by harnessing our growing understanding of breast cancer risk and predisposition. We are testing a personalized approach, which tailors screening to individual risk within existing guidelines, assigning more intensive screening for those at higher risk and more likely to benefit, and less for those at lower risk who might otherwise suffer harms of screening for less benefit. The proposal `Expanding the WISDOM Study's Diversity, Reach, and Generalizability' will enable us to extend the geographic and ethnic reach of this innovative study, which includes a coverage with evidence progression model, to increase the power and generalizability of our study results.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE South Africa has the world’s largest HIV population with approximately 7.52 million people with HIV (PWH), and prevalence of HIV associated neurocognitive impairment (NCI) is high (23% to 76%). Cognitive remediation training has been developed for PWH, but not in South Africa. Adapting and developing cognitive remediation training for South African PWH, allowing for rehabilitation of these patients, can have far reaching health benefits, such as enhanced physical and mental health related to better medication adherence and improved psychosocial outcomes, including mental health.
