IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Disentangling the Mechanisms of Coronary Blood Flow Regulation through Multi-scale Modeling The coronary circulation is regulated by numerous mechanisms to ensure that myocardial oxygen supply is adequate to meet the metabolic demand over a variety of patho-physiologic conditions. Despite the crucial nature of this intrinsic response, understanding the mechanisms responsible for coronary flow autoregulation remains one of the most fundamental questions in the coronary field today. In this project, we propose a combination of novel computational tools and animal experiments to improve our understanding of the mechanisms affecting autoregulation of coronary flow, in both health and disease.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative As of 2021, Kenya was the home of approximately 1.4 million people living with HIV (PLVHIV) and ranked eighth globally for the highest number of PLHIV residing within a country. Given this burden of disease, it is imperative that Kenyan investigators have the training to recognize gaps in the HIV prevention and care cascades, design implementation strategies to address those gaps, assess the effectiveness of these strategies, and translate findings into best practices to disseminate. By strengthening in-country educational infrastructure, expanding local human resource capacity in strategic areas, promoting sustained engagement in research, enhancing mentorship capacity, and supporting research collaboration with county health teams, this training program will build sustainable research capacity for HIV Implementation Science and Dissemination Research (HIV-ID) and promote decolonization of global health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a major public health issue, which has a significant impact upon our healthcare system. Economic analyses of the annual cost of TBI-related disabilities range from $4.5 billion in direct expenditure (medical care and services) to $70.6 billion in injury-related work loss and disability. Our goal in the proposed studies is to determine the underlying mechanism(s) through which stress exacerbates behavioral outcomes after injury and to leverage these findings into therapeutic regimes that can be translated from the bench to the clinic to mitigate the effects of TBI in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Public Health Relevance/Narrative The proposed research exploits the synergy of histone methylation inhibition with DNA base excision repair in contracting the expanded GAA repeats of Friedreich's ataxia to develop a frataxin gene-targeted CRISPR/dCas9 system fused with histone demethylase. The gene-targeted system will reveal the precise mechanisms for histone demethylation to coordinate with DNA repair, causing the contraction of the expanded repeats at the frataxin gene. The proposed research will significantly advance the development of gene therapy for Friedreich's ataxia and other repeat expansion diseases; thus, it is relevant to the NIH mission of reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tumor microenvironment acidity is a characteristic of breast cancers of all sizes, grades, and stages. We propose to develop and implement a holistic approach for tumor acidity imaging with pre-operative multi-parametric MRI (mpMRI) and novel pHLIP® ICG near infrared fluorescent (NIRF) intra-operative imaging. The long-term goal is to improve the standard of care: pre-operative non-invasive non-contrast TME acidity imaging with mpMRI will allow the identification of more aggressive tumor phenotypes that require intensified treatment, improve planning of surgical and treatment strategies, and enable monitoring spatial-longitudinal of tumor biology with treatment; and intra-operative pHLIP-ICG NIRF imaging will allow an improved up-front resection of primary breast cancer, which could allow a shift from more extensive surgeries to highly accurate tissue-sparing lumpectomies – therefore improving the quality of patients’ lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Most of the vertebrate genome finds its ultimate origin in transposable elements, once best known as prototypical selfish DNA, and their annotation is crucial for genome sequence analysis and our understanding of their unrivaled impact on genome biology and evolution. Their de novo discovery and description has become a bottleneck in the genome analysis of the thousands of new species sequenced every year. In this proposal, we describe a plan to make foundational changes to the way RepeatMasker adjudicates TE alignments and assigns confidence to annotations, and present two feasible and novel paths to improving the generation of new TE libraries through the use of multi-species genome alignments and ancestral reconstructions and core algorithmic changes to our RepeatModeler discovery tool.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: This application will develop and integrate a series of technical solutions that improve efficiency and reduce variability of current magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) exams, into a true 5-minute clinical exam. We will train artificial intelligence models to enable single button-push MRI exams, using a multi-center, multi-vendor approach to ensure the reproducibility and generalizability of our results. We focus on achieving these goals on the development of a rapid and quantitative MRI method that can detect and quantify early features of fatty liver disease and liver iron overload, to facilitate preventative treatment for millions of Americans who would otherwise go undiagnosed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Public health scientists lack reliable data on the burden of many infectious diseases, which is a barrier to effective control measures. This project will develop an open-source R software package, called serocalculator, to estimate seroincidence from cross-sectional serologic response data. We expect this tool will be used to generate incidence estimates for a range of infectious diseases, providing critical information needed to inform disease control interventions and ultimately reduce the burden of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Going to the doctor has largely become an experience of risk calculation for patients, while for clinicians and researchers, the emergence of evidence-based medicine, as well as the more recent turn to precision and personalized medicine, are predicated on the ability to statistically process large quantities of medical data. This grant will support research for a monograph that transforms our understanding of the history of modern medicine by analyzing how statistical tools and concepts once understood as relevant only in aggregate, and for population-level analysis, came to be understood as relevant for making claims of causality and efficacy for individuals in the clinic. As the first book- length history of biostatistics and clinical epidemiology, this work will be of great interest to audiences in history of medicine, health policy, clinical medicine, epidemiology, and related medical social sciences, as well as to members of the lay public who find themselves curious about the central role of probability and statistics in medical treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Crohn's disease has long been associated with the concept of impaired lymphatic drainage. In this application, we reveal that impaired lymph flow is due to formation of tertiary lymphoid organs (TLOs) that obstruct the outflow lymphatic vessels of the gut. In this application, we seek to determine how these TLOs form and whether they exacerbate disease, following up on surprising evidence that they may have a benefit in containing the spread of systemic manifestations of Crohn's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Pediatric cardiac arrest affects thousands of children each year, and pulmonary hypertension among children with cardiac arrest is an understudied problem that is likely associated with worse survival outcomes. The objectives of this research are to define the epidemiology of pulmonary hypertension-associated cardiac arrest and to quantify its physiologic effects as well as the physiologic impact of a potential therapeutic, inhaled nitric oxide. These studies will form the foundation of our collective knowledge on this topic and will potentially lead to prospective clinical trials to improve outcomes from pediatric cardiac arrest.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: 10-15% of all monogenic inherited diseases are caused by mutations that result in premature termination codons (PTCs) mutations. Despite being a central mechanism in over 1,000 diseases, including cystic fibrosis, no current therapies exist. This proposal is designed to investigate the ability of suppressor tRNAs encoded in small DNA vectors delivered to lung to treat nonsense-associated cystic fibrosis and identify off-target suppression effects to determine their therapeutic promise.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project narrative: Addiction and other mental disorders arise from disruptions in brain circuitry important for natural reward processing and motivation. However, the precise cell types and circuits that control adaptive reward seeking remain poorly understood. The proposed experiments will continue to investigate the neurocircuit architecture and function of genetically defined cell types in the rodent lateral hypothalamic area to better understand circuity implicated in these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The identification of cellular and molecular mediators of repair following demyelination is critical to developing therapies and drugs to ameliorate the progressive disability in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS). The proposed research is relevant to public health because of the novel link between circadian disruption, a common problem associated with MS patients, and the process of failed repair in MS. The proposed research is relevant to the mission of the NINDS because it will develop fundamental knowledge that may help reduce the burden of disease and improve the quality of life for MS patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Developmental prosopagnosia (DP), a disorder in which individuals have severe lifelong face recognition deficits, affects up to 2.5% of the population and currently has no treatment. We have found preliminary evidence of meaningful perceptually-impaired vs. perceptually-unimpaired DP subgroups and propose to further test and validate these subgroups in a large sample, examine the neural mechanisms of DP perceptual deficits, and also test whether DP subgroups differentially respond to cognitive training treatments targeting face perception vs. face memory. This could not only help developmental prosopagnosics but potentially other disorders with face processing deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: Public Health Relevance Jamaican sexual and gender minorities comprise between 27,000 to 33,000 individuals who are at risk for health disparities, including very high rates of HIV and mental health conditions. Violence against Jamaican sexual and gender minorities is also a key driver fueling the high prevalence of HIV infections in this population by driving them underground and away from vital HIV prevention and treatment services. This program of research provides a supportive, innovative strengthens-based approach to improve HIV care engagement among Jamaican sexual and gender minorities by targeting intersectional stigma and violence, both of which have a negative impact on mental health and engagement in care. We will look at the interplay between intersectional stigma and violence, within the Caribbean context, for the first time among sexual and gender minorities living with HIV and develop a supportive behavioral intervention that takes into account the complex, multi-layered lives sexual and gender minority Jamaicans inhabit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite a growing awareness of lipedema as a distinct clinical entity from obesity and lymphedema, fundamental gaps persist in our knowledge regarding both disease mechanisms and efficacy of promising treatments. The overall goal of this work is to address clinical unmet needs for patients with lipedema using advanced magnetic resonance imaging methods of vascular and molecular dysfunction, in sequence with portable clinical measures of adiposity and edema. Findings are intended to determine modalities appropriate for lipedema screening, demonstrate effects of lymphatic stimulation on symptoms of lipedema, and advance our understanding of the circulatory mechanisms involved in lipedema.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Commonly applied methods to measure and analyze multimorbidity fail to provide adequate context and technical support from which to design, evaluate, and implement multilevel clinically-relevant interventions as indicated by the recently announced PAR-20-179 (Advancing Research to Develop Improved Measures and Methods for Understanding Multimorbidity). To address this gap, we propose to build on our prior novel work designing the cumulative burden measure of multimorbidity and: (1) develop patient-level personalized risk- prediction, based on predefined risk factors and “burden weights,” a condition-specific, patient-derived health- related quality of life metric designed to incorporate patient perspectives; (2) create visualization tools to facilitate sharing of cumulative burden data, from any cohort, broadly across different stakeholder audiences; (3) study, for the first time, chronic multimorbidity in a highly vulnerable population of pediatric and adult sickle cell patients while simultaneously examining the barriers and enablers that impact effective implementation of the cumulative burden measures in an unrelated, non-cancer clinical population. We anticipate our work will yield a suite of visualization templates and modular applied method resources in order to support implementation within a diverse number of cohort studies with the ultimate goal of assisting health system planning and improving understanding by clinicians, researchers, advocacy groups, and policymakers about the growing problem of multimorbidity affecting nearly every sub-group of society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Reanalyzing data from some of the seminal studies linking a low level of response (LR) to alcohol to future alcohol-related problems, this R21/R33 Phased Innovation project aims to: 1) explore relationships of LR to acute and chronic alcohol tolerance; and 2) elucidate some of the functional brain networks underlying one's sensitivity and acute tolerance to alcohol. Building on the experienced investigative team's prior research, and incorporating insights from Newlin and Thomson's “Differentiator” and King's “Modified Differentiator” models, we will use neuroendocrine and ethanol-functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) approaches to explore the hypothesis that alcohol sensitivity involves both the drug's rewarding and stress-provoking properties which might differ between the sexes. The successful completion of this project should lead to more refined sex- specific hypotheses regarding these functional brain networks, and to improved neuroimaging-based quantitative models that better explain the linkages among alcohol sensitivity, tolerance, and the development of alcohol use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although the Fontan surgical procedure, which reroutes blood from the heart to the lungs, has greatly improved survival in children born with “single ventricle” congenital heart defects, these patients remain at risk for significant organ dysfunction and premature death. The proposed research focuses on using magnetic resonance imaging and computational models to characterize the novel role of blood viscosity in the Fontan circulation, with the long-term goals of developing sensitive tools to screen for Fontan failure and therapies to improve care in this growing population of chronically ill patients. This project is relevant to public health and in line with the NHLBI’s mission as it will promote the prevention and treatment of heart disease, so that people with the Fontan circulation can live longer and have more fulfilling lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: PACIFIC INSTITUTE FOR RES AND EVALUATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will support spatial and legal epidemiological research that will (1) summarize tribal alcohol policies across 56 tribal nations collocated in 13 US states, (2) perform qualitative and quantitative studies of the local contexts and enforcement implementation of alcohol policies across these 56 tribal nations, and (3) assess relationships of state and tribal alcohol policies to alcohol related health outcomes using hospital discharge and traffic injury data. For communities experiencing stark health inequities, the tribal alcohol policy measures developed in this project will increase capacity for policy making, provide opportunities for culturally and contextually-tailored health policy research interventions, create collaborative knowledge for multiple jurisdictions, and support jointly constructed solutions to public health problems. Results will advance methods for understanding alcohol regulation and measures of population health among communities experiencing some of the most disparate health inequities in the United States, demonstrate the utility of including community voices to enrich our empirical assessments of contextual factors associated with alcohol-related outcomes, and support community advocacy for policy change by improving understanding of policy effects on health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative This research project uses a Community-Based Participatory Research (CBPR) framework to test the efficacy of a culturally adapted relapse prevention intervention developed collaboratively by community partners from the Fort Peck Indian Reservation in northeastern Montana and research partners from Montana State University. The Indigenous Recovery Planning intervention employs trained Fort Peck community members to deliver manualized intervention content to American Indian adults with substance use disorder (SUD). By increasing access to culturally responsive evidence-based treatment, this research aims to decrease SUD- related health disparities and improve public health outcomes for underserved Native communities locally and nationally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was a major advance of the 20th century in patient care, but the need for high magnetic field instrumentation limits widespread accessibility. We have made progress with low-field MRI and compute-based imaging reconstruction and interpretation approaches. We propose the deployment of a point-of-care (POC), portable and highly mobile low-field MRI solution in two independent patient care settings. This system will be used at the bedside in individual patients as a model for broader deployment into any healthcare setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE  3 sentences We propose to study the effects of the NK1 receptor antagonist, tradipitant, on gastric function and symptom improvement in patients with functional dyspepsia. We will utilize and further validate simultaneous measurements of gastric emptying and gastric accommodation utilizing a solid meal and nuclear medicine scanning technique to better understand the pathophysiology of functional dyspepsia as well as the mechanism of action of tradipitant. Further understanding of the underlying gastric physiologic changes will provide groundwork for future diagnostic and therapeutic advances in functional dyspepsia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Eyes with advanced glaucomatous damage have little residual reserve and small amounts of progression can have important consequences affecting patient’s visual function and quality of life. We propose optimizing the use of longitudinal optical coherence tomography macular data to confirm and predict functional progression. The results of the proposed study will lead to the development of more effective methods for earlier detection of glaucoma progression and will allow clinicians to more aggressively treat deteriorating eyes resulting in decreased visual disability and reduced rates of blindness from glaucoma. ! !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease and related disorders (ADRD) research represents an area of major national investment. But ADRD research faces delays and risks to internal and external validity resulting from consistent challenges to efficient and generalizable accrual. Recruitment registries are tools to address these challenges by establishing large repositories of individuals who are potentially eligible and willing to participate in research, expediting discovery. This proposal will provide researchers with critical evidence to instruct methods to diversify registries by including people from the most disadvantaged neighborhoods and addressing sample bias in these unique recruitment interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative In a genetic screen, we made the unexpected discovery of a synaptic tRNA methyltransferase, TRM9L that regulates the formation and function of synapses and oxidative stress response. An emerging framework suggests a role for the dynamic regulation of tRNAs in modulating gene expression, while a growing list of links between tRNA modifying enzymes and neurological disorders underlines the importance of understanding how tRNA modification impacts neuronal function. Our proposed aims combine genetic and biochemical analyses to determine how TRM9L functions in the nervous system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Similar or identical DNA sequences along chromosomes have an impressive ability to find and interact with each other. Defects in such homologous DNA interactions may result in cell senescence, cancer, and reproductive failure. Our work will generate an assay that identifies sites of homologous DNA interactions along the entire genome of intact cells, thereby allowing diagnosis of mistakes in DNA interactions under pathological conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many forms of cancer are able to defeat T cell therapies by suppressing their growth and anti-tumor effectiveness. This research project is significant in that it will both study and develop tools to hack and reprogram the suppressive programs within therapeutic T cells. It is expected that these studies will be used to develop cell therapies that can overcome T cell dysfunction for patients with multiple types of blood cancers and solid tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this Pathway to Independence Award, the applicant will use advanced multimodal neuroimaging and statistical techniques to elucidate the extent to which small vessel cerebrovascular disease (svCBVD) and Alzheimer’s disease (AD) pathophysiology are additive or synergistic in their effects on neurodegeneration and cognition in a community-based, middle-aged, multiethnic cohort. Specifically, the contribution of svCBVD pathophysiology, through its effect on amyloid clearance and tau phosphorylation, to AD-related neurodegeneration and memory impairment in midlife will be compared across racial/ethnic groups. Outcomes from this proposal will provide key information about the mechanisms by which svCBVD and AD pathophysiology interact at the earliest stage of their development to affect neurodegeneration and cognition that informs clinical trials on the relevant target(s) in dementia with mixed pathology that can be generalized to racially/ethnically diverse populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE California has the highest incidence and largest number of tuberculosis (TB) cases in the contiguous U.S., of which 80% are due to reactivation. These TB cases can be prevented via screening and treatment of latent tuberculosis infection (LTBI), yet, current adoption of the latent TB screening and treatment guidelines has been extremely poor. We will leverage expansive electronic health record data from two of the largest healthcare organizations in California to create and validate a new LTBI screening and treatment approach that can vastly improve identification and successful treatment of LTBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Basic biological research, applied biomedical research, and biotechnology are limited by our ability to get information into and out from living systems, and to act on information inside living systems. This research will result in transformative advances in capabilities to design genetically- encoded technologies that receive, process, and transmit molecular information. Such technologies will significantly impact our ability to monitor, interface with, and program the dynamic cellular state, thereby resulting in an enhanced understanding of biological processes leading to disease and new approaches for constructing targeted molecular therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Title: Watching cooperative interactions between base and nucleotide excision repair proteins. PI: Bennett Van Houten, PhD Project Narrative: This highly innovative project is focused on understanding how common forms of oxidative DNA damage, produced during environmental genotoxicant insult and inflammation during toxic responses, are detected and repaired in various genomic locations in living cells. This project will also explore how chromatin remodelers work with DNA repair enzymes from nucleotide (NER) and base excision repair (BER) pathways. Loss of or key alterations in BER or NER are associated with several pathophysiologies, including cancer, premature aging and neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative and Impact to Human Health Photoreceptor loss due to degenerative retinopathy is a leading cause of adult vision loss worldwide. Transplantation of photoreceptor precursor cells (PPCs) into the degenerative retina is an exciting strategy for replacing lost photoreceptors and restoring vision. This project aims to define and optimize the cellular mechanisms driving PPC migration into the retina for photoreceptor repopulation and vison restoration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Neuropsychological symptoms, such as fatigue, depressive symptoms, cognitive dysfunction, sleep problems, and pain, are among the most common, debilitating, and long-lasting side effects from cancer and its treatment and are prognostic to survival. The proposed research will examine the association between gut microbiome and neuropsychological symptoms through the role of short chain fatty acids and inflammation in the gut-brain axis among patients with head and neck cancer receiving radiotherapy. The findings may indicate new biomarkers and novel therapeutic targets for neuropsychological symptoms in cancer survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The brain is a predictive organ: its memories of the past are used to adaptively guide behavior in anticipation of events that might occur seconds, minutes, hours, or longer in the future. This project will uncover how the brain can simultaneously represent anticipatory signals at multiple timescales, how these signals are influenced by top-down goals, and how they can guide future-oriented behavior. Understanding how hierarchical anticipation signals support behavior at a range of timescales will yield important insights into how flexible, future-oriented actions are planned and implemented in a constantly changing world.

PHR: Project Narrative Men who have sex with men (MSM) are heavily burdened by HIV in the U.S., particularly young MSM and MSM of color, and many new infections occur in the context of primary or main partnerships. The overarching goal of this proposal is to improve public health by establishing the effectiveness the 2GETHER intervention package, an innovative relationship education and HIV prevention program for both single and partnered MSM, in a Hybrid Type I Effectiveness-Implementation Trial design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because a greater understanding of plasticity after central vision loss can inform new therapies for treating low vision and has potential to benefit millions of individuals suffering from low vision. The treatment of low vision is particularly relevant to the mission of the NEI to support research on visual disorders, mechanisms of visual function and preservation of sight. The comparison of dif- ferent training and outcome factors is in line with the NIMH RDOC framework and studies in an aging popula- tion are consistent with the mission of the NIA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Solid and blood tumors are known to escape from and develop resistance to therapies, which renders therapies ineffective and leads to tumor progression. In this project, I propose to determine the mechanism of glioma escape from epidermal growth factor variant three (EGFRviii) targeted chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cell therapy and to design and test novel combination therapy strategies to prevent escape from and resistance to CAR T cells. The goal of this project is to provide better combination therapy strategies for use in patients based on mutations observed in tumor escaped cells in patients with glioma and other solid tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative Early life immune system activity needs to be tightly regulated to prevent organismal developmental abnormalities. A better understanding of the origin and development of immune cells in early life has important clinical implications, especially in providing novel insights into how child-specific diseases arise. We plan to generate a high resolution atlas of skin immune cells of children, which will greatly accelerate progress towards determining how early life immune system develops and identify genetic regulatory networks that are relatively fragile, and often contribute to disease susceptibility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: A shortage exists of MD and PhD scientific researchers equipped to develop new treatments for cardiovascular disease, the most common cause of morbidity and mortality both internationally and within the United States. Over the last 15 years, Virginia Commonwealth University, through the Pauley Heart Center, has created a high-quality research environment with federally funded, multi-disciplinary (involving collaborations among 7 institutional departments), translational (involving pursuit of fundamental discoveries that impact meaningful health outcomes) research projects conducive to training and mentoring young investigators. We now propose to further expand this academic environment to train post-doctoral professionals and clinician scientists desirous of an academic career in translational cardiovascular research – thereby helping to address the shortage of well-trained multi-disciplinary translational academic investigators needed in this area of high public health impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): Despite advances in diagnostics and therapeutics, Human cytomegalovirus remains a major life-threatening complication following solid organ or stem cell transplantation and in people who are immune compromised. The goal of our work is to elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) regulates cellular stress pathways to control entry into and exit from latency.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: The lack of approved drugs for treatment of MAFLD is due to the heterogenous pathology of disease progression and the limitation that animal models do not fully recapitulate the human disease. The use of a combined QSP and iPSC-derived MPS experimental platform to examine mechanistic detail of key disease- related genetic variants and to use for testing predicted drugs serves as a starting point to identify optimized therapeutics that will advance the approach to MAFLD drug discovery. The more detailed analysis of the best drugs and drug combinations in an optimized biomimetic model will refine the selection of drugs/combinations for select patient cohorts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic myelomonocytic leukemia (CMML) is an aggressive blood cancer for which we unfortunately have no curative therapies. Our group has now identified that 20% of CMML patients harbor a second subclonal disease that confers unique clinical characteristics. This R37 extension will build on the CMML PDX models generated during the parent grant to model this new discovery, confirm biologic clone-to-clone interactions, and begin to determine how these two distinct clones collaborate to result in fully manifested CMML.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: From mouse to man, traumatic injuries to the joint cause inflammation and, when the instigating injury remains uncorrected, persistent inflammation culminates in irreversible degradation of all joint structures. This project develops and validates a novel joint injectable anti-inflammatory sustained drug delivery system in client owned canines presenting with knee injury (cruciate ligament disease). Successful completion of this study will advance this new technology towards human clinical implementation and validate, for the first time, the safety and therapeutic efficacy of IL-1Ra delivered from mechanically activated microcapsules (MAMCs) compared to systemic and soluble IL-1Ra joint injections in a pilot clinical trial (executed through the PennVet Veterinary Clinical Investigation Center).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Public health relevance: Symptoms during cancer treatment are common, compromise patient quality of life and ability to tolerate treatment, and often go undetected at clinic visits. This project aims to combine smartphone and wearable sensor data with machine learning to remotely monitor symptoms during chemotherapy and to develop a system that automatically recommends patient-provider contact when severe symptoms are detected.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Characterization of the immune response before, during, and after administration of immunotherapy would allow researchers and clinicians to better understand how patients respond to these therapies and how resistance develops, as well as facilitate more informed decisions about therapy choice, dose, and target. One important marker of the immune response against cancer is the presence of mutated neoantigens in tumors, but a major unmet challenge is the ability to detect immune responses to neoantigens within tumors or in the peripheral blood. The proposed research seeks to apply a novel hydrogel-based platform for high throughput detection and expansion of neoantigen-specific immune responses in tumor- bearing mice and humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE Public Health Relevance: The limited intrinsic regenerative potential of large craniofacial bone defects represents a considerable challenge in oral and maxillofacial surgery. The long-term goal of this proposal is to develop novel tissue engineering platforms where mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) with functional organic cation transporters belonging to the solute carrier 22A gene family can be encapsulated within tunable metformin-releasing injectable scaffolds to potentiate regeneration of vascularized critical-sized bone defects. We anticipate this innovative project will lead to broader metformin-releasing tissue engineering platforms to benefit many patients in need of oral, craniofacial as well as orthopedic bone regenerative procedures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients undergoing extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) are at signiﬁcant risk of brain injury, yet no neuromonitoring is performed due to limitations of current devices. We propose to predict the severity of brain injury in patients undergoing ECMO using complementary multi-modal neuromonitoring devices based on hemodynamic and electrophysiological parameters, probing cerebral autoregulation, neurovascular coupling, and neuronal health. This approach will ultimately provide a means to monitor the risk of brain injury in critically-ill patients and optimize personalized treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to develop the Graph Artificial Intelligence for Precision identification of Alcohol use disorder (GAIPA), an evidence-driven, graph-based clinical informatics approach to transfer the knowledge learned from the AoU data to identify undiagnosed AUD cases in clinical care. The success of the proposed GAIPA model will provide a transferrable AUD classification model, bridge gaps between rich longitudinal EHR data and precision identification and management of AUD. This work will shift paradigms of big data and complex disease research, enabling EHR data to become part of daily AUD management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Post-stroke language deficits are exceedingly common and can be devastating to social relationships, vocational success, and independence in activities such as shopping, banking, texting, and emailing. We will characterize how language deficits resolve or improve over the first year after left hemisphere stroke, by carrying out longitudinal language assessments and brain imaging. We aim to identify demographic, genetic, and imaging variables that predict improvement in discourse comprehension, reading, spelling through (1) restoration of blood flow to brain specific regions, (2) repurposing of healthy brain areas to take over functions of areas damaged by stroke, or (3) development of compensatory strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately 30% of all Americans are infected with Helicobacter pylori, a bacterium responsible for a range of gastric conditions, including ulcer, gastritis, atrophy, gastric intestinal metaplasia, and cancer, and yet significant knowledge gaps remain regarding how to best care for patients infected with this bacteria, and specifically how to integrate molecular information about strain into clinical care. Furthermore, host response to H. pylori also affects the outcome of the infection, and our preliminary data suggest that stress exposures such as adverse childhood experiences and low socioeconomic status may be associated with poor outcomes. We hypothesize that the combination of infection with virulent H. pylori strains and stress exposure synergistically contribute to the development of premalignant disease in the stomach.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project seeks to document the frequency and duration of diarrheal disease and acute respiratory infection in early childhood, and assess how intergenerational disadvantage and household and community circumstances shape disparities in children’s health, illness, and healthcare utilization. The results of this project will allow child health programs and health systems to better address health disparities in illness and healthcare utilization among young children, and inform our understanding of the consequences of intergenerational disadvantage for children globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD), set as a public health priority by the World Health Organization, is one of the leading causes of death in the U.S.; however, a dearth of ADRD research data that consider dynamics across racial/ethnic groups beyond minimum standard racial/ethnic categories is detrimental to understanding a comprehensive picture of the current state of ADRD and its future. Hybrid sampling (HybS) that combines address-based sampling and respondent driven sampling conducted through the push-to-Web method is an attractive and practical methodological option for yielding a probability sample for racial/ethnic minority data. This project aims 1) to establish an inclusive probability sample national survey panel of the general population of adults ages ≥ 40 years old with an oversample of Asian Americans focusing on the granular subgroups of Chinese, Asian Indian, Filipino, Korean and Vietnamese, and of Latinx stratified by Afro-heritage using the push-to-Web HybS and 2) to study ADRD risks across racial/ethnic groups and the role of social networks on ADRD risks.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Cognitive deficits are a major determinant of the long-term disability associated with schizophrenia and other psychiatric disorders. Thus, an increased focus on developing novel therapeutic interventions targeting these deficits is highly warranted and important to the VA mission. Schizophrenia is associated with abnormal interactions between cortical regions. Thus, developing insights into circuit level changes that underlie the emergence of cognitive deficits represents an urgent challenge. Here we employ a multilevel, state of the art, approach to directly examine how basal forebrain modulation of cortical disinhibition helps to regulate functional network activity relevant to cognition. This work will inform novel therapeutic approaches to restore impaired network connectivity and cognition in schizophrenia and related disorders affecting veterans.

PHR: The proposed work could impact public health in the short term by identifying receptor interacting protein kinase- 1 as a key driver of brain injury and neurological outcome in the chronic period after intracerebral hemorrhage. IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) afflicts many veterans and results in distress, disability, and suicide. PTSD is characterized by the inappropriate and/or excessive activity of defensive responses. Defensive responses are normally adaptive changes in physiology and behavior that maximize an organism’s safety when faced with a threat; however, excessive activation of defensive responses lead to maladaptive behaviors. This proposal aims to understand the brain physiology underlying defensive response by mapping and decoding the neurophysiological signals across multiple brain sites and the connections between these sites in response to multiple threat stimuli. Naïve animals are exposed to threat both before and after a traumatic social defeat stressor to determine how this stressor affects the responses to threat. Optogenetic manipulation of neural signals is used to modify behavior. The overall goal is to understand how the brain controls these behaviors and to find potential targets for intervention in the treatment of illnesses like PTSD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current study seeks to investigate the mechanisms whereby a specific type of lung cell associated with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) accumulates and drives the pathology of this disease. To accomplish this, we have developed a new compound that selectively blocks the activation of a pathway that maintains these cells in the lung. Using cell-culture, and rodent models of IPF we will further test this pathway and assess how well this new compound could potentially treat IPF.

PHR: Project Narrative This project will investigate why some Mycobacterium tuberculosis infections remain in the lung while others disseminate to other parts of the body. It will focus on one outbreak strain with a high rate of dissemination to bone. Using animal models, the project aims to understand how infecting bacteria escape the initial site of infection and subsequently cause damage in other organs and tissues, including bone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Cancers are highly heterogeneous and the underlying mechanisms are driven in large part through mutations that are “silent”, but cause changes to protein isoform expression. This proposal will develop innovative, broadly applicable technologies to systematically link silent cancer mutations to splicing events and the functional impacts of their consequent protein isoforms. Such information will reveal highly specific cancer biomarkers, novel drug targets, and systems-biology-driven cancer treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative (Public Relevance Statement) Cardiac inotrope medications used to augment heart contractility during recovery from cardiac surgery carry steep tradeoffs between risks (e.g., myocardial ischemia, malignant arrhythmia) and benefits (e.g., enhanced perfusion to vital organs), and are independently associated with 3-fold increased mortality and complication rates. Aside from patients with advanced cardiogenic shock wherein inotropes are necessary for survival past the operating room, limited evidence exists to support the ability of inotropes to improve survival or reduce complications among the majority of 300,000 patients undergoing cardiac surgery each year, and as a result, inotrope practice patterns vary widely across clinicians and hospitals, contributing to wide variation in mortality and major complication rates. We seek to (i) identify patient, clinician, and institution phenotypes associated with inotrope practice patterns; (ii) characterize and quantify institutional barriers to inotrope practice change; and (iii) estimate context-specific causal effects of inotropes on outcomes through a novel integration of cardiac surgical databases which address unmeasured confounders historically biasing previous observational studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this study is to provide a comprehensive, robust, and generalizable test of multiple theory driven accounts of how negative and positive affect may be related to alcohol use behaviors. These data will test at what timescales, for what operationalization of affect and alcohol these associations are relevant, as well as when, how, and for whom these effects seem to be of greatest importance. This study will improve a mechanistic understanding of the role of affect in the development of alcohol use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Perinatal mood and anxiety disorders (PMADs) affect at least one in five birthing individuals and often underlie suicidal behavior and suicide itself. Environmental influences, such as individual level health or economic stressors, and macro stressors, such as restricted access to reproductive health care, may precipitate suicidal behavior. This study examines the impact of restricting reproductive health services on population health, including PMAD rates, suicidality and maternal health outcomes, and mental health service use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This project is of benefit to public health because, as visual disorders are on the rise, there is a greater need than ever to both understand the root causes of retinal degenerations, and to use this knowledge to develop preventive treatments and restorative therapeutics. We will use the cone-rich zebrafish animal system to dissect the role(s) played by STRA6 to modulate retinoid and JAK-STAT signaling in the RPE, examining the contribution of STRA6 to RPE cell survival and function. These studies will shed light on novel functions and mechanisms of STRA6, whose previous annotation has focused almost exclusively on its role as a retinoid transporter to maintain the visual cycle, and, in doing so, we will uncover new targets and routes of intervention to prevent loss of RPE cells, which underpin the health of the photoreceptors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because neurodegenerative and cardiac diseases are major causes of morbidity and mortality in this country. The proposed research exploits new transgenic mouse models that use the chemogenetic production of reactive oxygen species in blood vessels and neurons to identify the key oxidative stress pathways that cause human diseases, including Friedreich’s ataxia, cardiac hypertrophy, Alzheimer’s Disease and Alzheimer’s-related dementias. The discoveries made in the proposed research program may lead to the identification of new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Public Health Relevance: Intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasms (IPMNs) are cystic precursor lesions to pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) incidentally-detected by imaging in more than 500,00 Americans each year. There is an unmet need to discover noninvasive approaches to differentiate ‘low- risk/benign’ IPMNs that can be monitored from ‘high-risk/malignant’ IPMNs that warrant surgery and its associated risks of morbidity and mortality. In our parent award, we are evaluating the hypothesis that radiomic features extracted from preoperative computed tomography (CT) scans will more accurately predict IPMN pathology than conventional radiologic features, both individually and in combination with a plasma- based ‘miRNA genomic classifier’ (MGC). In this extension, we plan to 1) evaluate the value of artificial intelligence (AI)-driven CT deep learning radiomic features in predicting malignant versus benign IPMN pathology in retrospective and prospective cohorts, 2) evaluate telomere length and telomerase activity in the blood as candidate molecular markers of high-grade IPMNs or early-stage PDAC, and 3) use behavioral AI to predict malignant transformation among patients with a high risk to develop PDAC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Chlamydia is the most common cause of bacterial sexually transmitted infections and can lead to pelvic inflammatory disease, life-threatening ectopic pregnancies, and infertility in women. Disease is linked to the ability of Chlamydia to undermine human host defense and establish persistent infections. This research will define how Chlamydia induces inflammation but avoids clearance by human immune programs, and it will thereby pave the way towards the development of novel treatment options and improved vaccine strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative We propose to develop a new technology to ultrasensitively quantify proteins, DNA, and single extracellular vesicles in an integrated device, directly in patient blood, to address critical issues in multimodal diagnostics. In collaboration with the Abramson Cancer Center and building on prior work together on multi-modal diagnostics, we focus our attention on Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma -the third leading cause of cancer-related death in the United States with an overall 5-year survival of only 9%. In the proposed work, we will develop our technology to a level of maturity that it can measure multi-modal panels of relevant PDAC biomarkers at ultra-high sensitivity, high linearity, and dynamic range in plasma to diagnose PDAC at earlier stages and to more accurately guide the treatment of patients with PDAC than is currently possible.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Integrating statistical analyses of nationally representative data with quantitative and qualitative analyses of physiological, cognitive, social, and psychological data from a diverse lab-based sample to document and unpack how racial/ethnic disparities in exposure to family member deaths early in life may destabilize socioeconomic and family-building trajectories into young adulthood, this project will focus attention on a key domain through which this early trauma has lifelong consequences for health, elucidate biopsychosocial mechanisms underlying this life course process that are amenable to intervention, and identify potentially actionable supports for resilience. This theoretically grounded, policy-focused, and pilot-validated research can significantly address an overlooked channel in the intergenerational transmission of racial/ethnic inequality affecting vulnerable Americans, capturing the spirit of Healthy People 2030 and advancing many goals of NIH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  In response to PAR-21-138: Method to Extend Research in Time (MERIT) Award Extension Request, this 2- year MERIT extension proposes to enroll a sample of adults (ages 18-40; N=70) who are using e-cigarettes (vaped nicotine) daily or near daily and are co-using cannabis. The parent R37 study (R37 CA237245, PI McClure) is focused on the role of cannabis co-use on tobacco (cigarette) cessation, and this MERIT extension will leverage the methods, measures, and procedures of the parent R37 but with an expanded focus on e- cigarette cessation and the role of cannabis co-use as a barrier (or facilitator) to cessation. This MERIT extension represents an important, timely and logical next step to the parent R37 award, which will advance the field of co- use and contribute to understanding the relationship and treatment implications of tobacco/nicotine and cannabis co-use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inappropriate type I interferon (IFN) signaling is associated with excessive immunopathology during and after influenza A virus infection. We performed a genome wide over-expression screen for previously undescribed controllers of IFN signaling and identified the interferon stimulated gene ETV7 as a transcriptional suppressor of this pathway. The major goal of this application is to define the mechanisms underlying ETV7 function to enable novel intervention strategies which limit immunopathology and enhance lung regeneration after viral infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will shed light on relationships between physician practice consolidation, and delivery of care for an exceedingly common cancer. These issues have been virtually unstudied to date and have implications for specialty care in other disciplines that are experiencing similar trends in consolidation. Findings will have real-world implications for patients, who are naturally interested in getting the best possible prostate cancer care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kennedy’s disease is a progressive neurodegenerative disease caused by an abnormal androgen receptor (AR) protein. There is currently no effective treatment available to slow, stop, or reverse the disease. Based on the promising preclinical results obtained with our 1st generation selective AR degraders (SARDs), this R01 application proposes to perform structure-activity relationship (SAR) and mechanistic studies to optimize a lead SARD that will be developed for Kennedy’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Maintenance of ER protein homeostasis (proteostasis) is a fine balancing act between protein synthesis, folding and degradation. Mis-regulation of any one of these processes leads to perturbed ER proteostasis and activation of the unfolded protein response (UPR). ER stress and UPR activation is a major contributor to many human diseases. Here we investigate mechanisms that prevent protein mis-folding in the ER with a focus on how protein synthesis is regulated at the ER.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative – Osseosurface Electronics – Chronic Wireless Battery Interfaces for Osteoporosis Treatment and Discovery Osteoporotic fractures account for more hospital bed days than myocardial infarction, breast cancer or prostate cancer. Currently there is no method to measure bone health continuously in vivo resulting in suboptimal care. Here we propose the development of ultrathin wireless, battery free fully implantable monitors of bone health to enable management and discovery for osteoporosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Recently we discovered that cancer causes cachexia by disrupting the body’s natural resolution mechanism of inflammation caused by cellular debris, triggering both a lipid mediator and cytokine storm in mice. To stimulate the natural debris-clearing process (pro-resolution), we utilized resolvins, which are small molecule non-toxic lipid molecules produced by the human body. We’ve assembled a team of world-class investigators to study underlying mechanisms of resolution of inflammation as an entirely novel, paradigm-shifting approach to pre- vent and/or reverse cachexia in pre-clinical systems and patients.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Military personnel are involved in activities such as nuclear weapon testing (atomic veterans), nuclear power plant operation and nuclear accident cleanup that put them at high risk for radiation exposure. Radiation exposure can cause acute radiation syndromes associated with severe morbidity and mortality, and chronic long-term effects that culminate in development of cancer. The role of cytoplasmic sensors in radiation-induced acute radiation syndromes remain understudied. Here we examine the importance of RIPK2 signaling axis (an adaptor protein for cytoplasmic sensors NLRC1 and NLRC2) and RIPK2-associated microbiota in regulating radiation-induced acute sickness and death. Successful completion of this project will demonstrate a pathogenic role for RIPK2 in driving radiation-induced sickness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE A deadly lung disease caused by Mycobacterium abscessus, a cousin of the bacterium that causes tuberculosis, is becoming more prevalent worldwide, particularly in aging and immunocompromised individuals. Currently available therapies often fail to achieve cure due to the intrinsic resistance of M. abscessus to most approved antibiotics, several of which have serious side effects and must be injected. Here we propose to discover and optimize new medicines and better combine existing ones to improve the treatment of M. abscessus lung disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative of the Parent Grant The bioactive lipid, ceramide has very important roles in many pathological contexts including cancer and diabetes. Ceramide synthase (CerS) enzymes are crucial for ceramide production, however the basic molecular mechanisms of their regulation is largely unknown. The goal of this proposal is to establish and understand the molecular mechanisms of CerS1 regulation by Hsp27, and therefore will provide the knowledge for designing innovative therapies against cancer and other pathologies in which ceramide is implicated by identifying new methods to modulate CerS1 activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Every year over 1 million American adults and children develop overwhelming infection leading to a rotting of their body we call ‘sepsis’ and death in up to 1 of 4 afflicted, caused by too much inflammation, too little immunity, and toxic metabolism. In our previous funding period, we used ‘Watson’-like and ‘Twenty three and me’ and ‘Ancestry.com’-like machine learning approaches to figure out how to help each child to reduce inflammation and restore ability to kill infection with individually tailored treatments. We next figure out how to restore normal metabolism so that each child can live their longest and happiest life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Title: Lipidomics and structural genomics of cardiometabolic health in Samoan adults Project Period: 04/01/2023–03/31/2027 This project will explore the relationships between lipids, genes, environment, heart health, and obesity-related traits among Samoans, a Pacific Islander population with high rates of diseases like type 2 diabetes and heart disease. This study will focus on the lipidome, made up of biologically simpler lipid species than conventional cholesterol measurements, and on structural changes in the genome, which are expected to have larger effects than simpler genetic variants. Our discoveries will improve our understanding of the basic biology of lipids and how they affect heart health and obesity-related traits. We will also identify potential targets for interventions to improve health overall.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Skin-penetrating parasitic nematodes infect nearly a billion people and are a major cause of morbidity worldwide. This grant will investigate the behavioral, neural, and molecular mechanisms that underlie the process of skin penetration in these parasites. Our results will illuminate how skin-penetrating nematodes invade human hosts and may enable the development of novel nematode control strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Proliferating cells reprogram metabolism to supply critical metabolites and satisfy the increased demand for specific nutrients. During early T cell development, the generation of T cell receptor diversity relies on robust synthesis of the TCR, which requires abundant nucleotides and hexosamines for proper synthesis and folding. Our studies will elucidate how the de novo hexosamine biosynthesis pathway reprogram metabolism via regulation of mTOR signaling and pyrimidine metabolism to generate a diverse TCR repertoire.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it has a potential to establish the role of osteoblast bioenergetic and redox processes in defining bone phenotype and provide a scientific basis for new therapeutic approaches for bone aging. It will also advance the field by elucidating yet unknown mechanisms connecting the unique metabolic setup in osteoblasts, i.e. mitochondrial/glycolysis/pentose phosphate axis with bone phenotype. This is highly relevant to the NIH mission of developing fundamental knowledge that will help to reduce the burdens of human aging and disability.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Peripheral artery disease (PAD) is a cardiovascular disease manifesting from systemic atherosclerosis, which blocks the leg arteries and results in insufficient blood flow to the lower extremities. Limb ischemia from PAD is the most common disorder treated within the vascular surgery service at the Omaha Veterans’ Affairs Medical Center. PAD also accounts for one-third of the operations performed in the VA Medical Centers nationwide. This project aims to establish the feasibility and acceptability of a muscle oxygen-guided supervised exercise program for patients with PAD. We will determine the potential benefits of using this intervention over standard supervised exercise therapy. This modified intervention may enable patients to increase overall physical activity without the negative impacts on muscle structure and function. Increasing physical activity will decrease cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. If proven beneficial, our findings will lead to an improved exercise program that directly benefits veterans nationwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: We recently found that high expression of the collagen-modifying enzyme lysyl hydroxylase 2 (LH2) drives lung cancer metastasis due to a previously undetected collagen glucosyltransferase (GGT) activity. Based on our new mechanistic and structural insights into LH2 GGT’s pro-metastatic activity, we hypothesize that the unique structural features of LH2 GGT underlie its pro-metastatic activity. If our hypothesis is proven true, these findings will inform LH2b GGT inhibitor development and could have broad clinical applicability because LH2 has been implicated in the metastasis of multiple cancer types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Suboptimal human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine uptake has been an intractable problem since it was recommended for use in the US 12 years ago. Continued low uptake of HPV vaccine indicates that new systems-level approaches, beyond standard public health education campaigns, are needed to improve provider’s recommendations for HPV vaccination. We will utilize formative research to improve our existing TweenVax intervention, leading to an evaluation to assess the efficacy of the practice-, provider-, and patient/parent-level intervention package in improving HPV vaccine recommendations and uptake.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Autosomal Recessive Polycystic Kidney Disease (ARPKD) is a potentially lethal inherited kidney disease affecting children and young adults. Unfortunately, methods to sensitively measure kidney disease progression are lacking creating a barrier to conducting clinical trials in these patients. In the proposed studies, our collaborative multi-center research team will evaluate the capability of our multiple MRI biomarkers of cystic burden, kidney perfusion, and fibrosis to: (1) sensitively detect and stage ARPKD kidney disease across the spectrum of disease (Aim 1); (2) assess the progression of kidney disease over time in comparison to conventional clinical measures of kidney function (Aim 2); and (3) develop new free-breathing MR Fingerprinting methods to pave the way for assessments of kidney disease in very young children with ARPKD (Aim 3).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mammographic breast density is one of the strongest risk factors for breast cancer. Notably, a reduction in breast density over time translates to a decrease in breast cancer incidence. However, because adult dietary and lifestyle modifications have not been shown to reduce mammographic density, identifying a pathway that can be targeted to reduce breast density and breast cancer incidence is crucial. Buidling on recent findings, we propose a clinical trial to quantify the effect of RANKL inhibition on mammographic density in high-risk premenopausal women with dense breasts. Study findings could open up additional approaches to primary breast cancer prevention in high-risk premenopausal women, who do not have dominant genetic predisposition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: In a clinical trial, 240 participants with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) across 4 U.S. academic sites will be randomized to computerized, web-based high dose crosswords (4 puzzles per week), low dose crosswords (1 puzzle per week), or a health education control group for 12 weeks with subsequent booster sessions for a total of 78 weeks. Efficacy will be compared on measures of cognition, function, and change in MRI volumetric measures with exploratory analyses for change in plasma biomarkers. If crosswords training shows efficacy and dose effects are clarified, it could become a low-cost, home-based, scalable, cognitive enhancement tool for individuals with MCI, which is a common condition and major public health problem worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: We will test the global hypothesis that external bone size is associated with variation in hip strength-decline trajectory and fracture risk, independent of femoral neck aBMD. We leverage high resolution imaging and direct mechanical tests of cadaveric proximal femurs along with longitudinal hip DXA images collected for older men and women enrolled in MrOS and Health ABC to identify structural and material measures that explain the external-size specific fracture risks in terms of structural traits and trait interactions. Successful completion of the proposed aims will provide evidence of multiple biomechanical pathways leading to reduced proximal femur strength in older men and women and will identify sets of traits that best predict fracture risk for subgroups of individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The nervous system drives the initiation and growth of many cancers, establishing the targeting of nervous system-cancer interactions as a new therapeutic approach in oncology. To spur pioneering interactions among researchers in the fields of clinical oncology, cancer biology, and neuroscience, the proposed Cancer Neuroscience: An Emerging Hallmark symposium will feature seminars by a diverse team of leading experts in cancer neuroscience, with topics ranging from translational and basic biology to oncology, mental health, and quality of life issues for cancer survivors. The primary goal of the symposia will help fulfill the mission of the NCI of advancing scientific knowledge and help cancer patients have longer and healthier lives by exchanging data and driving thought-provoking discussions on the nervous system as a new actionable target in cancer treatment by a diverse forum of investigators and trainees.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research program utilizes a systematic approach to investigate new genetic discoveries associated with blood lipids and cardiovascular disease (CVD). The investigators aim to demonstrate this through a paradigm of functional characterization of newly discovered lipid-regulating genes using naturally-occurring genetic variants. This effort will help bridge the significant gaps in knowledge linking human genomic discoveries to new biology and therapeutic targets and provide a roadmap for how novel genomic loci, genes, and variants associated with blood lipids and CVD might be investigated in a systematic manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative One-third of the U.S. population has a detectable thyroid nodule and thyroid cancer is increasing in incidence and prevalence; yet the effects of current and emerging clinical practice on patients and related health care utilization are unknown. The proposed comprehensive simulation model of individuals with benign and malignant thyroid nodules in the U.S. population is a powerful, systematic approach to evaluating the impact of recent changes in practice guidelines and future advancements in the diagnosis, treatment, and surveillance strategies on patients with thyroid nodules and cancer. The insights gained through the proposed aims will identify strategies that have the most promise for increasing both length and quality of life, while enhancing the health and minimizing harm to our patients.

PHR: Project Narrative Diabetic kidney disease (DKD) and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) are common cause of end- stage kidney disease (ESKD) in the US and in our veterans. However, current regimen provides only partial therapeutic effects and the incidence and prevalence of these diseases remains high. Therefore, it is urgently needed to develop novel preventive and therapeutic measures for patients with DKD and FSGS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Millions of people in the U.S. and worldwide have been diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease (PD), a progressively debilitating disorder characterized by slowed and abnormal movement. Many patients with PD who no longer respond adequately to medications can be treated successfully with an FDA approved therapy known as deep brain stimulation (DBS), however results vary widely among individual patients and much remains unknown about how it works. Results from this study will provide a better understanding of how DBS and medical therapy change brain function to improve movement in patients, and lead to the refinement of current approaches and the development of new DBS strategies that provide a more consistent and beneficial therapeutic effect.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / LAY SUMMARY There is a critical need to develop and validate tools to assess cognitive function remotely (e.g., not in a clinical facility) for both research and clinical purposes. Mayo Test Drive is an easily accessible, web-based platform and brief cognitive screening instrument developed for remote self-administered cognitive assessment via multiple devices (e.g., smartphones, PCs, tablets) to ensure widespread utility in urban or rural environments. This project is relevant to the NIA's mission and will specifically (1) improve our understanding of the aging brain, Alzheimer's disease, and other neurodegenerative diseases and (2) promote broad use and dissemination of digital technology for early detection and monitoring of cognitive decline in aging, Alzheimer's disease and AD-related dementias.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Alcohol use disorder (AUD) is highly prevalent in Veterans, and while evidence-based treatments (EBT) are effective at reducing alcohol use, the rate of relapse if high. Anhedonia, i.e., a reduced interest in rewards, is widespread in Veterans, contributes to the maintenance of maladaptive alcohol use, and predicts poorer treatment outcomes. However, anhedonia is a multi-faceted deficit involving several mechanisms of goal- directed reward behavior, which are still poorly understood in relation to alcohol use and AUD outcomes. The proposed research will use computational modeling and functional neuroimaging to identify mechanistically driven anhedonic markers of alcohol recovery in Veterans with AUD completing standard care EBT. This project is expected to improve our understanding of how the relationships between anhedonia and alcohol use impact AUD recovery in Veterans, and to identify understudied mechanisms of change that are critical for developing new interventions to boost healthy reward processing in Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative Cardiac rehabilitation (CR) is effective at improving cardiovascular outcomes by supporting heart-healthy lifestyle changes, but these benefits are often not sustained after patients finish the program. Mobile health (mHealth) has the potential to provide ongoing support for behavioral maintenance after CR programs end, but to do so effectively, there is a need for new approaches to support engagement with mHealth interventions. We will develop algorithms and user interfaces that enable mHealth interventions to effectively adapt to a broad range of changes in individuals' lives so they can continue to be useful—and effectively support behavior change—over the long-term.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Abnormal brain development in DS begins in utero. It is critical to be aware of an altered initial brain anatomy in DS for better predicting what aspects of brain function will likely preferentially/precociously deteriorate, which would allow for potentially earlier/better prevention and treatment. Based on our promising results from in vivo MRI, we plan to confirm the findings using ex vivo MRI with significantly higher spatial resolution as well as polarization sensitive optical coherence tomography which provides micron-level spatial resolution, in order to identify detailed basis of the DS early brain abnormality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Many antidepressants show limited effectiveness in patients, which partially reflects the limited relevance of the models used to study depression-relevant behavior in animals to the human condition. The proposed study will test whether psychedelic drugs, such as psilocybin, can reverse the effects of three distinct manipulations known to induce depression-relevant behaviors in mice. Using both behavioral and EEG assessments, we intend to develop more suitable depression-relevant models and to find new, and possibly more effective, treatments for people with depression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative A loss of smell is associated strongly with pre-clinical Alzheimer’s Disease, yet the relationship between olfactory loss and disease progression are not understood. We have developed an approach to obtain human olfactory biopsies for single cell profiling, providing a means to directly compare neuroepithelial samples at any disease stage, focusing on sensory, supporting and immune cells. In our proposed studies, we will use this approach leveraging an Alzheimer’s Disease Research Center cohort to identify mechanistic insights into human olfactory loss as well as Alzheimer’s Disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: While the newer classes of diabetes medications have shown clinical benefits in patients with diabetic kidney disease (DKD) in randomized controlled trials, one of the major prescribing barriers is the lack of safety data in real-world patients with DKD, a complex, older population with multimorbidity and polypharmacy, who are at greater risk for adverse events and drug-drug interactions. This proposal’s goal is to develop a framework to optimize the safety of newer diabetes medications in real-world patients with DKD. This proposal will advance our understanding of these drugs’ safety and thus, will help overcome barriers to prescribing in patients with DKD who may largely benefit from them, greatly advancing the clinical care of patients with DKD.
