IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Heart disease poses a major health threat in the US, and there is a disproportionate burden of heart disease among African Americans. However, the environmental and/or genetic reasons remain incompletely defined. Our goal is to use novel technologies to study blood proteins to identify those most at risk so that preventive interventions can be made as early as possible – and to improve our understanding of the underlying disease mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: FGF21 is a particular hormone that is made by fat cells that may be important for the development of obesity, which is currently a major public health burden. The objectives of this proposal are to examine how FGF21 released from fat cells modulates the harmful metabolic effects of obesity, and whether FGF21 released from fat is different from FGF21 derived from other parts of the body such as the liver, where it is known to exert beneficial effects on health. Strategies to specifically target FGF21 released from fat cells could lead to new therapies to combat obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CRISPR has revolutionized our approaches to study cancer, allowing rapid functional interrogation at transcriptome-wide scales. However, single-cell sequencing compatible transcriptome-wide screens in autochthonous genetically engineered models remain a challenge. Here we propose a novel methodology to enable transcriptome-scale multiplex gain and loss of function CRISPR screens that is compatible with our robust MADR tumor modeling approach in human 3D organoid models and well-characterized “off-the-shelf” mouse lines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aggressive B cell lymphomas are a very common type of cancer with varied outcomes for patients—some are cured with standard treatment, but others are not. The goal of this research is to identify biomarkers that can identify which patients are likely to be cured, and which patients might need new treatments. The biomarkers may also tell us if certain types of immune targeting therapies would be useful for certain types of patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Overall outcome for patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) remains unfavorable. The limited applicability of allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (allo-HSCT) as well as the rise of the immunotherapy era highlights a pressing need to develop novel immune-stimulating drugs for AML eradication. To address this challenge, herein, we will determine whether targeting PRMT9 promotes a sustained leukemia-eliminating immunity and assess whether a PRMT9 inhibitor combined with an immune checkpoint inhibitor eliminates AML cells in-vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Many human illnesses, such as neuropsychiatric disorders are heritable, but the connection among genes, brain structure and neuropsychiatric disorders is not well understood. Through application of genetically-based cortical atlases and new statistical approaches in a large sample with brain imaging and genotyping data, we will identify genetic variants associated with structural variation of the human brain. These findings in turn may help us better understand the pathogenesis of neuropsychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this proposal is to identify novel mechanisms by which genetic variation gives rise to behavioral variation in behaviors comorbid with substance use disorders. We take a circuit-based approach and combine systems neuroscience with mouse genetics to find genes that causally alter the behavioral function of defined circuits in the brain. These results will provide new biological models to explain how DNA variants affect psychiatric disorder risk in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Statins are among the most effective medications to prevent and treat heart disease, but they are not prescribed routinely to people who would benefit from them, especially racial and ethnic minorities, women, and older adults. This study will use information from electronic health records and focus groups to identify patient, clinician, and health system barriers to statin use. This approach could be used to increase the use of statins as a way to reduce health disparities for millions of high-risk individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Intimate Partner Violence (IPV) is a major global problem that can lead to mental health problems such as depression and PTSD. We propose to test a family-based intervention, Multi-component family Intervention to Lower depression and Address intimate Partner violence (MILAP), that will engage women experiencing IPV, their husbands, and mothers-in-law. If successful, the results of this study can provide an intervention that will improve depression, address IPV, and reduce PTSD, and help us understand the mechanisms via which this intervention works.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is growing evidence in many neurological diseases, including traumatic brain injury (TBI), that prolonged activation of the innate immune system rather than repair can instead contribute to disease. It is not understood if or how microglia's impact on neuronal excitability might contribute. This proposal will establish how perineuronal satellite microglia and P2Y12 receptors can modify cell-type specific function in TBI and provide vital information that could influence clinically relevant treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: RELEVANCE Despite the growing list of new antiseizure drugs, status epilepticus remains the second most common life- threatening neurological emergency and triggers a series of neuropathological changes in survivals that can lead to lifelong epilepsy. Current medications merely provide symptomatic relief and are not effective in > 30% of patients, not to mention the unbearable side effects. The proposed research will uncover neuroinflammatory signaling that is essential to the development of spontaneous seizures, and thus might provide novel druggable targets to prevent epilepsy or modify its progression after status epileptics and other precipitating brain insults.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is one of the most common and debilitating health conditions among Veterans. Prolonged exposure (PE) is an effective treatment for PTSD that is commonly used in the VA, but it often fails to fully resolve PTSD in Veteran patients. Inhibitory learning is thought to be a driving force behind symptom reduction in exposure-based therapies like PE, but its role in PE has yet to be evaluated. By establishing inhibitory learning as a mechanism of PTSD improvement during PE, this study will validate a new therapeutic target that can be used to make PE a more effective and precise treatment. Additionally, by showing that inhibitory learning abilities at pretreatment predict PTSD improvement during PE, this study may produce a novel tool for determining which patients to enroll in PE. In this way, the proposed study has the potential to enhance the effectiveness of PE for all Veteran PTSD patients and yield an innovative method for identifying the specific Veterans who are most likely to benefit from this commonly used intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The molecular progression of Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) as measured by amyloidosis (Abeta) and tauopathy post mortem has not yet been explicitly linked to clinical biomarkers for measuring neurodegeneration, which renders in vivo diagnosis and effective intervention a challenge. Following the 2018 research framework published by the National Institute of Aging (NIA) and the Alzheimer’s Association (AA), MRI biomarkers have gained particular interest as non-invasive measures shown to correlate with clinical progression of AD; yet, they have not been shown to be specific to AD as current analytical tools remain inadequate for linking 3D macroscopic measures to underlying 2D microscopic measures of tau/Abeta. This work proposes to build a multi-modal, multi-scale image registration and analysis platform to integrate and correlate imaging data from 2D histology images and 3D MRI to establish the specificity of MRI biomarkers for AD and thereby enable their use in clinical practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer's Disease and Corticobasal degeneration are 2 of more than 20 “tauopathies” that are characterized by different forms of fibrillar tau aggregates and lack basic understanding of mechanism of neurotoxicity, disease development, and disease progression. Valosin-containing protein is an essential factor in proteostasis, the regulation and balance of the proteome, through removing proteins from complexes, membranes, and aggregates such as those formed by fibrillar tau and has recently been linked with a newly discovered tauopathy. This application proposes to obtain the first structures of valosin-containing protein with brain-derived tau fibrils from Alzheimer's Disease and Corticobasal degeneration patients and probe the mechanism of how valosin-containing protein interacts with brain-derived and recombinant tau fibrils.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We recently developed a form of neuromodulation termed SAINT that induces remission in 90% of individuals with treatment-resistant depression. SAINT-induced remission is associated with significant reductions in explicit suicidal cognition. This project aims to elucidate the nature of the suicidal cognition changes produced by applying SAINT to the DLPFC-sgACC of acutely suicidal inpatients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: Tuberculosis remains of utmost public health concern globally and domestically, with escalating public health threats including relentless global increase in multi-drug-resistance, disability even after the cure, and global pandemics. The ‘syndemic’ of tuberculosis and HIV/AIDS and the ongoing coronavirus pandemic adds complexity to public health control. In this proposal, we seek to harness the powerful process called autophagy, an endogenous anti-microbial defense and tissue-protective mechanism available to every cell in the body. We have developed the concept that autophagy and its component Atg8ylation can clear the intracellular bacteria and protect lungs against M. tuberculosis-induced pathology. To unleash this internal power that our cells possess, we will identify specific proteins and processes carrying out autophagic control of M. tuberculosis, suppression of inflammation, and protection against active disease. This will enable us and others to develop new autophagy-based therapies and drugs to prevent and treat tuberculosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cells maintain sophisticated mechanisms that ensure replicated chromosomes are accurately transmitted to daughter cells during division. When these mechanisms fail, cancer and other diseases are the result. The studies described in this grant examine an unsuspected and unexplored set of mechanisms that operate during the final stages of cell division (anaphase/telophase) to ensure accurate chromosome transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: To make and store insulin, pancreatic islet ß-cells must make large quantities of the precursor protein, proinsulin, and fold it properly. However, we have now definitively identified misfolded proinsulin that occurs in the islets of human beings or rodents, and is markedly worse in individuals with insulin gene mutations, or in islets prior to the onset of type 2 diabetes. This proposal aims to understand the mechanism of how proinsulin misfolding occurs, and how to limit its damage, in order to prevent diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CNS cancers such as diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma (DIPG) are notoriously difficult to treat, due to both their anatomical location as well as the lack of highly effective treatment options. To address these issues, our group has identified a common DIPG mutation in the phosphatase PPM1D that confers metabolic defects which can be exploited for therapeutic gain. Using in vitro and in vivo preclinical model systems, this proposal seeks to develop and utilize nanoparticle-encapsulated inhibitors of NAMPT, an NAD biosynthesis enzyme, to target and kill mutant PPM1D cells and tumors with high efficacy and low toxicity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Dental caries is one of the most prevalent dysbiotic diseases worldwide. Since caries itself is  irreversible, focus should be on caries prevention. This study aims to understand the role of  commensal streptococci in promoting oral health. Specifically, we will identify how a common  molecular trait of commensal streptococci, the production of H202 by the pyruvate oxidase, can be  used as predictor of caries risk before caries manifestation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Pregnant women and women using oral contraceptive agents(OCA) have a 2-3 times greater risk of thrombosis (spontaneous clotting that blocks blood flow), and obese women using OCA have a dramatic 24 times greater risk of thrombosis. We have identified gene regulatory proteins that suppress expression of a key anti-clotting protein, Protein S. Our project will identify the molecular mechanisms of OCA and obesity-mediated PS suppression and thereby suggest new therapies to mitigate thrombosis in women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is evidence that exercise is beneficial to the brain in aging and Alzheimer’s Disease (AD), but findings are mixed and the mechanisms that underlie this benefit are unknown. The heterogeneity of benefit may be explained in part by individual differences in the acute biomarker response to exercise, which is the repeated acute and transient changes that occur during and immediately following exercise. The acute biomarker response and its relationship to relevant brain outcomes has not been characterized in elderly or AD individuals. Understanding these relationships will help us understand peripheral metabolites affect the brain and aid in the design of future exercise intervention trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One of the most pressing problems in breast cancer treatment is to devise new therapies for estrogen receptor-expressing tumors that do not respond adequately to anti-estrogen therapies. For these tumors, our laboratory discovered that a related hormone receptor, the glucocorticoid or stress hormone receptor, can also be targeted to help reduce tumor growth driven by estrogen. In this project we will perform experiments to understand the mechanisms whereby these two hormone receptors act in breast cancer, with the overall goal of developing new, effective and relatively non-toxic treatments for breast cancer.

PHR: Project Narrative This work will define new requirements for classical dendritic cell type-2 (cDC2) positioning, homeostasis and function in spleen and lung. The work will establish the role of the CD97 adhesion-G-protein coupled receptor pathway in splenic cDC2s using flow cytometric, cell signaling and imaging approaches. Studies in EBI2 conditional knockout mice and mice unable to make oxysterols that function as EBI2 ligands will determine how this chemoattractant system determines lung cDC2 distribution and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proteolytic cleavage of ultra-large von Willebrand factor by ADAMTS13 is crucial for normal hemostasis. However, the mechanism underlying the regulation of this process remains to be poorly understood. The proposed study aims to determine the mechanical unfolding profile of VWF-A2 in the absence and presence of coagulation factor VIII, to elucidate the molecular mechanism of direct interactions between VWF-A2 and factor VIII, and to assess the physiological relevance of factor VIII-dependent regulation of VWF proteolysis by ADAMTS13 under a mechanic force and pathophysiological conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative While the degeneration of basal forebrain cholinergic neurons (BFCNs) is a well-known feature of Alzheimer’s Disease, the pattern of degeneration and the extent to which this phenomenon contributes to cognitive decline remain elusive. The research proposed here seeks to define how the neural circuitry associated with BFCNs is altered throughout Alzheimer’s Disease progression and aims to evaluate the effects of targeted, cell-type specific manipulations of BFCNs. Studies such as this are essential to further our understanding of the circuit pathology underlying Alzheimer’s Disease and identify potential therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Despite enormous recent progress in treatment and supportive therapies for acute myeloid leukemia (AML), it accounts for the highest percentage of leukemic deaths, and less than a third of patients will become long-term survivors. We recently discovered that specific AML-associated mutations in two genes, isocitrate dehydrogenase-1 and -2 (IDH1/2), block DNA repair pathways and lead to sensitivity to drugs which block these same pathways. Here, we seek to develop highly effective combinations against AMLs with IDH1/2 mutations, as well as mutations in other AML-related genes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE: The skin functions as a potent immune organ, rendering the readily accessible cutaneous microenvironment an attractive target that can be locally engineered to induce and regulate systemic immune responses. Increasing age is associated with changes in immune function (immunosenescence) that result in increased susceptibility to diseases and poor vaccine responses in older adults. This proposal is designed to bring together very recent and significant advances in dermatology and skin biology to address critical problems in human health. Specifically, we propose to modulate local immune regulatory circuits in the skin to enable the induction and regulation of antigen-specific systemic immune responses. The studies we propose will investigate the effect of locally delivered immune modulators on the mechanisms underlying cutaneous immune regulation in young and aged skin. Importantly, our studies include translational studies using living human skin to enable the rapid advancement of novel cutaneous immunomodulation strategies into clinical trials. An improved understanding of these underlying skin immune mechanisms will enable the development of localized skin targeted immunization strategies to induce antigen-specific systemic immune responses for the prevention or treatment of a broad range of diseases across the lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioids are commonly prescribed medications for a variety of pain conditions; however, these medications carry significant risks due to their addictive potential and lethality via respiratory depression. The mechanisms underlying opioids’ beneficial and harmful effects are still unknown and few successful treatments for pain have been created since opioid use became widespread. This proposal aims to characterize the effects of opioids on prefrontal cortex output neurons and to dissociate the prefrontal cortex circuits that underlie opioid analgesia and addiction to allow for more precise targeting of future therapeutics.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Adolescent relationship victimization (ARV), including physical, sexual, cyber or psychological abuse, reproductive coercion, and sexual exploitation, is a public health problem with broad, lifelong negative outcomes that result in significant cost to both individuals and society. The emergency department (ED) offers unique opportunities to promote healthy relationships among large numbers of at-risk youth, but current interventions are limited by disclosure-based delivery, limited efficacy, addressing limited forms of abuse, and missed opportunities to provide point-of-care harm reduction resources. Our proposal to adapt the Healthcare Education Assessment and Response for Teen Relationships (HEART) intervention for the ED setting will result in a novel intervention that is delivered universally, addresses ARV comprehensively, and links adolescents to point-of-care harm reduction resources to improve health outcomes across multiple domains, contributing to disruption of generational cycles of violence and early childbearing

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Early onset anhydramnios from fetal renal failure, which affects > 1 in every 2000 pregnancies in the United States per year, leads to pulmonary hypoplasia that is fatal in the neonatal period. This multicenter prospective trial will rigorously test the first ever viable therapy of serial amnioinfusions, to assess short- and long-term safety, feasibility and efficacy to treat this fatal disease. This work will fill critical gaps in knowledge and help optimize the chance that fetuses with early onset anhydramnios are born as healthy as possible with the best chance of long-term survival.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Pregestational diabetes induces neural tube defects (NTDs) in the offspring, one of the most common birth defects in human. Yet, the molecular mechanism underlying the teratogenicity of maternal diabetes is still unclear. This project will unravel the mechanism underlying maternal diabetes-induced autophagy impairment leading to NTDs. The proposed mechanistic studies will provide a basis for the therapeutic development of autophagy activator, unfolded protein response inhibitor and microRNAs as new prevention strategy against diabetic embryopathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The physiological functions of beta-secretase- 1 (BACE1), the rate-limiting protease in the formation of AD amyloid plaques, is incompletely known, particularly at the level of the synapse in different neuronal circuits. This project will shed light on BACE1’s function in regulating the activity of excitatory neurons, synapses, and circuits in the hippocampus, which will provide critical insight into our fundamental understanding of learning and memory, synaptic transmission and plasticity, and the development of AD therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Childhood-onset systemic lupus (cSLE), a devastating disease with high morbidity and mortality, especially among adolescents and young adults (AYA) of color and low-income, requires engagement in SLE care to prevent poor outcomes. Depression is highly comorbid with cSLE and may contribute to disengagement in care, along with socio-demographic, clinical, and other psychosocial factors. This research will investigate specific depression symptoms as potential contributors to disengagement in AYA with cSLE and pilot a mobile app intervention targeting engagement in care and providing psychological support in a vulnerable population of predominantly low-income, Black and Hispanic AYA from The Bronx, New York.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the accelerating expansion of online resources for modern life science education and training, the reality is that development of molecular biology laboratory-based skills requires `hands-on' instruction, preferably in a research-oriented context. Educational strategies that rely on lecture alone or traditional, but outdated, laboratory experiences ineffectively prepare the current and future generations of the US biomedical workforce. New paradigms are needed for molecular biology lab training that are flexible, inclusive, broadly applicable and supportive of inter-institutional cooperation, all of which is addressed in the proposed project.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The recent FDA approval of sotorasib, a direct pharmacological inhibitor of KRASG12C, marks a critical milestone in the treatment of lung cancer, but primary or acquired resistance remain major obstacles in sustaining durable patient responses to this therapy. Based on compelling preliminary data, this proposal seeks to test the hypothesis that combined inhibition of KRASG12C plus the intracellular recycling process of autophagy will lead to superior tumor control in preclinical models. We will also test how genetic alterations that cooperate with KRASG12C to promote lung carcinogenesis, such as silencing of LKB1, influences response to KRASG12C inhibition to develop a deeper mechanistic understanding of these cellular processes and potential clinical impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The formation of the distal air sacs (alveolarization) requires the development of blood vessels by the process of angiogenesis. Disruption of angiogenesis and alveolarization in infants causes bronchopulmonary dysplasia, the most common complication of premature birth. Our studies will explore if lung immune cells regulate angiogenesis in the developing lung, and identify new pathways to allow the development of therapeutic strategies to promote lung growth and regeneration in both infants and adults with lung disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE In contrast to children with sickle cell anemia (SCA) in whom stroke prevention screening has been highly successful, methods to identify adults with SCA at highest risk of new or recurrent stroke have not been developed and are urgently needed. This study uses multiple novel brain imaging techniques to measure differences in brain oxygen consumption, brain blood flow, and brain structure in adults with SCA that progress to develop new strokes, and also to understand how these methods can be used to evaluate the effect of curative SCA treatments on brain health. Study findings are intended to improve stroke risk assessment and allow individualized care to eventually prevent strokes in adults with SCA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Adolescent major depressive disorder (MDD) is a potentially debilitating disorder which increases the risk for suicide, and recently, rising youth mental health concerns since 2021 have been declared a national emergency; yet, treatment efficacy continues to fall short in subsiding depressive symptoms. The goal of this proposal is to improve our understanding of the role reward processing and reward-related learning behaviors play in adolescents with MDD, and aims to investigate how neurobiological reward mechanisms in adolescence are related to future reward-related behavior. In building a stronger framework of reward-learning behavior and neurobiological marker predictability of future reward-learning behavior in adolescents, the potential findings of this proposal may better inform individualized treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The cullin-RING ligases (CRLs) are under intense investigation as targets for human therapeutics. The multi- purpose drug thalidomide is already known to target a CRL, and a novel potent inhibitor of CRLs named Prevonedistat is currently under investigation in clinical trials as a cancer therapy. Most recently, CRLs are being employed by proximity-inducing drugs called proteolysis-targeting chimeras (PROTACs) to promote the degradation of disease-causing proteins, and the work proposed in this grant is likely to help in the development of these human therapies that exploit the CRLs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Plasmodium sporozoites are transmitted to a vertebrate host by Anopheles mosquitoes. We have shown that mosquito saliva proteins can influence the infectivity of sporozoites, and identified two sporozoite associated mosquito saliva proteins, SAMSP1 and SAMSP2. We will now determine the effects of SAMSP1 and SAMSP2 on Plasmodium infection in vitro and in vivo; this will lead to a greater understanding of the earliest phase of Plasmodium infection of a vertebrate host and may facilitate the development of a potential vector-based malaria vaccine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Post-traumatic osteoarthritis (PTOA) is a type of joint disease that develops after joint injury, and there are currently no effective treatments to halt or reverse this debilitating condition. This research will study whether genetically-modified adult stem cell-derived chondrocytes can block inflammation to slow down the progression of PTOA and determine their mechanism of action. We will inject modified and unmodified stem cells into mouse knee joints after injury and use multiple experimental measures to characterize the potential positive effects of this novel cellular treatment as well as highlight new targets for the treatment of PTOA in mechanistic studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The aim of this proposal is to hold an annual, full-week advanced gene mapping course at The Rockefeller University in New York City. The course is directed towards advanced researchers with knowledge in statistics and genetics and will provide participants with information on the latest methods to identify pathogenic suscptibility variants for complex traits and disease. Thirty- four participants will be admitted to the course and travel stipends will be provided to ten trainees who are either pre-doctoral students or post-doctoral fellows to cover the cost of airfare and hotel.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer is still the second leading cause of death in the US, and many challenges still remain to cure this devastating disease Therefore, it is imperative to establish a sustainable program to train and educate the next generation of scientists and clinicians, who must have broad knowledge and the ability to communicate and work with colleagues. The goal of the proposed Translational Oncology Training program (TOTP) is to ensure that the next generation of cancer researchers are equipped with the tools and knowledge that will enable them to bring bench-top discoveries into clinical trials and vice versa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Oral bacteria play a key role in human health and in diseases such as tooth decay and gum disease, and a suspected role in heart disease, stroke and pre-term birth. The proposed research will provide tools, genetic information, and bacterial strains for scientists to understand the interactions between people and their oral bacteria and viruses. Based on this information, health professionals will be better able to understand, prevent, diagnose, and treat diseases caused by oral microbes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Childhood undernutrition is common in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs), and affects not only child health, but also young adult health, cognition and socioeconomic productivity. The present proposal extends this body of evidence on early nutrition effects to mature adulthood and aging. The potential for childhood nutritional intervention to relieve some of the health, cognitive and socioeconomic declines of later life suggests future benefits for older individuals and their families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The prevalence of obesity continues to increase in the US and obesity increases the risk of cancer. While it is common practice to apply a dosing cap, current recommendations for the treatment of obese cancer patients is full body surface area chemotherapy dosing regimens despite some evidence suggesting that these patients may have exacerbated drug toxicities. Given that obese individuals are more likely to undergo anti-cancer treatments, there is a need for studying the complex over-lap between obesity and cancer; my proposed study will examine the mechanisms underlying obesity’s impact on the off-target toxicities associated with chemotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT TITLE: Chemical Biology Studies of the Dynamics and Inhibition of Peptidoglycan Biosynthesis PROJECT NARRATIVE The research proposed in this MIRA application seeks to continue the development of fluorescent D-amino acid (FDAA) probes for detailed study of the dynamics of peptidoglycan (PG) synthesis and bacterial cell division and cell separation. We will also continue our ongoing studies of cyclic peptide antibiotics that inhibit bacterial cell wall biosynthesis, either through direct inhibition of glycan polymerization or through inhibition of lipid recycling. The lipid recycling pathway is not well-defined; its elucidation may reveal novel targets for antibacterial development and provide new opportunities to address the public health threat posed by antibiotic resistance.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Narrative The fungus Candida albicans causes significant morbidity and mortality in the United States, particularly among individuals that have a weakened immune system such as cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy or transplant recipients. Using animal models of Candida colonization and infection, my laboratory has uncovered fungal regulatory genes that are key determinants of the Candida-host interplay. We will study of these regulatory systems, their associated traits and the molecular mechanisms whereby they effect the interactions with mammalian cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Antibiotic resistant bacteria are a growing crisis that not only threaten our ability to treat infections but also advances of modern medicine that rely on antibiotics, such as transplants, chemotherapy and even routine surgeries. Heteroresistance is an underappreciated and emerging form of antibiotic resistance which is poorly understood. The Heteroresistance Interdisciplinary Research Unit (HR-IRU) will elucidate the mechanisms causing heteroresistance, its dynamics and prevalence among clinical isolates, leading to translational interventions to improve human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: When a taste is placed on our tongues, we must decide whether to push it to the back for swallowing or to the front for ejecting, a decision that depends on our experience with the taste -- the process that involves the amygdala and cortex, whereby we learn to reject a potentially harmful taste. While these two forebrain structures are known to be reciprocally connected, and this connection is vital for learning, little is known about how amygdala and cortex work together to make learning happen. The work proposed in this grant will answer this question, testing whether and how activity in the amygdala-cortical pathway enables cortical neurons to make the response changes that are necessary for learning, and also provide a more systemic understanding of taste learning which will help us to develop tools to aid parents with a wide range of child feeding issues, and to cure vexing taste abnormalities such as develop during pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: This research seeks to develop innovative statistical methods for, and address several gaps in, the longitudinal analysis of heterogeneous and high-dimensional neuroimaging and -omics data, combined with clinical and demographic features, towards the ultimate goal of advancing precision medicine for Alzheimer's Disease (AD). The primary goal is to build predictive models for disease progression in AD that incorporates unknown interactions between imaging and -omics features as well as supplementary information such as gene pathways, while accounting for heterogeneity resulting from observed as well as latent confounders. To our knowledge, our project is one of the first to develop a sophisticated integrative statistical framework for studying the trajectory of disease progression in AD using longitudinal cognitive and brain imaging data and baseline clinical, and -omics data, which provides valuable computational tools for early detection in AD that is of tremendous clinical importance in delivering patent centric outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: This is the second renewal application of the Alpert Medical School Summer Research Program (AMSSRP). The  overall goal of the AMSSRP is to provide  12  medical students with the opportunity to have a mentored research experience annually under the guidance of Brown University faculty. Designated faculty trainers are the principal investigators for research programs focused on the molecular basis and pathology of cardiovascular, pulmonary, and blood diseases and/or disease outcomes and prevention. The current program offers 8 medical students, who have just completed their 1  year of medical school, a 9 week summer research st experience that includes a collaborative, multidisciplinary, mentored research project, didactic training, and career development activities to enhance their understanding, and give them the hands-on experience of a career as a physician-scientist. The AMSSRP is geared to expose students to the critical role played by physician-scientists in translational research and to inspire these students to embark on this career path of exploration and discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epidemiological data strongly suggest worse treatment burden and outcomes for comorbid anxiety and depression (AD-MDD) than depression (MDD) alone, but these groups are often collapsed in mechanistic studies and clinical trials. Our pilot data suggest striking differences between AD-MDD and MDD on multiple measures of threat sensitivity but it is unclear if these differences are in “acute threat/fear” or “sustained threat/anxiety”. The present study seeks to delineate threat sensitivity between AD-MDD, MDD and AD in terms of “fear” and “anxiety” using electromyography, fMRI and an acute pharmacological manipulation to establish circuit based treatment targets for AD-MDD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Neural circuit health and function rely on the active transport of mitochondria and maintenance of their health. Disruption of mitochondrial transport and deficits in mitochondrial health are associated with neurodegenerative diseases including Alzheimer’s disease. This application proposes to investigate the molecular regulation of mitochondrial transport and the role this process has in the maintenance of a healthy mitochondrial population in neurons to better define the pathology and therapeutic pathways relevant to neurodegenerative disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Diarrheal disease is a leading cause of childhood morbidity and mortality in the developing world. The goal of this work is to understand the nutritional signals that regulate the virulence of bacterial pathogens that cause diarrhea. Armed with this understanding, a simple dietary intervention may be devised to mitigate or prevent disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common bacterial cause of sexually transmitted infections (STI) in the world today that can lead to the severe sequelae including pelvic inflammatory disease, life-threatening ectopic pregnancy, and infertility. We lack a fundamental knowledge of the natural history of urogenital and rectal C. trachomatis infections that are likely interconnected and influenced by the respective microbiomes and host immune responses in each site. The objective of this research, therefore, is to elucidate the role of endocervical, vaginal and rectal microbiota and host immune responses in the acquisition and prevention of C. trachomatis among a high-incidence cohort of women to aid in designing strategies to decrease the growing global epidemic of C. trachomatis STIs and their devastating sequelae especially among neglected populations who have the highest rates of these infections.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this proposal we aim to define the mechanisms of IFN2 induction and its impact on interferon signaling and target cell phenotypes at the site of HIV transmission using longitudinal mucosal sampling from the ongoing clinical trial. In addition to providing crucial information on IFN signaling in HIV infection, the results of this study will provide key information on the role of pre-existing inflammation and the role of timing and duration of exogenous IFN stimulation on generation of potent antiviral immune responses in prevention and treatment of viral infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The goal of our laboratory is to understand the mechanisms of action of volatile anesthetics (VAs) in order to optimize clinical care and understand control of consciousness. We discovered that VAs inhibit mitochondrial function, producing specific defects in excitatory neurotransmission. We are extending the studies of VAs and mitochondria to understand arousal from the anesthetic state, and how VAs produce undesired long-term effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE Post-surgical opioids contribute substantially to the burden of opioid misuse, opioid use disorder, and overdose, which caused nearly 70,000 U.S. deaths in 2020. The partial opioid agonist buprenorphine represents a potential alternative; this study will evaluate its abuse potential and determine its feasibility and acceptability for postoperative analgesia. Results may lead to new practices for treating postoperative pain that confer lower risk of opioid-related harms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Staphylococcus aureus is a highly virulent and widely successful pathogen that is speculated to be the most common cause of human infection. With the continued emergence of multi-drug resistant isolates of S. aureus (such as MRSA), there is an urgent need to understand the mechanisms by which this deadly pathogen causes disease. This proposal seeks to explore the contribution of a membrane associated, C-terminal processing protease to S. aureus virulence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 1 million Americans have Familial Hypercholesterolemia (FH) and 90% of them are undiagnosed and untreated, with substantial disparities in Black and African American people, Asian people, and women. Cascade screening is an evidence-based practice that includes contacting and screening biological relatives of index cases that is cost-effective and has the potential to save lives. The proposed work has the potential to radically impact public health by testing which patient-facing implementation strategies, designed with key stakeholders, are most effective in increasing cascade screening in partnership with the FH Foundation. This clinical trial will take place in Penn Medicine and will use principles from behavioral economics to increase cascade screening while also gathering information about effectiveness and mechanisms in order to inform large-scale equitable implementation efforts nationally to save the lives of all Americans with FH.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Veterans with leg amputations have limited footwear options because their artificial feet do not change shapes for different shoes. Studies have shown that women with amputations receive more frequent prosthetics care than men, but are less satisfied with the fit, comfort, and appearance of their prostheses. Our previous research indicates that women Veterans would like to be able to wear a broader variety of footwear, and those who perceive more footwear limitations tend to have poorer body image and community participation. A new prosthesis designed by our group allows Veterans with amputations to use their footwear of choice using 3D-printed artificial feet with a single ankle. Our novel prosthesis will be tested in this project with women Veterans with amputations to determine the impact of improving footwear options on body image and community participation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Although the nasal mucosa is arguably the most frequently infected tissue in mammals, the cellular immune landscape that pathogens encounter upon entry into the nasal mucosa remains largely unexplored. Preliminary results for this project suggest that the nasal mucosa at steady state harbors a large population of extravascular neutrophils that are composed of three subsets which each display unique phenotypic and molecular characteristics. Based on extensive preliminary data, this project will test the hypothesis that beyond phenotypic diversity, each nasal neutrophil subset has a distinct origin, accesses the NM by discrete mechanisms, and exerts specialized functions in host defense and tissue homeostasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative (PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE) Acute intestinal injury is a major limiting factor in the recovery of radiation victims and some cancer patients. There is currently no FDA-approved treatment. The proposed work will provide novel insights on epithelium- immune interactions critical for intestinal recovery, and help establish temporal STING/Type 1 interferons as novel and normal tissue selective therapeutic targets to treat radiation-induced acute intestinal injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Proteins are long chains that must fold into specific three-dimensional structures to carry out their functions, which include digesting nutrients, making muscles contract, and enabling communication of neurons in the brain, among many others. Like long strands of yarn quickly become entangled if not organized into balls, proteins that fail to fold into their functional structures promptly tend to clump together into aggregates, which can be detrimental to cellular and organismal function and is associated with neurodegenerative diseases, including Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases. Our mechanistic studies will clarify how proteins fold into their functional structures and avoid aggregation, providing fundamental insights into disease mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: Project Narrative  This proposal investigates the therapeutic potential of using hypothermia to restore activity of temperature-sensitive p53 mutants in mouse tumor models. The p53 tumor suppressor is frequently inactivated by mutations in cancer. Currently no approved drugs are available for restoring the activity of mutant p53. Although p53 missense mutants are inactive at 37°C, ~14% are temperature-sensitive (ts) that regain activity at 32°C. The p53 ts mutants represent a unique class that may be activated by mild hypothermia, which is currently standard of care for post- cardiac arrest patients. We have established conditions for inducing controlled hypothermia in mice. Preliminary experiments demonstrated the ability of hypothermia to induce regression and stable remission of tumors expressing ts mutant p53. We will use this system to further investigate conditions that can improve the efficacy of ts p53 targeting and achieving long-term remission. We will also test the effect the hypothermia against clinically-relevant patient-derived xenograft models (PDX) expressing ts mutant p53, and against spontaneous tumors developed in a mutant mouse with germline ts p53 mutation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The synthetic sphingolipid SH-BC-893 (893) activates an evolutionarily-conserved growth control pathway that kills cancer cells while sparing normal proliferative cells. This project will establish whether 893’s unique, pleiotropic mechanism of action makes it more robust, and therefore less susceptible to the development of drug resistance, than existing therapies. Whether 893 overcomes resistance to FDA-approved cancer therapies will also be assessed.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute neurological complications, including intracerebral hemorrhage, cerebral edema, cerebral vasospasm, and ischemic stroke, are a leading cause of postpartum severe maternal morbidity and mortality in individuals with preeclampsia. We propose to apply a novel, non-invasive neuromonitoring approach to the management of BP in postpartum preeclampsia in a single-center, Phase II clinical trial, PROMIS (PROtecting Maternal brains from Injury and Stroke). We will use near-infrared spectroscopy monitoring to calculate personalized limits of cerebral autoregulation in 20 individuals with postpartum preeclampsia with severe features (Aim 1); and pilot the use of autoregulation-guided BP goals for treatment of postpartum preeclampsia with severe features in an additional 20 individuals with (Aim 2).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This program is designed to train the next generation of leaders in pediatric hematology-oncology biomedical science. The focus is on providing a strong guidance and mentoring around investigations pertaining to areas of clinical and basic research at the forefront of pediatric hematology-oncology including, but not limited to, genomics, epigenomics, developmental biology, cellular therapies, clinical trial design, and survivorship. Qualified trainees, both MD’s and MD/PhD’s, will be selected for their potential to assume academic positions in pediatric departments at major medical schools. The training program compliments multiple other existing training programs in the Department of Pediatrics and the Washington University School of Medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE New biological and biomedical data are now collected in unprecedented pace and analyzing such complex data has become a research bottleneck. Graphical causal models have recently emerged as attractive methods to model complex systems because of their flexibility, efficiency and interpretability, but they have limitations on the types of data and size of datasets they can process. In this project, we are proposing to develop new causal learning methods for a variety of datasets; and test them on synthetic and real-life data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Addictive opiate drugs such as morphine and heroin activate the same cellular receptors as endogenous opioid neuropeptides, yet produce pathological effects after prolonged or repeated administration. We seek to understand the underlying cell biology and biochemistry of these drug effects that yield new insights to pathology or new therapeutic targets for the treatment of opiate tolerance, dependence and addictive disorders. Beyond specific relevant to opioid receptors, the proposed studies address mechanistic aspects of GPCR signaling and regulation with broad biomedical relevance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Keeping heart failure patients at home with a low symptom burden after hospital discharge is challenging. This project aims to adapt a computer-interface telephonic interactive voice response system that monitors symptoms and provides real-time, self-management coaching messages based on heart failure patient- reported outcomes. This system has the strong potential to be widely disseminated into clinical practice leading to improved patient outcomes through better self-management behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative To address the critical need for empirically supported non-pharmacological interventions for attention-deficit/ hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), we will test Trigeminal Nerve Stimulation (TNS), a novel, minimal risk, non- invasive neuromodulation treatment, within a large independent sample of children aged 7-12 years old at two independent research sites (UCLA, Seattle Children’s Research Institute). In addition, we will test the underlying neural mechanism of TNS treatment as a mediator of ADHD symptom change. Finally, we will identify baseline behavioral and cognitive predictors of positive treatment response to TNS in order to inform a personalized treatment approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The burden of cancer in Nigeria, Africa's most populous country, is large and growing, and there is a need for increased research capacity to generate evidence to inform effective treatments, cancer control programs, and policies. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Creating an effective and scalable weight loss intervention is fundamental to treating obesity on a population level. This proposal seeks to optimize a standalone digital intervention for weight loss by identifying which self- monitoring components (tracking diet, physical activity, or body weight), alone or in combination, maximize success while minimizing burden. This line of work has potential for important public health impact by enhancing weight loss in digital treatments that can reach broad populations of adults with overweight/obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Oral cancer patients suffer from severe, chronic pain, which is induced by release of mediators from the cancer that act on nearby sensory nerves. Sensitized nerves, in turn, secrete factors that potentially modulate growth and metastasis of the cancer. Whilst nerves and epithelial cells normally interact in healthy tissues, a better understanding of the disturbed interactions that occur in cancer can lead to new ways to both treat cancer and alleviate cancer pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative Diseases caused by mixtures of bacteria are often more serious and harder to treat that those caused by a single organism. Periodontal (gum) diseases are caused by mixtures of microbes that communicate with each other to regulate the level of disease-causing potential of the microbial community. In this proposal we shall study the communication mechanisms that allow periodontal bacteria to increase production of toxic products, become more metabolically active, and resist killing by the host.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Persistent Jak2 signaling in myeloproliferative neoplasm (MPNs) defined as Philadelphia chromosome negative (Ph-) myeloproliferative disorders (MPDs) provided rationale for the targeted anti-Jak2 tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI). However, unlike the efficacy of ABL inhibitors in eliminating the leukemic cells in Ph+ MPN, Jak2 mutant clones are resistant to JAK2 inhibitor treatment. Here we provide molecular insight how MAPK feed-back regulation by DUSP1 protect the Ph- cells from TKI induced cell death and demonstrate that blocking DUSP1 activity leads to effective elimination of MPN cells. While the project focuses on MPN (the paradigm for TKI therapy), the findings should be readily translatable to kinase-addicted diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rupturing of arteriovenous malformation (AVM) in the brain is a serious medical problem that can cause significant morbidity and mortality, and often requires urgent embolization to stop bleeding. Currently used FDA approved liquid embolic agents for brain AVMs are associated with significant limitations, including toxicity from organic solvents, difficulty in delivery, danger of being washed away, lack of universality to block wide range of vasculature sizes, no intrinsic radiopacity for visualization on X-ray, and lack of therapeutic treatment. To address the aforementioned issues, we propose to develop biocompatible injectable gel embolic agents that are visible on various imaging modalities, offer flexibility to penetrate varying AVM vasculature geometry and serve as therapeutic carrier for the minimally invasive treatment of brain AVMs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Toxoplasma gondii infects a third of the global population and, when contracted by a pregnant woman, can cause severe disease in the developing fetus. In order to reach the fetus, T. gondii must surmount the placenta, an organ that has evolved specifically to restrict pathogens. This proposal investigates how T. gondii manipulates the development and function of placental cells to facilitate its own transmission.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed 2023-2028 Johns Hopkins University, Tanzania Red Cross Society and Muhimbili University School of Public Health and Social Sciences Education and Mentoring Program On Surgical Work and Rehabilitation in Tanzania (EMPOWER-TZ) will strengthen research capacity to address surgery, rehabilitation, and humanitarian health in Tanzania, a middle-income country in east Africa where the burden of surgical problems among refugees are twice that of non-refugee settings in low- and middle-income countries. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mineralocorticoid receptor (MR) antagonists are a promising class of drugs currently under investigation for heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF), a growing cause of illness and mortality, but it remains unclear how these medicines work in HFpEF and which patients they benefit most. Primary aldosteronism (PA) is typically considered a rare cause of severe hypertension and heart disease that can be effectively treated with MR antagonists; however, milder forms of PA are common but underrecognized in all stages of high blood pressure, raising the possibility that PA might also be an unrecognized cause of HFpEF. Our proposed research aims to understand the mechanisms of how PA might lead to HFpEF, using cardiac imaging tools to examine changes in the heart's structure, function, and blood supply, in order to help guide the use of MR antagonists as a targeted treatment for heart failure.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative This project will evaluate the genetic etiology of both rare and common forms of infertility and delayed puberty. During the K99 phase, the proposal will apply cutting edge genomic analysis techniques to discover novel risk genomic loci in congenital hypogonadism and perform functional analyses in disease relevant cell lines to elucidate the underlying biological mechanisms. Building upon these analyses, in the R00 phase I will explore the genomes of constitutional delayed puberty to identify risk genes and build novel statistical models to associate genomic variation with puberty timing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Microelectrodes implanted in the brain are critical tools for recording and stimulation in neuromodulation approaches to treat a variety of neurological conditions, however, poor long-term stability and functional performance limit their clinical application. The objective of this proposal is to develop iron chelation as a therapeutic approach in intracortical implants, understand the effects of iron accumulation at electrode sites on microglia and neuron degeneration and its impact on electrophysiological signals. Further, the proposal will determine an optimum iron chelator and develop a microelectrode array platform for local delivery of iron chelators at the electrode tissue interface to improve long-term functionality of implanted electrodes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Polygenic risk scores (PRS) are set to play a key role in advancing our understanding of the etiology and treatment of disease. While the application of genome-wide PRS is burgeoning across biomedical research, we propose that pathway-specific PRS have even greater potential to provide etiological insights and will help pave the way to precision medicine. Here we introduce a new generation of pathway-specific polygenic risk scores, informed by biological function, and deliver a comprehensive computational tool for their analysis, applying it to perform patient stratification in schizophrenia and bipolar disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative:  A cardinal trait of the tumor microenvironment is that it is immuno-suppressive, and converting it to one that is immuno-supportive is the key to developing effective immunotherapies that can combat cancer. This proposal focuses on a largely unexplored area of tumor immunology— the metabolic control of T cell function and survival in tumors— and seeks to determine if the deregulated metabolic states of tumor cells directly contribute to the development of an immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment by altering the function, phenotype and metabolic states of tumor infiltrating T cells. This work has the potential to open up a new dimension of immunoregulation in tumors and determine if T cell metabolic reprogramming offers new opportunities for cancer immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Breastfeeding is beneficial for both mother and child; however, mothers with obesity and type 2 diabetes often have insufficient milk production. We hypothesize that adipocytes in the breast tissue interact with the mammary epithelial cells to undergo dramatic remodeling, with play critical roles in establishing breastfeeding, as well as post-weaning lactation suppression and cessation. Our findings will provide fundamental knowledge to the fields of both adipose and mammary gland biology, provide novel insights into lactation and involution complications in women with metabolic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The ongoing intertwined pandemics of viral infections of HIV/AIDS and SARS-CoV-2/COVID-19 and substance use disorders (AUD), unexpectedly bring antiviral drugs and substance abuse disorders together, which severely damage the liver. This project will identify specific off-target(s) of commonly used anti-HIV and anti-COVID-19 drugs, investigate pathogenic mechanisms, and seek therapeutic solutions to mitigate the devastating side effects of antivirals on the liver.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Mechanobiology has emerged as a new frontier in T cell biology. However, the mechanisms are poorly understood, which impact our collective ability to understand, predict, and control T cell immune recognition. Here, the mechanisms of T cell mechanobiology will be elucidated and used to better understand and control T cell recognition, with wide implications for understanding and manipulating the immune system in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Aging has been known to be a common risk factor to the large group of age-related disorders, including Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (AD/ADRD). However, the mechanisms by which aging increases vulnerability to the toxicity of proteins related with AD remain unknown. This Program Project aims at answering this question building in the multidisciplinary team assembled (with expertise in biology of aging, neurodegeneration, lysosomal biology, metabolism, nutrient sensing, immunology, stem cells, medicinal chemistry, drug development and advance imaging procedures), the programmatic approach and the series of tools, resources and models developed by the team in previous periods. We will analyze if the age- dependent changes in autophagy are behind the aggravating effect of aging in AD-related proteotoxicity and test if preventing autophagy deterioration with genetical, chemical and dietary intervention is beneficial in this context. Our studies may ultimately lead to fundamental insights in understanding, treating or preventing AD and other common diseases related with loss of proteostasis that affect our elders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Drug response is inherited in much the same way as other traits like height, hair color, and the risk for some diseases. Pharmacogenomics studies how human genetic (DNA) variation influences the response to drugs. The PharmGKB resource aims to catalog all the human variation that impacts drug response, so that individual genetic data can be used to choose drugs for the individual that are more likely to work, and less likely to cause side effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  We discovered that the natural product EnnA is a novel Heat Shock Protein 90 (Hsp90) inhibitor that exhibits a powerful antitumor activity through a novel mechanism involving dual effects: cancer cell toxicity that increases its immunogenicity, and modulation of the tumor microenvironment that reduces immunotolerance. Mechanistically, Enniatin A binds to the middle domain of Hsp90 and reduces the protein level of several oncogenic proteins and the programmed cell death ligand-1 (PDL-1), a key mediator of tumor-induced immune tolerance. Enniatin A is a promising compound combining to eradicate cancer through inactivation of the Hsp90 pathway.

The core has a component of imaging  service to provide support to routine imaging procedures and sample preparation and a key component of  innovation that will develop new imaging procedures on superresolution and light-sheet microscopy for use in  the study of proteostasis in aging. The core provides support for interpretation of imaging data as well as monitors  rigor on experimental design and image data analysis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Dysregulated mitochondrial pathways have been increasingly implicated in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), with the major focus being in the context of epithelial cells. We have observed that a number of IBD- associated genes regulate mitochondrial functions, which in turn, modulate key responses across a range of pattern recognition receptors (PRR) in macrophages. We will define mechanisms for mitochondrial contributions to PRR-initiated outcomes in human macrophages, determine roles for fine-tuning these outcomes in vivo in intestinal inflammation and infection, and establish how these mitochondrial functions are modulated by IBD-associated genetic variants and in intestinal tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: All four Projects require the use of similar age-controlled autophagy and CAN proteotoxicity associated with Alzheimer’s disease mouse models, but focus on different tissues. Centralizing the procedures involving animals in the Core: 1) maximizes animal use; 2) offers uniformity across the different projects; and 3) allows integration of the information obtained from different systems by the different projects. The interventions performed by the core to modulate autophagy may help set the basis for future anti-aging interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Large scale, traumatic orthopedic injuries can leave individuals with lifelong limitations in daily function. Our work seeks to understand if the local muscle environment and metabolism is limiting to adaption during various treatment and rehabilitation approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Cancers that depend on the spatial location of the disease affect all ethnicities, and are diagnosed each year in large numbers in the United States, leading to large, rich repositories of patient data. This project develops a longitudinal decision support tool to assist clinicians in selecting treatments that balance survival and side-effects responses to cancer therapy. The project will lead to better insights into the biological and therapeutic factors related to cancer survival and toxicity, allowing personalization of care at the individual level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Although it is well accepted that aging is a risk factor for the so call age-related disorders such as for example Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias, the mechanism(s) by which aging increases vulnerability to those disorders and whether interventions to slow down aging will be protective against age-related disorders has not been fully explored. This project investigates the impact of aging of one of the mechanisms used by cells as defense against intracellular toxicity and damage on the onset and progression of a highly prevalent disease among our elders, Alzheimer’s disease. We will use the plethora of molecular information on these surveillance mechanisms obtained in our previous studies to boost their function in old organisms with the goal of prevent or delay onset of neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Attenuated recycling of cellular components (autophagy) frequently occurs in aging immune cells and perturbs normal cell function and immunity. We will be the first to investigate how autophagy-impaired immune cells contribute to and are affected by neurodegeneration and AD. Our study may provide a new therapeutic avenue for patients with dementia, and potentially a paradigm for other age-associated tissue and organ-degenerative processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Hepatitis B virus (HBV) remains endemic in many regions of the world, and prevention measures beyond vaccination are necessary to reach disease elimination goals. In sub-Saharan African settings like the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), where HBV prevalence is 3.3% (~3.5 million infections), limited available evidence indicates that horizontal exposures in households and communities are driving endemicity. This proposal applies epidemiological, spatial, and genomic approaches to a large household study of HBV in Kinshasa, DRC, to understand HBV transmission dynamics and drivers of transmission and will inform expanded prevention programs towards elimination efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (AD/ADRD) are neurodegenerative disorders characterized by progressive dementia caused in part by proteoxicity and neuronal death. AD/ADRD are the 6th leading cause of mortality in the U.S. and affects approximately 5.4 million individuals in the U.S. This number is projected to increase to 13.8 million by mid-century. Unfortunately, despite significant research, the deliverables have been marginal due to complex multifactorial causes of AD/ADRD. Studies in this application will test new incisive hypotheses that restoring global metabolic function and preventing AD- related proteotoxicity by activating macroautophagy (MA) will delay cognitive decline. Studies will also determine whether dietary interventions that activate MA will delay cognitive decline in models of AD- related proteotoxicity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Progress in the development of in vivo biomarkers for the subregions of the medial temporal lobe (MTL), which have distinct functional roles and vulnerabilities to disease pathologies, has been hindered due to a lack of valid, standard segmentation protocols. The proposed research will leverage ongoing efforts and multicentric datasets to develop a harmonized MTL subregions segmentation protocol and validate it in clinical populations of early- stage Alzheimer’s disease and semantic variant Primary Progressive Aphasia. The proposed research is aligned with the goals of standardizing neuroimaging tools, and will have broad implications for reproducible research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol use disorder and prenatal alcohol exposure continue to impose a tremendous burden on society and efficacious treatment options are severely lacking. The proposed work will investigate a novel aspect of alcohol exposure in adults and during pregnancy, which is mediated by direct interactions between metabolic and epigenetic processes. This new knowledge can be leveraged to develop novel treatments for these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) are considered the “gold standard” study design to determine the effectiveness of therapeutic interventions; however, they often suffer from rigor and transparency problems, leading to potential research waste. The proposed research will develop a set of natural language processing (NLP) methods to identify information related to rigor and transparency from RCT reports (protocols and results publications). These methods will support tools and resources that assist stakeholders of clinical research in maintaining high reporting standards, synthesizing information on methodological quality, and fostering open science practices, and will contribute to improvements throughout the scientific ecosystem, leading to better patient care and health policy.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Persistence for longer periods of time and during periods of heavy immune surveillance may select for features that allow infected cells to evade detection and clearance by the immune system. IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Narrative Psychiatric disorders, including alcohol use disorder and other stress-related disorders (e.g., post-traumatic stress disorder, major depressive disorder and others), are a set of chronic, non-communicable diseases (NCDs) that constitute a global public health problem of enormous economic, social, and medical cost internationally. Low and middle-income and developing countries such as Thailand are disproportionately affected due to both unique stressors experienced and less well-established institutional infrastructures (facilities, personnel, and research) dedicated to the understanding, treatment and prevention of psychiatric disorders; especially so during the COVID-19 pandemic when many countries, including Thailand, experienced extensive shutdowns and an interruption of the tourist industry, a major source of income. In the current application, we propose a collaborative research training program in the interdisciplinary and translational research of stress, alcohol use and psychopathology between three Thai institutes (the Chulalongkorn University Faculty of Medicine (a leading medical research center in Thailand and established collaborator, the lead Thai site), Phramongkutklao Hospital and Medical College in Bangkok, Thailand (a new collaborator), and Prince of Songkla University in Hat Yai, Thailand (also a new collaborator)) and the Yale University School of Medicine in the U.S.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative HIV incidence and mortality are increasing markedly in Georgia despite many available evidence-based interventions to prevent HIV, which are sub-optimally implemented due to challenges in delivery in key populations like PWID and MSM, where the epidemic is concentrated. The proposed Georgian Implementation Science Fogarty Training (GIFT) Program is designed with short-, medium- and long-term training to address the current implementation gap through training of 4 faculty and 6 doctoral students at Ilia State University (in collaboration with Yale University), creating a regional resource and training hub and to provide a summer bootcamp training program each year for local and regional implementers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant for human health and disease because allergic asthma is currently on the rise in the United States, therefore there is a need to understand the mechanisms that drive disease in order to identify new targets for the development of therapeutic options. Our proposal has identified Blimp-1 as a novel tissue-specific driver of allergic asthma that is required for the development of allergen-specific Th2 cells known to drive inflammation of the lung and subsequent airway inflammation. Therefore, this research has translational significance for patients with asthma while also elucidating basic mechanisms of the pathogenesis of allergic disease and T cell responses to allergens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Substance use, particularly the use of stimulants and opioids in the fourth wave of the opioid epidemic, are a major public health problem. Research is needed to develop new substance use disorder treatments and to determine how to best broadly disseminate the treatments that are currently available and effective. The National Institute on Drug Abuse’s National Drug Abuse Treatment Clinical Trials Network (CTN) and the Big South/West Node will contribute their expertise to solving the substance use problems impacting our Southern region as well as nationally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE To systematically investigate the mechanisms of risk genes implicated in diseases and disorders including autism spectrum disorder and neurodevelopmental delay, we will establish functional genomic technologies called Perturb-map and Perturb-seq as in vivo genetic screening tools. We will combine a series of genomic technologies including tissue clearing, high-throughput imaging, single-cell multi-omics, and in vivo CRISPR- Cas9 gene editing, to seek cellular mechanisms across brain regions and their effects in cytoarchetecture and neuronal projectome in intact, whole brains. This interdisciplinary approach is set to establish modular and broadly applicable tools to allow discoveries of key anatomical, cellular, molecular, and circuit-level mechanisms related to diverse genetic variants in human diseases and disorders.
