IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma (DIPG), the leading cause of brain tumor-related mortality of childhood in the US, is driven by aberrant chromatin structures. This grant application proposes to better elucidate the molecular basis for these aberrations. Insights gained from the experiments proposed here will pave way for future therapeutic development to ultimately allow children burdened with this disease to live longer, healthier lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance Statement Hydroxyurea (HU) is a commonly prescribed disease-modifying medication, approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), for adolescents with sickle cell disease; however, low hydroxyurea adherence limits the use of this medication in clinical practice. In addition, the longitudinal relationship between hydroxyurea adherence and patients' health-related quality of life, such as pain, fatigue and depression, has not been studied, and, to date, mobile health or mHealth interventions for hydroxyurea adherence have not been evaluated in adolescents with sickle cell disease. This study will examine the relationship between hydroxyurea adherence and health-related quality of life overtime among adolescents with sickle cell disease, and determine if a mobile or smartphone app (HU-Go) is a feasible and an acceptable intervention that can improve hydroxyurea (HU) adherence in this population.!

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative People who are diagnosed with thyroid cancer often receive radioactive iodine therapy. This therapy can lead to many symptoms that patients did not expect. Patients also report difficulty managing these symptoms. The first goal of this project is to develop a web-based intervention that provides information and support to patients with thyroid cancer who receive radioactive iodine therapy. The second goal is to test if the intervention reduces patient symptom burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Protein radicals are involved in a range of both beneficial as well as harmful chemical reactions in living organisms. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative: Stress during pregnancy is common and alters neurodevelopment in a way that increases the risk of development of psychiatric disorders in the offspring. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Relevance to public health Currently available oral cholera vaccines have a number of shortcomings. Developing improved vaccines or vaccination strategies is hampered by the reality that we do not currently understand the mechanism of immune protection against cholera. We have strong preliminary evidence that immune responses targeting O-specific polysaccharide (OSP) affect Vibrio cholerae, and we here propose an investigative approach to define and evaluate these effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research seeks to address the substantial burden of unmet mental health need for Black and Latinx children who have been sexually abused. We will develop and pilot test a novel engagement intervention for Black and Latinx caregivers, whose children have the highest rates of unmet mental health need after sexual abuse. This intervention, which aims to increase children’s receipt of mental health services after sexual abuse, will provide an urgently needed strategy to improve mental health care delivery and promote positive outcomes for children at significant risk of lifelong psychopathology from sexual abuse.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In Armenia (AM), NCDs account for 93% of deaths, cancer death rates are the 2nd highest globally, and CVD rates are the 35th highest; thus, addressing NCD risk factors (e.g., tobacco/alcohol use, diet) is crucial, with 52% of men smoking (11th highest rate globally) and 48% of adults overweight/obese in AM. Social determinants (SDs) impact NCD risk factors, outcomes, and disparities, and are key drivers of NCDs in AM; thus, we propose the Armenia-US Collaboration to Address Chronic Disease via Education in Social Determinants Science (ACCESS) program. ACCESS is a strategic partnership between George Washington University and American University of Armenia, alongside AM’s Ministry of Health and its entities, and aims to reduce the NCD burden in AM by enhancing research capacity related to NCD prevention and control, focusing on SDs of NCD risk factors; we will enhance (1) formal training and institutional infrastructure, (2) mentored research opportunities, and (3) dissemination and translational skills to optimize impact in AM and globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Prenatal exposure to unsafe levels of heavy metals such as cadmium and arsenic through food and drinking water is an unavoidable risk factor concerning communities with disproportionately high burden of airway disorders, healthcare disparity and environmental injustice. There are no effective prevention and intervention strategies against prenatal exposures due to the lack of understanding in abnormal vs normal airway development modulated by environmental stressors. This application will provide critical mechanistic information on how prenatal exposures at human-relevant levels quantitatively impact airway development and growth in mouse models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The research in this proposal will generate novel methodologies to improve disease risk prediction for the underrepresented minority populations by integrating trans-ethnic, disparate sources of information on the genetic markers and other factors such as clinical factors, health conditions, and socio-demographic indicators. In addition, it will provide enhanced, user-friendly disease risk prediction tools for multi-ethnic populations, as well as general data integration methodologies that can be widely implemented to accelerate future research in disease risk prediction and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Single-cell sequencing of clinical specimens uniquely enables studies of tissue heterogeneity, a significant barrier to precision medicine. However, the use of single-cell assays for clinical decision making is limited. This project bridges that gap and develops algorithms to integrate heterogeneous single-cell datasets to support the selection of combination therapies.

In this proposal we use MDMA as a probe to understand neural mechanisms of potentially therapeutic social behaviors, which may lead to safer treatment for a range of psychiatric conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: SIRT3 Narrative We discovered that the mitochondrial sirtuin SIRT3 is required to maintain the growth and survival of DLBCLs and is especially highly expressed in those lymphomas with the worst clinical outcome. Herein, we will develop the basis for translating SIRT3 targeted therapy to the clinic for these chemotherapy resistant patients who have few viable therapeutic options. We will develop SIRT3 lead compounds for clinical translation and define potential resistance mechanism and the means to overcome them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This project will study how virtual reality augmented bicycling using visual feedback and competition will increase exercise intensity, motivation, and enjoyment for persons with Parkinson's Disease. The short-term goal of the study is to select exercise strategies that yield the highest intensity and promote greatest motivation. The long- term goal is to design optimal exercise training programs that are accessible and promote mobility and fitness for persons with Parkinson's Disease so they may maintain a high-level of activity, participation and well-being.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Subject motion is the fundamental impediment to reaping the full benefits of fetal-brain magnetic resonance imaging, as it frequently produces images with dramatic artifacts. The goal of this project is to exploit innovations in deep learning and integrate them into the acquisition pipeline to overcome the challenges posed by motion in fetal neuroimaging studies. This will be achieved by using fast, automated scan prescription of standard anatomical planes and by adaptively updating the acquisition as motion happens in the scanner, based on sub-second navigator scans interleaved with the imaging sequence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: TNBC is a recalcitrant malignancy with limited therapeutic options. Our research supported by this grant has demonstrated that the MUC1-C oncoprotein drives TNBC stemness, drug resistance and immune evasion. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative: MM is a common disease that can cause substantial morbidity and mortality in patients. The success of the predictive models developed in this project will not only provide a quantitative and reliable decision support for early prediction of treatment response and patient outcome but also constitute a strong foundation to meet our long-term goal of developing a clinically-translatable framework to facilitate clinical decision making in early diagnosis and tumor burden assessment, staging, assessing treatment response, optimizing therapeutic regimens, monitoring MM progression/regression and detecting recurrence, as well as assisting in new therapeutic agent and drug development. The advancement in these areas is expected to deliver the promise of precision medicine for MM by improving patient outcomes and reducing the cost of healthcare.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Projective Narrative Dehydration due to diarrheal diseases remains a leading cause of death in both children and adults worldwide, yet health workers lack validated tools that can help them assess and manage dehydration in patients with diarrhea. This proposed research will validate a recently developed mobile phone application that uses artificial intelligence to help health workers of all types to estimate the severity of dehydration in patients with diarrhea and provide the correct type and amount of rehydration fluids. This novel clinical decision support tool has the potential to improve medical care for the hundreds of millions of patients each year presenting to healthcare facilities around the world with diarrhea.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Blood flow restriction training (BFRT) is appealing as a rehabilitation strategy because it allows for strengthening with low exercise loads, but high-quality research is lacking, especially in patients with shoulder disorders. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will inform decisions for designing a future rigorous large-scale efficacy trial on BFRT as a treatment for shoulder pain. The proposed project is relevant to the NIAMS’ mission to investigate the cause, treatment, and prevention of musculoskeletal diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For the gastrointestinal tract to function properly, the patterns of contractions in the muscle layers must be tightly regulated and coordinated. Normal contractile patterns in the gastrointestinal tract are dependent on a cell type called the interstitial cell of Cajal and on a transporter named SLC4A4, which is expressed in interstitial cells of Cajal. This proposal will study how the expression of SLC4A4 is regulated, how the transporter regulates electrical activity of the gastrointestinal tract, and how it contributes to both gastrointestinal health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although cortical glutamate synaptic impairments are considered a core pathophysiological feature underlying brain dysfunction in schizophrenia, the nature of these synaptic impairments in schizophrenia is almost completely unknown. This project investigates the schizophrenia disease effect on presynaptic, postsynaptic and mitochondrial ultrastructural correlates of function at individual glutamate synapses using a focused ion beam- scanning electron microscopy approach, and molecular perturbations underlying these findings using a synaptosome proteomic approach, in postmortem human brain. These studies will determine the structural and molecular bases of cortical glutamatergic synaptic impairments in schizophrenia to inform functional and molecular therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We have developed a group of novel anticancer chemicals, curaxins, which are currently tested in clinic; they act via disrupting of packaging of genetic material, DNA, in tumor cells. Contrary to exiting drugs targeting DNA they do not cause mutations. We recently identified a new feature of these compounds that they can activate immune response against tumors; in this proposal we will figure out how they do this and how we can utilize this property in the clinic to get maximal benefit for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung cancer relapses in over half of all treated patients; relapsed disease does not respond well to current therapies including those directed at boosting the body’s immune response against the tumor. We and others determined that a protein called STAT3 promotes the growth and survival of lung cancer cells and blocks tumor immunity. We have developed a safe drug that effectively targets STAT3 that we propose to test in this proposal for benefit in mouse models and patients with lung cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Using both tobacco and cannabis during pregnancy is more common in minoritized groups and can make quitting smoking in pregnancy and remaining smoke free postpartum difficult. Because depression symptoms are addressable and are also related to experiences of discrimination and trauma, we will collaborate with people from marginalized identities to understand the ways in which depressive symptoms relate to using tobacco and cannabis during pregnancy. We will then co-develop and test an intervention to address prenatal depressive symptoms to encourage people to quit tobacco and cannabis during pregnancy and stay quit postpartum.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our goal is to develop a novel in-plane IVUS/fiber optic imaging-integrated fine needle/ balloon catheter system for TIPS creation. Tests of the fine needle/balloon system in pig cadavers for TIPS creation resulted in 100% success of placing a 5Fr.catheter in portal vein from the right hepatic vein. This IVUS/fiber optic borescope-incorporated fine needle(22G)/balloon catheter system is expected to significantly lower the risk and difficulties of TIPS techniques, which will ultimately increase the availability of TIPS treatment and benefit millions of patients with decompensated cirrhosis, particularly those in underdeveloped countries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Reward-associated cues are essential for adaptive decision making and contribute to maladaptive states, such as addiction. Critically, not all individuals respond in the same way to cues, producing unique vulnerability trajectories to psychiatric disease. Here, we investigate the behavioral and neurobiological mechanisms of individual variability in sensory-guided reward learning and addiction-like behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will use innovative methods to incorporate predictors from longitudinal data, collected in routine clinical practice, into models that diagnose NAFLD and predict future risk of liver events, such as cirrhosis and related complications. Lack of screening methods in current clinical practice and absence of symptoms until late-stage lead to delayed diagnosis and poor patient outcomes; therefore, early diagnosis and prediction of disease trajectory at primary care level will enable timely intervention and selection of patients who need specialized testing and hepatology referral. The project is relevant to the NIDDK’s mission because it will create a sound clinical pathway management for the most common chronic liver disease affecting 80-100 million US adults, which will ultimately decrease health care burden and improve population outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic, biochemical, and model organism studies indicate that genetic variants in the gene encoding the signaling protein TRIO contribute to the pathology of schizophrenia, autism spectrum disorders (ASD), and intellectual disability (ID). Our analysis of a cluster of variants associated with ASD and ID has identified a mechanism that controls TRIO signaling ability. Our proposal aims to identify small molecule compounds that can modulate this key signaling function to use as probes to understand how TRIO works and how disrupting TRIO function impairs brain development, paving the way for validation of TRIO as drug target and for future therapeutics development for neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Spatial transcriptomics technology enables structure-function analysis of tissues at single-cell resolution producing atlases with a broad impact on many biomedical research areas, yet, despite tremendous technological progress in spatial transcriptomics, all existing spatial transcriptomics technologies are limited to thin 2D sections. We propose to develop a new approach for whole organ spatial transcriptomics based on the integration of new ﬂuorescent in situ hybridization technology we invented, scRNAseq reference, and light-sheet microscopy. We will demonstrate the new technology by creating a complete cell type and gene expression atlases of the whole mouse brain.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Thousands of hospitalized Veterans receive inappropriate antibiotic treatment with a class of antibiotics known as “anti-anaerobic” antibiotics. Recent research suggests that this class of antibiotics is particularly disruptive to the gut microbiome and that this disruption may increase mortality in hospitalized Veterans. This proposal will use a big-data analysis of electronic medical record data to determine if anti-anaerobic antibiotics may increase mortality in hospitalized Veterans. It will also look at the impact of anti-anaerobic antibiotics on the microbiome and inflammation in hospitalized Veterans. As a result of this research, physicians can make better decisions about their antibiotic use and avoid harm related to antibiotic treatment. This research will also support the training and development of Dr. Rishi Chanderraj, a VA researcher who will combine big-data analysis, advanced statistical methods, and molecular techniques to improve our understanding of the impact of antibiotic treatment on the microbiome and Veteran health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Relevance NK cells are powerful immune cells that kill infected and cancerous cells by secreting lytic granules onto their surface. The proposed work seeks to convert these cells from “one cell at a time”, directional killers into killers that can eradicate multiple diseased cells at a time by releasing granules in multiple directions. We propose strategies to alter modes of killing as well as new high-resolution systems to observe and test killing in complex 3-dimensional tumor environments with the ultimate goal of improving NK cell therapies for cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Type 1 diabetes (T1D) is an autoimmune disease of increasing incidence resulting in the loss of pancreatic β- cells and lifelong dependency on exogenous insulin with only one recently approved preventative measure to marginally delay onset. Our preliminary evidence indicates Cornus officinalis (CO), an herbal medicine, can promote pancreatic β-cell survival via promotion of Nrf2 and autophagy, stimulate antioxidant pathways and inhibit onset of T1D in the non-obese diabetic (NOD) mouse. Therefore, this proposal aims to determine clinical efficacy in-vivo by elucidating the biological mechanism of CO to be utilized as a therapeutic option for T1D interventional therapy.

PHR: We are proposing to further develop a percutaneous cavopulmonary assist system toward clinical application. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Suicide is a serious public health crisis and a leading cause of death in children, and those whose mothers have a history of suicidal behavior are especially vulnerable to an early and persistent course of suicidal thoughts and behaviors. Results from this study will advance understanding of emotion regulation as one intergenerational mechanism of suicide risk transmission while simultaneously testing a prevention and intervention model to mitigate suicide risk at the level of the mother-child dyad. The ultimate impact of this work is to inform improved, evidence-based assessment tools and identify new targets for prevention and early intervention strategies to reduce suicide risk and improve psychosocial functioning in vulnerable children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative 7T MRI image quality is degraded by inhomogeneities in the static B0 and transmit B1+ fields, which reduce its overall diagnostic value and slows its translation to clinics. The B0 and B1+ problems have so far been approached independently, thus yielding two separate hardware solutions, namely multi-coil (MC) shim arrays for B0 shimming and parallel transmission (pTx) for flip-angle control, that are expensive and difficult to integrate and operate. We propose a new class of excitation pulses that leverage the degrees-of-freedom of MC shim arrays to homogenize the flip-angle distribution at 7T, thus yielding an integrated solution for both B0 and flip-angle shimming that is cheaper and bypasses the complex safety management of pTx, and may therefore be more readily deployed in clinics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Confocal endo-microscopy is a powerful tool for high-resolution imaging of cells and tissues inside the body, allowing for high-sensitivity and high-specificity diagnosis of diseases, including cancer. However, current confocal endo-microscope probes are made of discrete bulky optical elements and require scanning, resulting in slow imaging speed and large size and thus hindering their broader utility. The goal of the proposed research is to overcome these limitations by developing a metasurface based chromatic confocal endo-microscope, which promises to enhance medical imaging and enable fast, minimally invasive diagnosis of diseases deep within the body.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This will be the first fully-powered clinical trial that will use formal tests of both mediation and moderation to identify the neuromodulatory mechanisms of mindfulness meditation and self-hypnosis relative to a control condition for reducing chronic pain intensity in older adults. The study findings will benefit the health of older adults by providing an empirical basis for streamlining these evidence-based interventions, which will reduce the burden of chronic pain, and provide an effective non-pharmacological alternative to opioids. Moreover, advancing our knowledge of treatment moderators will inform precision medicine and the development of patient-treatment matching algorithms which will optimize both treatment efficacy and efficiency.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of this study is to test the hypothesis that disturbed sleep is a modifiable, bio- behavioral mechanism contributing to impaired vascular function and increased CVD risk among young adults with exposure to Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACEs). We propose an innovative, robust hybrid approach to objectively quantify the degree to which lower sleep quality contributes to ACEs-related endothelial dysfunction, inflammation, and oxidative stress in young adults, and to determine if improved sleep quality is causally related to improvements in vascular function among young adults with ACEs. These findings will provide the critical groundwork needed to develop therapeutic strategies to improve CVD risk in individuals with exposure to ACEs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: Although many major psychiatric disorders have their onset in adults, there is increasing evidence that traumatic experiences early in life can predispose an individual to illness as adults. Moreover, males and females show different susceptibilities to pathologies as adults following peripubertal stress. We have found that major stressors delivered to male rats prepubertally versus females postpubertally, while acting similarly soon after the stress, show major differences in the pathways impacted as adults. We propose that this is due to differential regulation by the medial prefrontal cortex. By studying the factors that link differential stress susceptibility to stress-induced damage at the systems level, we hope to better understand why there are substantial differences in susceptibility to adult pathology based on sex, which may lead to more effective means for early intervention that may prevent the emergence of major psychiatric disorders later in life.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative: Sudden Unexpected Infant Death (SUID) is the leading cause of infant mortality up to one year of age. A significant proportion of the ~3,500 SUIDS per year in the US are classified as Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS). The cause of SIDS is complex, multifactorial, and remains largely unknown. Here we implement an animal model of SIDS to: 1) investigate new (and existing) central and peripheral neural mechanisms associated with mortality; 2) perform screening of blood and urine to discover several new biomarkers as potential predictors of infants at increased risk of SIDS; and 3) test a clinically approved drug that may be a novel prophylactic measure to prevent SIDS.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE By using machine learning in satellite imagery and other geotagged “big data” sources, this project has the potential to fundamentally change the measurement of maternal and child health indicators in low- and middle- income countries, providing up-to-date estimates for each village and neighborhood in a country. Until now, measurement of maternal and child health has relied on household surveys, which are expensive, conducted infrequently, and cover only a small fraction of all populations and areas in a country. This research is relevant to public health because it uses an inexpensive and scalable method that could enable the geographically precise targeting of interventions and up-to-date monitoring of changes in key maternal and child health indicators, and additionally lead to a low-cost approach for evaluating the effect of past policies and interventions on maternal and child health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Radiotherapy (RT) is an effective prostate cancer treatment that provides cures; however, radiotoxicity adversely impacts the lives of cancer survivors, most notably older patients. There are no predictive biomarkers associated with its incidence, nor are there durable therapies preventing radiotoxicity. Here, we investigate novel players, extracellular vesicles induced by RT, for their action, predictive power, and therapeutic targets for radiotoxicity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: In the US, keloids most commonly occur in individuals with African ancestry, are less prevalent in other populations of color and more rare in Whites. Despite the severe physical, psychological and social impact of keloids and despite the unsatisfactory treatment success, this wound healing disorder has been understudied and contributes to racial disparity in research and health care. Keloid research is highly relevant to public health and is recognized as such by the NIH/NIAMS Strategic Plan for fiscal years 2020-2024.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy (FSHD) is a progressive hereditary disorder that affects ~4 per 100,000 of the world’s population and causes patients to have impaired ambulation, weakness, muscle wasting, and impaired physical function. We previously completed an open label safety and tolerability study of testosterone paired with recombinant human growth hormone (rHGH) in FSHD, where participants demonstrated marked improvements in strength, walking distance, symptomatic burden, and lean muscle mass. Through this one-year planning grant, we will conduct and complete all of the necessary activities in order to conduct a definitive, multicenter, double-blind, placebo-controlled, efficacy trial of this very promising therapeutic approach for patients with FSHD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Invasive aspergillosis causes significant mortality in patients with weakened immune systems. We seek to identify the early host-pathogen interactions dictating the outcome of infection through cytosolic sensing of fungal patterns of pathogenesis via MDA5/MAVS. Full activation of these early innate immune defense pathways will provide optimized resistance against respiratory fungal pathogens, which can be used for the development of immune modulatory strategies aimed at improving outcomes in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative A major challenge in medicine is to better understand and treat human cancers. In this proposal, we aim to develop novel computational methods to analyze cancer genomes in order to help uncover alterations that play an important role in cancer development or that can elicit an anti-cancer immune response. Application of our approaches will not only advance our understanding of basic cancer biology but also improve prospects for personalized cancer treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Digital phenotyping methods have the potential to identify dynamic risk factors in psychopathology. In a 6- month longitudinal study, we will examine the additive and interactive effects of ecological momentary assessment (active digital phenotyping) and computational estimates of emotion derived from speech (passive digital phenotyping) to predict self-reported and clinician-rated mood symptoms in individuals with bipolar disorder. The resulting data will improve fine-grained and quantitative behavioral assessment tools that allow for personalized modeling of emotion and mood dynamics in the real-world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Endogenous and exogenous Aryl hydrocarbon Receptor (AhR) agonists, cinnabarinic acid and 2,3,7,8- tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin (TCDD) exhibit mutually exclusive transcription regulation of target genes, stanniocalcin 2 and cyp1a1 respectively with distinct physiological consequences. Cinnabarinic acid induced AhR-regulated stanniocalcin 2 provides hepatoprotection against non-alcoholic fatty liver disease. The experiments outlined in this proposal will characterize cinnabarinic acid-specific AhR-mediated regulation of stanniocalcin 2 and investigate mechanism by which AhR-stanniocalcin 2 signaling protect against steatohepatitis, which may prove instrumental in developing therapeutic strategies targeting hepatic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Over 450 million people suffer from type 2 diabetes, a disease which is defined by the failure of pancreatic β-cells. These studies will provide new insights into the mechanisms by which nutrient metabolism stimulates insulin secretion in β-cells via the metabolic enzyme pyruvate kinase, and identify how this key enzyme amplifies external cues from incretin hormones and paracrine signals from neighboring α-cells that act via G-protein coupled receptors. This work may lead to new therapeutic approaches to restore insulin secretion in patients with type 2 diabetes and related metabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The blood potassium concentration must be maintained within narrow limits for critical life functions, including regular heart rhythm, muscle contraction, proper nerve impulses, and hormone secretion. ROMK potassium channels in the kidney are critical in maintaining potassium balance. This project will illuminate the mechanisms by which ROMK channels are regulated in health and become dysregulated in disease and provide new insights to develop drugs that treat disorders of potassium balance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to study the impact of mucosal adjuvanted vaccination on the outcome of disease, host immune responses to and transmission events after experimental respiratory infection with influenza virus and SARS- CoV-2. Hereto we will use the guinea pig (influenza) and Syrian golden hamster (SARS-CoV-2), two established models for vaccination, infection and transmission studies with respiratory viruses. We will compare protection provided by mucosal adjuvanted vaccination to parenteral vaccination and will investigate the impact of induction of protective immune responses at mucosal sites on host immune responses to infection (hybrid immunity) and virus transmission between vaccinated infected animals and naïve receiver animals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative: Sinoatrial node dysfunction represents a significant clinical burden in the US and is the leading cause for surgical implantation of artificial pacemakers. This proposal seeks to define the underlying cellular interactions that maintain normal sinoatrial node function. Successful completion of these studies will uncover the homeostatic processes that support native cardiac pacemaking, identify how these processes become disrupted in disease, and provide critical insight for the design of next-generation of therapeutics for correcting human arrythmias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Cerebral cavernous malformations (CCMs) are vascular lesions in the central nervous system that cause debilitating neurological problems. CCMs are usually treated by surgical removal, which is invasive and risky. In this proposal, we are developing and testing an MR image-guided technology (i.e. focused ultrasound) for overcoming physical barriers to drug delivery to CCMs in an effort to better control their pathological progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Routine chest CT examinations contain prognostic information that is often underutilized for its value in primary prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD), leaving missed opportunities for incidental screening to predict future cardiovascular events, such as heart attack and stroke. Current risk assessment tools, such as Pooled Cohort Equations (PCE), are poor predictors of ASCVD due to data limitations, most notably the static nature of the data and lack of model complexity, resulting in misestimation in minority groups. A graph- based multimodal fusion model that integrates imaging and electronic medical record data is essential to addressing the data limitations of outdated tools and creating more sophisticated technology that supports opportunistic screening of a larger, more diverse population of patients as well as earlier prevention strategies and therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative When you inhale harmful bacteria or fungi, they can stimulate airway tuft cells found interspersed throughout the nasal cavity and sometimes in the lungs. Tuft cells activate antimicrobial and inflammatory responses that might be useful to pharmacologically target in diseases like chronic rhinosinusitis or asthma. The goal here is to determine how the receptors in these tuft cells are activated and regulate tuft cell function to understand how we can leverage them to treat airway diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our proposal uses well established implementation science theories, models, and frameworks to develop, implement, and evaluate Proyecto Tariki, a novel dengue prevention and control program. Tariki aims to address 50 years of previous dengue program failures by inclusion of: 1) a proven community mobilization strategy that includes a mobile/web-based application, 2) community led febrile surveillance with direct link to health systems to improve case management, and 3) pragmatic protocols for Ministries of Health to evaluate their vector control interventions. Project adoption, sustainability, and scale-up will reduce transmission risk and health burden of dengue.
